Sir:

Enclosed please find voucher No. 62 for $81.92 in favor of Marshall-Wells B.C. Ltd., for tools supplied to the Alert Bay Residential School. The authority is your letter of June 15, No.156-0-5.

I obtained the very best possible wholesale prices on this shipment from Marshall-Wells, Ltd., but did not put the matter up to competition as I knew that I was getting the best prices obtainable.

A few of the articles ordered have not yet arrived but will be filled in, and the amount of the order is coming considerably below the estimate.

Your obedient servant,

W.M. Halliday
Indian Agent

Sir:-

re Fire Equipment, Girls' Home, Alert Bay, B.C.

In view of the recent serious loss by fire of our Old Sun School at Gleichen, Alberta, I made another careful survey of both these buildings from the point of view of fire risk and facilities for escape from the building. The result of this inspection prompts me to write and ask if the Department would sanction the purchase of the following supplies:

2 - Guardene Fire Extinguishers, 2½ gallon type.

1 - only 30' Extension Fire Ladder.

2 - Pyrene Fire Extinguishers, 1 gallon type.

There are only two extinguishers in this building and I feel that these are not sufficient. The ladder is needed, in order to approach and get into this building from the outside. Being a Girls' Home, you will clearly understand that we must keep this building tightly locked at night and, in the event of fire being observed from the outside of the building, a ladder of this type would enable us to get into the building from the outside and help in clearing the dormitories.

The Pyrene extinguishers are needed for the oil house, as the Guardene type are useless in fires breaking out amidst oil, gasoline or other inflammable substances.

This equipment, coupled with systematic and frequent fire drills, will make this building reasonably safe from loss of life in the event of fire.

I have the honour to be, Sir

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Principal.

FEA:M
Dear Mr. Scott:

I find that I have not yet acknowledged the receipt of your very kind letter of the 13th ult., giving an account of your visit to Alert Bay, and of your decision with regard to the site for the proposed new School at this centre. As we discussed during your recent visit to Winnipeg, various aspects of this question, further reference, I think, need not be made to them here. There was one point, however, to which I omitted to refer at that time, and that is with regard to the pupilage which the new School should have. I have recently received a letter from Mr. Anfield, the Principal, suggesting that it should have accommodation for 175 pupils, namely, 100 boys and 75 girls. It is not very clear to me how such accommodation could be provided without sacrificing the symmetry of the School building, and I am of the opinion, that it would be better to have a building with a capacity of 200 pupils. Mr. Anfield states that he has 100 applications waiting, and as there are 4,640 Anglicans in B.C., according to the Departmental Report for 1926, with only two residential Schools, namely, the one at Lytton, and this one at Alert Bay, it seems to me that accommodation should be provided for 200 pupils or more. As our General Secretary will probably call on you early next week, I shall be glad if you will further discuss this important matter with him.

Yours very truly,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.O.
Ottawa, September 13, 1928.

Sir:

The Department is in receipt of a letter from the Principal of the Alert Bay Residential School in which he requests the following additional fire equipment for the girls' school:

- 2 Gardene fire extinguishers, 2½ Gal. type,
- 1 only 30' extension fire ladder,
- 2 Pyrene fire extinguishers, 1 gallon type.

Please visit this school at an early date and report to the Department what additional fire equipment you consider is required.

On the requisition forwarded for supplies for this school, the Principal requested 5 No. 3 single desks, also 2 rears and 2 fronts, to replace worn out desks in the girls' school. Please let me know if you consider these are necessary, and, if so, you should state the name of the manufacturer of the desks at present in the classroom.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

W. M. Halliday, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Alert Bay, B.C.
Ottawa, September 13, 1926.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of July 12th, requesting additional fire equipment for the Alert Bay Girls' School.

In reply I beg to say that Mr. Agent Halliday is being written in connection with this matter and your request for additional desks.

The Department would appreciate if you would conform with the general practice of principals of Indian residential schools by forwarding all your requests to the Indian Agent, who will write to the Department.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

F. Earl Airfield, Esq.,
Principal, Indian Res. School,
Alert Bay, B.C.
September 7th, 1928.

We have furnished the U.S. Indian Service with a very large number of our Units, which have worked out very satisfactorily, and we feel certain that you would be more than pleased with the performance of the ENGBERG Apparatus, and that we can quote you some very attractive prices.

Sir: Re - Alert Bay Industrial School,
Water Supply, Sewage Disposal
and Fire Protection.

In compliance with your instructions
of recent date, an investigation having refer-
ence to the suitability of the site, water supply
and sewage disposal for the new industrial school
at Alert Bay has been completed. I submit as
follows:-

INTRODUCTION

The new school buildings at Alert Bay
as proposed are similar to those recently com-
pleted at Lytton, with an accommodation of
approximately 175 persons. The site selected is
in close proximity to the present structures.
This selection was contingent on the finding of
suitable ground to bear the weight of the new
building.

BUILDING SITE

Tests were carried out over the ground
to be occupied by the new buildings.

The soil on the site was found to be
gravel for the first four feet in depth. This
gravel is very loose and unsuitable for footings.
However, at a depth of four feet the gravel
becomes finer and it was at approximately this
depth that all tests were made.
The test pits were continued down to a maximum depth of 7½ feet. The soil between 4 and 7½ feet consisted of layers of fine and coarse gravel.

Tests were carried out as follows:- one at each of the four corners and two in the centre of the largest and heaviest portion of the building. These tests were made on bearing surfaces of 1 sq. ft. and 2.25 sq. ft at each hole. The log of the various holes is appended herewith as well as sketch showing location of the holes.

A safe bearing load of 4 tons per square foot is indicated by these tests.

However, as the weight of this building is not very great and the footings may be spread to carry a load of two tons per square foot without adding materially to the cost, I would recommend that this latter amount be not exceeded.

WATER SYSTEM

The supply of water on the island on which the Alert Bay school is situated is derived entirely from wells.

The well at the school has been supplying a sufficient quantity of excellent water for a number of years.

A test run of the pump showed a capacity of 10 gals. per minute for 13 hours without diminution of supply.

The system proposed for the new school is to consist of a pumping unit, reservoir and gravity pipe line.
The pumping unit is designed to deliver 20 to 25 gals. per minute and consists of a crude oil engine, belt connected to a deep well pump.

The reservoir, of reinforced concrete, is to have a capacity of 25,000 gals. and the pipe line, of cast iron pipe, a capacity of 480 gals. per minute. The excess capacity of reservoir and pipe line is to provide for fire protection purposes.

Under these conditions two fire streams of maximum capacity and pressure would be available for one hour. The cost of this system, including outside fire hydrants, would be $8320.00.

RAIN WATER SYSTEM

Due to the necessity of pumping water for all purposes a rain water storage system has been provided. This consists of a concrete storage tank of 6000 gals. capacity into which the leads from the roof are to empty. An automatic pumping system, to operate off the electric light plant, is provided to supply the laundry. The cost of this equipment would be $1452.00.

SEWAGE

At the present time sewage is disposed of directly into the sea, not only from the school but also from the village of Alert Bay which stretches along the coast for a distance of two or three miles to the south of the school.

Strong tidal currents prevail close inshore and carry all deposits away. There
appears to be no reason why this method of disposal could not be continued as the provincial Department of Public Health is agreeable to such practice.

However, the sewer system has been designed so that a septic tank may be added at any time without disturbing the present arrangement. The outfall of the sewer into the bay has been protected and it has been removed as far as practicable from the vicinity of the school.

A separate outlet has been provided for the laundry and kitchen, as well as overflow from the rain water tank.

Manholes are provided at suitable locations for the clearing of obstructions.

The cost of the system as designed would be $1508.00; with the addition of a septic tank the cost would be $2960.00.

DRAINS

Drains have been provided for the low area to the rear of the school to prevent seepage into the new building. The cost of this would be $652.00.

FIRE PROTECTION

Sufficient water is to be supplied for fire protection purposes. However, equipment for the proper application of this water is necessary if the fullest measures for fire prevention are to be provided. The equipment suggested is:- for outside, a hydrant cover with doors
at each hydrant and each equipped with 150 feet of hose, nozzle and hose wrench; for inside, two hydrants on each floor of the main building, and one each on the two of the rear wing, equipped with hose hanger, 75 feet of hose and nozzle.

The cost of this equipment, exclusive of installation of water supply pipes within the building, would be $1142.50.

PROVIDING ROAD FROM WHARF

To provide a road from the sawmill wharf to the school, several old, disused buildings would have to be disposed of. These are the property of the Coast Missionary Society, and, I believe, their permission could be readily obtained. The accompanying sketch of the location shows the buildings to be demolished. I believe that no question of compensation would arise. The cost of demolition and the necessary grading would amount to $450.00.

HEATING

Heating is provided in the old school buildings by a furnace and stoves. The cost of wood fuel has become very great and of coal the same may be said. Coal of approximately 10,000 B.T.U. is delivered at the beach for $11.50 per ton. I believe that there would be a saving in operation if fuel oil was used. This, however, would be contingent on the securing of a suitable gravity system capable of burning oil of a gravity of at least 28° Baume.
A suitable location for tanks well above the height of the boilers is immediately to the rear of the boiler room. Shelter could be provided and steam pipes run to the tanks. If, however, pressure tanks are necessary, the motor feed type burner would be preferable as it would burn an oil of a lower gravity and consequently cheaper.

ADDITIONAL WORK TO BE INCLUDED IN SPECIFICATIONS FOR NEW SCHOOL

While there are some details in connection with the construction of the new plant at Alert Bay upon which I have not been asked to report, I should perhaps point out that these details are not included in the specifications for Lytton school. Among these are: the supply of water and light to the new barn to be erected, and the installation of inside pipe lines for fire purposes. I presume, however, that these details will be included in the new specifications and I have accordingly shown them on the attached plan.

The water supply system for the laundry should be provided with a shut off from the main domestic supply and outlets provided for connecting up the automatic pump from the rain water system.
In respect to disposal of the excavated material from the school site, it is suggested that the surface soil for a depth of at most one foot be placed immediately to the front of the new building. The remainder should be disposed of along the foreshore immediately adjoining the playground.

The foregoing is respectfully submitted for your consideration.

Attached hereto are plans of work proposed and additional information on tests carried out respecting stability of ground for school site.

Your obedient servant,

W. C. Warren,
Asst. Hydraulic Engineer.

Sir,

I enclose herewith a report prepared under Mr. Webb, our District Chief Engineer at Vancouver, at the request of Dr. Scott, on the proposed building site and water and sewage systems for the new industrial school at Alert Bay, B.C.

Mr. Webb states that the report has been prepared with considerable haste and that it has not been possible to have it checked in detail without considerably delaying its transmission; he is satisfied, however, that Mr. Warren, who prepared the report, has given the conditions careful and serious consideration.

The estimated cost of the water supply and sewage systems without a septic tank amounts to $14,855. It does not appear under the circumstances that a septic tank is necessary at the present time.

Mr. Webb states that the matter of sewage disposal was fully discussed with Dr. Young, in charge of the provincial Department of Health, and the latter is quite agreeable that the installation should be built without a septic tank, with the understanding that provision be made for installing a tank in the future should it be found necessary. This is provided for in the report and the additional cost of a septic tank is estimated at about $1450.

I shall be glad to have your further instructions with regard to this matter.

Your obedient servant,

J. T. Johnston,
Director.

Sir:-

I am enclosing you voucher No.115 in favor of the B.C.Equipment Company for $22.35 for material supplied to the Alert Bay Residential School.

The Principal reported to me recently that the pump would not work and on investigation it was discovered that it was the engine that was the cause of the difficulty. They had run it without water and when they turned the water on it cracked the head so that it was leaking when it came in.

It was a case that had to be dealt with immediately so I instructed the Principal to wire to the B.C.Equipment Company and get a new head, and that I would recommend it and the Department would pay for it.

Of course it was their carelessness in the first place to allow this head to get broken and really the Missionary Society should be responsible, but where approximately ninety people are to be supplied with water it was absolutely necessary that it should be done immediately and the voucher is enclosed for your consideration.

Replying to your letter of September 13th, I have given very carefully into the matter of fire extinguishers and desks necessary to keep up the equipment for the Alert Bay Residential Schools.

There is a new kind of fire equipment called the "Shar-stop" manufactured by the International Fire Equipment Corporation, West New Brighton, Staten Island, New York, which consists of thin glass shaped somewhat like a pear and contains pink fluid. They contain each probably one pint of fluid and the result with their use is marvellous, particularly where gasoline or oil is the cause of the fire.

An experiment was made in Vancouver harbor with one of these when a gallon of gasoline was thrown into the engine room of a boat and a match thrown in and allowed to get a good hold on it and in less than a half a minute all vestige of a fire was gone. I do not know the prices nor who sells these fire extinguishers, but I think the cost is about $7.00 or $7.50 each. If authority is given I could order them through a wholesale dealer in Vancouver, and I would recommend that five be purchased, two each for the Girls' School and the Boys' School and one for the pump house.

With regard to the other fire extinguishers mentioned, I took up the matter with the principal and I understand that this equipment as suggested would quite fill the requirements.

With regard to desks, the last desks purchased were from the Tait Pipe & Foundry Company, Limited.
and called the "CROWN DESK". After going into the matter thoroughly I would recommend that 2 complete desks for single pupils be purchased, No. 1 size, and one back No. 1. One front, No. 2. One complete desk No. 2, and 3 backs No. 3.

The last purchase was made from the Tait Pipe & Foundry Company in Vancouver, in November, 1927.

With reference to the fire extinguishers, I beg to say that we are placing an order with the Pyrene Mfg. Co. of Canada, Ltd., Toronto, to forward, addressed to you, the following:

This is the type of extinguisher we are now supplying to Indian residential schools, and I enclose for the information of the Principal and yourself copies of the pamphlet showing the characteristics of these extinguishers and the use to which they are to be applied. The 1½ quart size is excellent for use where there is danger of fire from oils, greases and electrical machinery. The pump tank extinguishers should be distributed at strategic points throughout the building.

It is noted that the Principal requested that one only 30' extension ladder be supplied for the Girls' Home. Please state whether you consider that this equipment is necessary, and, if so, where it could be obtained and the cost of same.

Relative to the extra desks required, I beg to say that you may place an order with the Tait Pipe & Foundry Co., Vancouver, for the supplying of the following:

3 No. 1 Single Desks,
1 No. 1 Rear,
1 No. 2 Front,

1 No. 3 Single Desk,

Dear Sir:

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 11th inst. #156-0-5 embodying a statement from the Indian Agent at Alert Bay relative to the difficulty in operating the pump at that School and stating that the difficulty was due to engine trouble, the engine having been run without water, "and when they turned the water on it cracked the head so that it was leaking when it came in".

A copy of your letter was forwarded to the Principal with a request that he should furnish an explanation as to the cause of the difficulty, and I enclose herewith for your information a copy of his reply.

In a further letter from Mr. Anfield, dated Oct.24, he writes with regard to this subject, in part, as follows:-

"With further reference to my letter of the 22nd, dealing with the pumping situation here, I have to advise you that I paid a call on Mr. Halliday, the local Indian Agent, today and had a long talk with him about the whole matter. To sum it up, he took back his statement about the trouble being caused by running the engine without water, but as to whether he will so notify the Department, I do not know. I assured Mr. Halliday that I was most anxious to work with him and he promised me his support and help. In fact he was very nice, and seemed to feel that perhaps he had been at fault in not helping us more. It would be a good thing to forward my letter or a copy of it to the Department, but it might be wise to withhold the last page as I have no desire whatever to make any trouble for the gentleman in question."
From the information set forth above it seems to me to be quite clear that the difficulty with the pump and engine was not due to any carelessness on the part of the School Management, but rather to the fact that the engine which passed through the fire when the pump-house was burned down, was patched up and made to continue in service instead of being replaced by a new one. It had already been in service for five years, but despite the request of the School Management for a new engine at the time, the Indian Agent insisted on having the old one repaired, and it has been giving trouble ever since.

I am returning the bills for your further consideration and trust that you may agree to a prompt settlement of the same.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Dear Sir:-

Ref. yours of the 15th instant dealing with the Dept.'s 156-0-5 of the 11th October, addressed to you, and enclosing an account of $21.80 plus 55¢ freight, on goods ex B.C. Equipment Co., Vancouver. I am compelled to take exception to the statement made by the Indian Agent in forwarding this account to the Department. It might be best at this time to submit a full report on the whole pumping situation.

Immediately after my arrival here it was found necessary to install a new foot-valve in the pump at this school. This was purchased and installed by the order of the Indian Agent, and I purposely refrained from having anything to do with it. I should say, however, that the pump sent up by the Marshall-Wells Co. was equipped with a foot-valve which came attached to the pump itself. Apparently the persons installing this equipment were unaware that this foot-valve was to be disconnected and inserted in the bottom of the pumping cylinder, as the mechanic who made the repairs manufactured a foot valve on the half-ball type, enclosed in a cage also made locally. This was installed and for a while all went well, although the pump never worked at the capacity intended. Then came the fire and the subsequent repairs made to both pump and engine. I should mention that when the fire took place, the top rods of the plunger were burnt to ashes, and the whole plunger fell to the bottom of the barrel, and quite conceivably caused damage to the cage containing the foot-valve. Previous to this I should also mention the trouble we had had with the engine, due to the absence on it of an automatic lubricator. After some delay authority was granted by the Department for the purchase of a Madison-Kipp type of lubricator, but less than a month after installation, the pump house was burned to the ground, necessitating the purchase of a new one after repairs had been made to the engine.

From this time on, we have had serious trouble with the pump, which would stick on the up stroke and jam the engine. This to my mind indicated one of two things, either trouble with the pump itself, or an obstruction in the pipe line. I consulted experts, including the local machinists, Fairbanks-Morse Co. who made the pump, and finally Mr.
C.W. Warren, hydraulic engineer for the Dom. Water Power Branch of the Dept. of the Interior. They were all of the opinion that it was an obstruction of the line, but all stated emphatically that the reduction system on the pipe line caused a lot of needless pressure. I then applied to the Indian Agent for permission and help in taking up the line, and was turned down as far as the help was concerned. So I proceeded with the help of the boys in digging up the line and taking up the pipe, and found nothing. At this stage we were in a serious state, as it was quite impossible to even get the tank half full, and were compelled to keep someone in the pump house while the engine and pump were running. Only a negligible quantity of water was going into the tank, yet the whole system was under terrific pressure, ranging at times as high as 150-200 lb. taken on a gauge. I became convinced that the foot valve was the trouble and that it must somehow or other have become locked, and that the back pressure on the line trying to work against the pump which was working against a near vacuum in the pump cylinder was causing the pressure. I proceeded to the Indian Agent's office and informed him of the situation and also that the schools had been without adequate water supply for some weeks at least, and he authorised the taking out of the whole pump, and himself went down to the mechanic and told him about the job to be done. He also authorised the overhauling of the engine, which due to the terrific pressure on the pump, had had its bearings worn down to the danger point. I should also state that the pressure on the engine had caused it to overheat tremendously in the head and this in my opinion caused the leaking which was apparent prior to the taking down of the engine at all.

The pump was taken out and it was found that the guides holding the cage into place had been either cut or worn off, resulting in the foot valve becoming loose and both cage and foot valve must have been riding up into the barrel of the pump proper. What happened when they came down with the stroke of the pump, I do not know, but I imagine that at times they must have jammed and finally become completely stuck. The old footvalve and cage were removed and are in my possession now, and the bent and twisted condition of the guides is indicative to me that some great weight must have fallen on them, thus bearing out my theory that when the pump fell in during the fire, that the plunger struck the valve with sufficient force either to break off or seriously weaken the guides holding the cage in place, because the trouble started then and has continued ever since.

The engine was removed bodily to the machine shop and thoroughly over-
hauled. Due to a shortage of help and pressure of work, the mechanic could only put one man on the job, and so, on account of the schools having been without water for some days, I worked myself for sixteen hours on the engine without a stop, and we had it installed that night. The engine was set up with the head complete, the water connections made and the water turned on. Then the engine was started but it refused to work, although we used several starters on it. I thought perhaps that it was the gasket at fault and that water was running into the cylinder, and as it was then midnight, I took the boys down to bed, after turning off the water into the cylinder. The next morning, Sunday, I sent for the mechanic who came up and tried for an hour to start it. Then we removed the head and re-set the gasket. In order to seal the gasket, the mechanic started the engine without turning in the water, and it started right off, and as soon as it was running, the water was turned in and the engine stopped, thus proving that there was a leak in the head prior to this action. Mr. Halliday, the Indian Agent, was present when this took place. I think that any engineer will admit that it is not dangerous to start an engine and immediately turn in the water, thus rendering easy the starting of an engine in cold weather. In fact Mr. Halliday informed me himself in his office that he does the same thing with his boat engine. We then borrowed a head from the Sawmill engine and ran with it until the new one, authorised by Mr. Halliday for purchase, after I had been down to see him and taken the old head with me, arrived on the S.S. Louise the following day. The engine now runs well, and the pump works perfectly, and I should inform you that we only have to pump for three or four hours at the most, three times a week, whereas prior to this overhauling, we pumped for as long as fourteen hours a day and got but little for our trouble.

These are the facts of the case, and whilst this report is lengthy, it is necessarily so, as I want both you and the Department to realise why we have been up against the equipment since the fire of a year ago. Mr. Halliday's statement is a grave misstatement of fact, and how he can say that the pump would not work because the engine was giving trouble, I fail to see. Never once, and I have the word of the engineer and the boy who has charge of the engine, has this engine been run without the water being turned in, outside of the one time when it was done by the mechanic in question who was apparently doing it intentionally to find out if it was water that was causing the trouble with starting. In any case this man was working for the Indian Agent who had given authority for the work to be done.
In conclusion I must inform you that I am in receipt of a letter from the Department asking me to place all matters pertaining to the School through the local agent. They are quite right, and I recognise to the full the justice of their request, and I am afraid that I have been rather stern in their flesh of late. However in face of such statements as this, you will realise how difficult it is for me to administer these schools with such help as I receive from Mr. Halliday. I have tried repeatedly to work with him, but when he writes back to me that he will not even pass my suggestions on to the Department for consideration, it is small wonder that I try to approach them in other ways.

When I wrote to him about the truck provided by the Department, he informed me that he would not send in the request to Ottawa for their consideration, and if I had not have taken it up with you, we would not have got the truck, which has paid for itself already in work performed. I have always been willing and am yet to work through Mr. Halliday, and will go the limit to meet the wishes of the Department in this respect, but though I regret to say it, if we only had what Mr. Halliday has got for the school, we would have mighty little. There is a big work to be done here and it has not been developed as it should have been, due to lack of financial help in the past. Now, with the advent of the new and enlarged school, wants have become necessities, and the money involved has been considerable. Let me assure you that I will do my best, though if you feel that I am at fault in the matter of co-operation as far as Mr. Halliday is concerned, I am willing to step aside and let someone else try.

Trusting that this will convey fully the whole situation,

Believe me, most sincerely yours,

[Signature]

Principal.
October 17, 1928.

Dear Mr. Anfield,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 10th instant with which you furnished a sketch of what you consider should be the lay-out of the barn and hog house for the new school at Alert Bay. While it is a little early to consider matters pertaining to the out-buildings, I may say that the sketch which you sent conforms generally with the plans of other such buildings which the Department has erected in the past at other schools. I note you want provision made for twenty cows, but I may say that with the small amount of land which will be available for pasturage and hay-growing at Alert Bay, I can not see how you can possibly take care of a herd of that size. Surely they will supply more than enough milk for the School. Twelve animals, to my mind, would be sufficient. I, however, will send your sketch on to our Architect at Ottawa.

With regard to the temporary school room now in use, I may say that the plans and specifications deal only with the main building and no mention is made about moving this building or the cottage. This work, no doubt, will be attended to by the contractor as an extra, after a price has been submitted through the Inspector of Works who will be in communication with the Department as the work progresses. The most important thing at the present time is to get the main buildings under construction as early as possible.

Your obedient servant,

W.E. Ditchburn,

Dear Mr. Ditchburn:

Whilst realizing that it is hardly my province, I enclose herewith a sketch of what we consider to be the most suitable layout for a barn and hog house for this school, bearing in mind future requirements rather than the immediate present. I leave the matter entirely in your hands, however, realizing your greater experience in these matters.

I have received the plans and specifications for the new school from the Department in Ottawa, and wish to thank you most sincerely for your kindly efforts which has now brought our hopes for a building to fruition. My only hope is that an early start will be made on construction before the really bad weather of the winter sets in.

Mr. Halliday and I had a talk on the proposed site of the barn, and we are both, I think, of the opinion that there will be no detrimental advantages to the pump house and water supply due to its proximity.

Might I have your views on the following:- I notice in the location plan sent with the plans of the building that the temporary schoolroom is shown as moved into its new location. This plan also shows the building as equipped with steam and electric light. Are the contractors to figure in the moving and plumbing of this building in their estimate? Are they also to figure the moving of the cottage which will right on the front steps of the new building? I would appreciate your views on these matters.

With kind regards and best wishes,

Yours very sincerely,

(Sgd.) F. Earl Anfield,
Principal.
Re--Alert Bay School.

Dear Mr.Orr,-

I am attaching hereto for your information a copy of a letter I have received from Rev.Earl Anfield, Principal of the Alert Bay School, with which he submits a sketch of a proposed lay-out of the barn and hog house. A copy of my letter to Mr.Anfield is also attached for your information.

The plan which Mr.Anfield refers to is that gotten up by the engineer of the Dominion Water Power Branch showing the site of the new building, and you will note that it indicates that steam heating and electric light system are to be carried to the temporary class room which will be moved to the rear of the new main building. It may be that this is the engineer's idea, though probably Dr.Scott authorized him to make this provision. You might consult the Deputy Minister on this point.

As regards the size of the barn, it will be noted that Mr.Anfield wants provision made for the housing of twenty cows, which, I feel, are too many, taking into consideration the amount of land there is for growing and hay-growing purposes at Alert Bay. It is all bush with the exception of about twenty-five acres cleared and now in clover.

Your obedient servant,

W.E.Ditchburn,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

2. Sewage disposal. Whilst in town I had a long chat with Mr. Webb, the Chief Engineer of the Water Power Branch of the Dept.; of the Interior, whose Dept. handled the report on the water and sewage systems for the new school here. Mr. Webb assured me that the new plant would be well and safely handled by the outfall system recommended, but that should a situation arise that would demand the installation of the septic tank system, that provision is being made in the plans for such a system to be installed without interference with the building at all. I feel that it would be best to leave this matter as it stands now and abide by the expert advice in possession of the Department.

3. Heating plant. The plant installed in the Lytton school is a 6 and 3 K.W. Lister-Bruston Automatic gas plant. I understood from Mr. Lett that the plant was ample for the requirements of the school there, where the plan provides no power at all outside of lighting. The situation here should be carefully watched as the engineer's report and location plans show that the same plant in addition to lighting the building, is to have lines run to the proposed new barn up the hill, and in addition is to provide power for pumping purposes, both for the main and auxiliary systems. This is a considerable load to put on a plant of this type, and although the Department will doubtless consult expert opinion, we should make it our business to see that adequate power is provided for all the requirements of the new institution.

4. Refrigeration plant. A large ammonia plant is installed in the Lytton building, which is to be used as a main supply refrigerator and also as a kitchen refrigerator. This means that the refrigerator is opened and closed many times during the day and if large pieces of meat are to be stored there safely, the operating costs of keeping this refrigerator going are going to be high. It should also be borne in mind that the door of the refrigerator is only a stone's throw from the kitchen range. When the time comes, it might be wise to suggest that the main refrigerator be placed elsewhere and kept only for storage of meat, and a small type such as the "Frigidaire" be placed right in the kitchen and hooked on to the power plant, for it is apparent that a plant will be needed here capable of providing power for several purposes.

5. Alterations in plans. I enclose sketches of alterations desired. In connection with the kitchen corridor, as far I can see, this corridor is not needed and if taken out would enlarge the kitchen and the staff dining-room, both of which are too small, especially the latter. This would undoubtedly save money as two walls and two doors less would be needed. My purpose in asking for the door at the other end of kitchen to be moved is that it is too near the range which will not fit in if this door is left as at present shown on the plan.
Double doors are required at both ends of corridor on main floor as the children undress for bed in the basements and proceed upstairs in their night attire, and with no doors at either end it is liable to lead to trouble. There should also be a door on the left end of the corridor on the second floor as it means that any boys proceeding to the infirmary would have direct vision into the Girls' dormitories. Little changes like this involving but little money will mean all the difference as far as supervision is concerned.

Just whether or not this is the right time to bring these matters before the Department I leave to you, though I feel that it might be better to hold off until the contract is let and an inspector of works is on the job.

Most sincerely yours,

F. Earl Anfield (Signed)

Dear Sir:-

In connection with the proposed new building to be erected by the Department of Indian Affairs at this centre during the coming winter, I am venturing to bring to your attention certain suggestions that I feel might aid the Department in erecting a building which will enable the Commission to administer it with a minimum of inconvenience, and which will in addition possibly save the Department some money in extras. I should say that I have but recently returned from a visit to Lytton where in conjunction with the Principal, I went over the building recently built there by the Department; a replica of which building is to be erected here. It is a magnificent institution and well worthy of the Department that built it. However, there are certain circumstances at Alert Bay that are totally different from those existing at Lytton, and a few changes might be helpful.

1. Reversal of plans. On his recent visit to Alert Bay, I asked Dr. Scott if it would be possible to have the plan reversed, and he assented. This would necessitate the removal of the Principal's residence to the right of the plan, and the boys' and girls' sides would also change. This will leave the boys and girls on the same side as they are here now in the two separate schools. Such action is absolutely necessary on account of the placement of woodsheds, and the layout of the farm, etc. On talking this matter over with Commissioner Ditchburn in Victoria this past week, he seemed to be of the impression that the reversal would only mean the changing of the residence and then automatically making the right wing into a girls' wing and the left for the boys. It should be clearly understood before work commences that the reversal of the plan must be complete, including the reversal of the laundry and boiler rooms. In fact the plan should be read in its entirety as a left hand plan. If for example the laundry were to be left as at present shown, it would mean an acute disciplinary problem, as the girls would be working on the same side as the boys' wing, and the same would apply to the kitchen, whilst the boys who would be working in the boiler room would then have access to the girls' wing. The upper floors, especially the ground floor would have to change to suit the plumbing arrangements of the basement. This matter should be most carefully watched or we are going to have an appalling time with supervision in the new building.

Dear Sir:-

After long and careful consideration, I have reached the place where I consider it necessary that this school should in the near future be provided with a gas-boat, and I must ask you to give careful consideration to my request that a recommendation in this respect go forward to the Department of Indian Affairs, with a view to an estimate for same being included in the Departmental expenses for next financial year, should the Department give favourable consideration to our request.

Personally speaking, I am much averse to having a boat at this school, as I realize quite well that they are a liability and a worry. But there are features that quite offset these, and I will detail them as follows:-

1. Food supply, fish of different kinds. Although this school has been running for thirty-seven years, as far as I can find out, the school has never put down a winter's supply of fish, certainly not since the Commission took over the schools. For the past two years I have been in possession of a permit to take out up to one thousand fish from the Nimpkish River, but I have been unable to take advantage of this permit on account of lack of boat facilities. At the time when it is best to take these fish the Indians are all fishing on seine boats, and it is impossible to get an Indian to give one any fish, as they are being paid big money for them. The few small gas boats available for charter are expensive, and in most cases are unsafe for crossing over to the Nimpkish in rough weather. As this type of fishing is done in the early morning at a fish trap, it means that we have to go over the river in the dark, and this needs a good boat with a good engine. We have been over three times this year, and took out two hundred fish, which we have salted down for use during the winter. We could have gone over more often, but the only boat I could charter was too small, and the owner would not take it out, (It is a 16 ft. boat) on account of rough weather. With a boat of our own, we could go over to the river and camp there for two or three days at a time, and thus get enough fish to keep the school in food, and thus save on the meat bills which are outrageously high. The children need, and should have fish for food.
Fish is the natural food of the Indian of the coast, and both the Indian and Fisheries Departments go to great lengths to see that the Indian people have ample facilities for getting fish for winter food. Yet here in the schools, in the centre of the fishing district of the whole coast, it is impossible for us to get fish at any price unless we go and get it ourselves. It might be asked why do the Indians not give us fish for their own children. This is answered by the fact that all fish caught are the property of a whole crew, and in any case the prices received for their catch are so high that it does not pay to be generous. Another feature that I am well aware of is the fact that the local Indians are not any too well disposed towards the schools on account of the presence of the northern children. Many years ago, when the locals refused to send their children to school, children from the north were bought down, and have been here ever since, we now having on the rolls children of parents who were in their turn pupils at Alert Bay. This action brought about a feeling that has never quite disappeared. This might also be the reason why they are not keen on taking us over the river to gaff fish out of their (as they put it) fish traps.

Apart from the fall-fish which we would salt down, we could get fresh fish from the same trap from the month of June on, including sockeye and other types. We could also engage in halibut fishing on a small scale when they are running this way in the spring, as we have all the necessary gear here now, but no boat from which to use it. I fished halibut with my small gas boat a year ago, and with great success, but I had to sell the boat as it was unsafe for rough weather being only a sixteen foot boat. In the new school, with a large pupilage, it is almost imperative that we have facilities for securing fish for food purposes.

2. Towing and freighting. As you are aware, the Department are making extensive clearing on the school reserve. This is going to mean a tremendous amount of fencing. In addition, all our other fencing much of which has been up for many years, needs replanning and replacing to suit the new conditions at this centre when the new school is completed and in operation. Fence posts on this coast, to be worth anything at all, must be of cedar. There is no cedar at all on this island, and we are going to have topay Indians to go out and haul in cedar logs for fence posts. This will cost money, as they will charge for the logs as well as the towing. If we had a work boat of our own, the cost would be that of fuel alone. I can assure you that we are going to need hundreds and hundreds of posts when we do start fencing in earnest, as the Department of Animal Health demand that the school land be entirely enclosed, and at present, although the Department authorized it, not even the line fence is in. In addition to this need, a boat could be very useful for hauling freight from the different wharves to the school. Although it is possible that the Department will fix the Sawmill wharf, or make arrangements to have it declared a public wharf and placed under the Public Works Department, there are many boats that bring freight to us that will not call at any wharf but the Cannery, and in summer when we are short handed, it is no light task for a couple of men to have to truck or pack freight for a mile, especially
When the goods might be large and cumbersome such as W.A. bales, a boat would make short work of such a task.

2. Visiting out-stations and villages. We have quite a number of children who live in villages only a few miles from the school, yet during the summer months, when the parents are busy fishing, and all boats are employed either seining or trolling, we have had cases of children who have been weeks late in returning to school solely because there was no way for them to get down. Whilst I grant that the fathers should make arrangements to bring them in on time, yet you know that it is hard to get an Indian to quit fishing just to take their children back to school. At any rate, they don't do it, and if we had a boat, we could run up and pick up all these children in short order. A great deal of work, and valuable work too, could be done in the way of recruiting trips during the winter, when the Indians are in their winter village which in most cases are only accessible to small gas-boats.

The foregoing matters more or less convince me of the necessity of our having a boat, and the remaining factor to consider it what kind of a boat. I would suggest a boat of at least 30 feet in length, and equipped with a heavy duty type of engine. Such a boat could be procured second hand for about $1,000.00. Mr. Halliday, the Indian Agent, is a good judge of boats, and I think that should the Department decide to make a grant, that the purchase could safely be left in the hands of Mr. Halliday, whose knowledge of this coast and the needs of the school, would enable him to select a type that would be both useful and serviceable to the schools.

May I commend this matter to your most careful consideration,

Yours very sincerely,

(sgd) F. Earl Anfield

Indian School Now Being Built

Department of Indian Affairs
Erecting Building at Alert Bay to Accommodate 175 Pupils

The Department of Indian Affairs is erecting a new Indian residential school at Alert Bay.

The structure, on which considerable work has already been done, will be completed early next fall and is intended as a monument to the work of the pioneer missionaries who first brought to the native peoples of the Coast their first real knowledge of the Christian religion and culture. It is furthermore, a witness to the keen interest taken by the people of Canada in the Indian peoples. The building and its equipment will cost in the neighborhood of $60,000.

In view of the acute economic situation among the Coast Indians at present, the Alert Bay school principal and staff, as well as the Indians themselves, are hoping that the Department of Indian Affairs will equip the school with such shops and machinery so that the children may leave with sufficient technical knowledge to be able to earn their living as fishermen with some useful trade or industry.

A high school section is to be provided for in the new building, and when the school is opened for some pupils, it is anticipated, will be ready for classes in this.

The school is modern in every respect. In addition to the five classrooms there are big dormitories, infirmaries for both boys and girls, and spacious playgrounds. The auditorium will seat 300 persons and will be convertible into a gymnasium. One of the classrooms will be used as a chapel. If the school is completed, either by the Diocese of Columbia or the Department of Indian Affairs.

The school is fitted throughout with electric lights and modern machines are being installed in the technical school.

Dear Sir:

The attached letter addressed to me from Mr. Anfield, the principal of Alert Bay Residential School, will in itself be almost self-explanatory. May I, however, be permitted to deal with the matter in the same order in which Mr. Anfield does.

Encs. 4 Ground Floor:

(a) From a practical standpoint of view I consider the request for these doors of great importance, and would, therefore recommend them.

(b) You will readily see the importance of the toilet in question. I may add that the cost would not be excessive, as it is immediately above the C.I. drain in the basement beneath. In this connection, in order to create sufficient room for the toilet, the cupboard shown on the plan in the Indian's room will be done away with, and the partition between the said room and the cupboards will be placed two feet further south, thus slightly reducing the size of the bedroom, but making the cupboard now quite large enough for a toilet. By my explanation you will see that I propose to still run the partition straight across the room. By this it will be seen that the cupboard in the adjoining room will also be made larger. It will, however, leave the Indian's room amply large enough.

(c) The connecting door here asked for is quite in order, judging from the explanation, and is therefore recommended.

(d) Recommended as above.
(e) The request for this item can be readily seen after reading Mr. Anfield's explanation. The cost is not excessive, as he does not ask for any heat, simply an installation of one push switch and two lights. By looking at the plan you will, however, see that the present windows lighting this corridor will, of necessity, have to be placed in the opposite exposure to where they are, in order to still light the passageway. Two extra windows, of course, will be necessary to light the new room, and also one entrance door. Shelving will be placed at intervals of approximately two feet, commencing from the floorline, and carried out to a depth into the room just leaving sufficient space to handle the clothing in question. It will be noticed that the walls of this portion of the building are in any case of stucco construction, therefore easily run up to the necessary height to complete another story.

(f) This request is similar to the preceding one, but the cost would be slightly in excess per cubic foot owing to the fact that approximately fifty feet of radiation will be necessary in addition to the lighting, and that the walls must be of tile and brick construction corresponding with the story beneath. Necessity of it, however, I would consider warranted.

First Floor:
(a) In this request Mr. Anfield's views are recommended.

(b) In connection with this item I have carefully studied the proximity of the nearest staff bedroom, and in recommending it would say that there should not be any additional cost in connection with it.

Second Floor:
(a) Considering Mr. Anfield's explanation here, I would judge that this request be quite in order and it will be seen that the cost in connection with it would be very small.

I trust my explanation may readily grasped, and it is only owing to a temporary shortage of plans on the job that I have not traced all the alterations on a full set of plans and mailed same to you. It so happens that all the sets of plans belonging to the contractor happen at this moment to be in the hands of the separate sub trades, and in consequence not available.
The cost of these alterations carried out in conformity with the rest of the building would be approximately $2,400.00. I have not taken the matter up with Mr. Carson, but I know that this sum is pretty close to what he or any other contractor would ask for carrying out such work.

Dear Mr. Gow:

I have to request that you will give consideration to the following suggestions in connection with the new building, and to report on them with your recommendations to the Department. From the administrative point of view, the additions or changes are wholly desirable, and will render the administering of the new plant very much easier than would otherwise be the case. For ease I will deal with the building floor, by floor.

Ground floor

(a) That double swing doors be placed at each end of this main corridor, and placed next to the stairs leading up from the basement. These doors are most necessary, in view of the fact that the children will undress for bed downstairs, and will proceed upstairs in their night attire. The present layout would mean that boys and girls would both be in full view of each other at this time, and such is not conducive to ease of supervision.

(b) That a toilet be placed in the Indians' room on this floor. As at present laid out, the Indians would have to use the staff toilet or go downstairs into the children's quarters, neither of which conditions are desired at all.

(c) That a connecting door be placed between the office and the class-room. This room will not be used as a classroom here, but will be an office for the Matron in charge, and will also act as a stock room for office supplies, and will further be used as a stenographer's room later on.

(d) That a connecting door be placed between the sewing room and the classroom shown adjacent thereto on the plan. We will not be using this room as a classroom for quite a while, but need it urgently as another sewing room, for the making of clothes, keeping the other as a mending room.

(e) That the roof of the kitchen be built up on one side to the level of this floor, said space to be then used as a storeroom. May I stress most urgently the need of further provision of store room. With our system of bales, and the fact that all our supplies come in large quantities four times a year only, the provided store space is hopelessly inadequate. I
quite realise that the request is rather a large one, as it involves considerable money, and also the question of a window in the staff bedroom lying at the end of the corridor, but I would appreciate your serious consideration to our request, as the space is urgently needed.

(f) That the roof of the coal cellar be raised up one floor also, and that a door be provided to connect the new room thus formed with the auditorium. A little explanation is needed here. No chapel is provided in this building, and the local church will not nearly accommodate the number of children that will be enrolled in this school. This means that we will have to utilize the auditorium as a temporary chapel until the local church is enlarged or other provision made. If our auditorium is used in this way, we will have a temporary and movable altar, prayer desk, lectern, etc., and we must have somewhere to store them when the auditorium is used as a gym, or play room, or concert hall. We would further require a vestry for the presiding clergyman to robe in. This corner room would just suit the situation ideally, as well as providing a store room for auditorium chairs, etc. I wish to press this item most strongly.

First Floor

(a) That a door be placed at the end of the main corridor on the girls' side. This is needed so we are going to have segregation of the sexes, and keep the girls from the infirmary.

(b) That all switches for the night toilets in the entire building be placed in the staff supervisor's rooms, and not in the toilets as shown on the plan. We wish to allow children no access whatever to switches. We would put in 20 volt lamps in these sockets, and let them burn all night.

Second Floor

(a) That a door be placed between the boys and girls wings, allowing the use of this one dormitory for boys. I should say in this connection that we will have more boys in this school than girls, and hence it will be necessary for us to have more dormitory space for the boys. By utilizing one dormitory on the girls' wing on this floor for the boys, and by locking the door into the remainder of the girls section, we could accommodate the 25 boys then I expect to have in excess of girls. In the event of the number of girls increasing in the future, the connecting door could be locked, and the entire wing given back to the girls. In the event of the Department sanctioning this change, the fire escape on this side could be locked, and in case of emergency, the boys would run through the new connecting door and go out on their own fire escape.
Wharfage

I wish you to take a careful survey of the present Sawmill Wharf, with a view to reporting to the Department what I consider to be a most dangerous situation. From my own personal observations and from conversation with those who in a position to speak with authority, I have reached the place where I consider the present wharf and its approaches to be nothing short of a death trap, so much so in fact, that I refuse to allow any children from the schools to be on it at all. There is hardly a pile in the entire structure that is not rotten, and I think that the Department should be notified, and further that the contractor should be warned of the danger. As it is more or less incumbent on the Department to provide the Schools with facilities for the bringing in of the large supplies that will be required to operate the new plant, and as I understand that some arrangement has been arrived at between the Department and the Diocese of Columbia, who are the present owners of the wharf; and in view of the large amount of money that will be required to repair this wharf and the condition of the present road over which supplies have to be hauled from this wharf; I would ask you to give serious consideration to an alternative proposition of extending the wharf recently built by the contractor to a point where it could be utilized as a permanent school wharf, with a suitable freight shed built thereon.

Sunday Work

As this is a Mission school and as we object strongly to the contractor working here on Sunday, I must ask you to obtain a ruling from the Department as to what constitutes necessary work that must be performed on Sunday. The contractor has stated to me that he is compelled to work on Sunday in order to clear his scows, but when a scow is securely lashed to the wharf he is using, I do not consider that the situation is then a state of emergency. We do not wish to be narrow minded on the matter, but we owe a duty to the Indians under our spiritual care. We cannot teach them not to do what we ourselves perform.

Yours very truly,

Sir:

I am enclosing you a copy of a letter which I have just received from Mr. A. M. Gow, regarding an extra in the completion of the new residential school building at Alert Bay.

Occasionally at Alert Bay we have four or five days of excessive rain, sometimes two inches of rain falling in twenty-four hours, and when this occurs the surrounding country becomes saturated.

If you study the contour plan prepared by Mr. Warren, you will notice that immediately behind the new building is a depression, which is marked on his plan to have a drain, and during these periodic rain storms this becomes a small lake.

In doing the excavating for the building, hard-pan was struck, and when this heavy rain came on, the contractor found it necessary to put in a six inch tile drain to carry off the overflow. I make periodic visits to the new building, and I discussed this matter with Mr. Gow about putting in some extra drains, so it would prevent all danger of the basement of the new building ever flooding as has occurred on numerous occasions at the old girl's home.

It is possible that when the drainage system is shown on the contour plan is carried out that there may be no danger of the water from this valley at the back ever going into the basement, but on the other hand it is possible that this surface water may follow a strata in the hard-pan and pass completely under the proposed drainage system and crop out where
it showed during the last heavy rains and as the total expense in putting in the extra drainage will only come to $100.00, I would recommend that it be done, and it will be money well spent.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Halliday,

The contract for building the above new School has been let to one Carson and the Heating Contractor is Carl Beck of this City.

We have been in touch with Mr. Beck, and Mr. Beck has agreed, providing we get your authority, to substitute what is known as the Class S. # 16 "Inglis" SUPREME Boiler. We have asked the John Inglis Co. to not only send you bulletins covering this boiler, but to
visit you in Ottawa and explain to you the merits of this boiler.

We might say that in this matter we are working with the British Columbia Branch of the Taylor Forges Company and have got their consent to this substitution.

Dear Mr. Orr:

Mr. W.E. Ditchburn, Commissioner of Indian Affairs for British Columbia, visited this school on the 18th and 19th instants, and at his request I am writing you with regard to two or three matters pertaining to this building which he thinks, if attention is called to them, you would be desirous of changing in the school at Alert Bay now under construction.

Mr. Ditchburn states that the plans and specifications for the Alert Bay school are practically identical with what were used here, and this being the case, that it would be well to advise you of anything that might be changed to advantage before the newer building is far advanced.

In my letter of the 17th instant I drew attention to the failure of hot water service here when depending on steam from the heating boilers, and pointed out the difference between what was provided for St. Paul's School for instance, and that installed here. Mr. Ditchburn asked me to make the request on his behalf that a hot water storage service similar to what has proved so satisfactory at St. Paul's be authorized for Alert Bay, and that the specifications be changed accordingly. This would call for taking steam from the boiler header through a larger steam line, and for the substituting a "Darling-Whitlock Type K Storage Heater No. H-3" or approved equal, in the place of the one specified at present.

It is desired that in planning the heating of the Principal's residence a separate steam main be taken direct from the boiler room to the residence. The Rev. Principal tells me that during last winter it was found impossible to get sufficient heat in the residence without overheating the rest of the school; and Mrs. Lett remarked that never before did she suffer such discomfort from cold rooms as she has done here. I recall that Canon Middleton also complained of the same condition in his residence at St. Paul's. In the latter case I tried to have a separate steam line carried to the residence during construction, and submitted an estimate from the heating contractor, but it was refused by the Indian Commissioner at Regina. This extra service can be installed much cheaper during construction than afterwards, as you will readily understand.

In this school all doors into corridors on ground and first floors were specified to have glass panels to give borrowed light. This was mentioned in the carpentry specifications, and repeated in the glazing specifications, but owing to an inadvertence in the markings on the plan, the glass panels were not provided, and have been omitted. Mr. Ditchburn would like this corrected in the plans for Alert Bay.

Your obedient servant

Dear Sir:

Mr. Anfield, the Acting Principal of our Society's School at Alert Bay, has expressed to our Commission his very deep concern that the recommendation he made to the Inspector of Works on the new school building, with regard to the provision of proper chapel accommodation, has not been accepted. His recommendation as set forth in his letter to the Inspector of Works on Jan. 19th last, was as follows:

"That the roof of the coal cellar be raised up one floor also, and that a door be provided to connect the new room thus formed with the auditorium. A little explanation is needed here. No chapel is provided in this building, and the local church will not nearly accommodate the number of children that will be enrolled at this school. This means that we will have to utilize the auditorium as a temporary chapel until the local church is enlarged or other provision made. If our auditorium is used in this way, we will have a temporary and movable altar, prayer desk, lectern, etc., and we must have somewhere to store them when the auditorium is used as a gym, or playroom, or concert hall. We would further require a vestry for the presiding clergyman to robe in. This corner room would just suit the situation ideally, as well as providing a store room for auditorium chairs, etc., I wish to press this item most strongly."

Our Commission have very carefully considered this recommendation with the blue print plans before them, and they feel that it deserves re-consideration by your Department. I beg to suggest, therefore, that the attention of your architect be directed to this important matter, and that steps be taken, if at all possible, to incorporate in the new building, the improvement suggested.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary M.S.C.C.

Although this floor is to be of the terrazzo type, I still think it would be most advantageous to have a floor drain put in, as the floor will be washed down daily. Sir:

Replying to the first paragraph of yours of the 6th inst., I have obtained from the contractor the following figures:

1) To tar and asphalt inside of all outside walls except basement ........................................ $343.00
2) To metal lath - ¼" furr all walls as above 1020.00
3) To metal lath ¼" furr E.S. exposures only 450.00
4) To waterproof S & E exposures two coats waterproofing on the outside ......................... 185.00

The contractor is of the same opinion as myself that it is not good practice to tar beneath a white plaster wall, besides when the waterproofing is on the inside it allows whatever water that does get through the tile to remain against the inside of the wall, whereas in choosing the outside method the water is run off and not allowed to be absorbed by the brick, and in any case, Sir, while asking to be permitted to recommend the outside method it certainly is not in my opinion, (having found out a good deal about climatic conditions here) at all necessary to either waterproof or furr out any portion of the building except the south and east exposures of the main building.

When first I suggested that the south-east exposure be furred, I only estimated for fir lath and only for the front wall of main building, now in item number three above it is for metal lath and takes up all the "South" clear round the residence, thus accounting for the difference in price.
I may add that in case the Department sees fit to separate the work and not do as a whole as outlined above in lump sums, that furring and metal lath on inside of outside walls is worked out at $60 per sq. yd., tar and asphalt at $20 per sq. yd., and outside water-proofing at $15, so upon this basis any portion of work that may be deemed necessary can be performed at these rates.

Dear Mr. Gow:

I have to request that you will bring to the Dept.'s attention the advisability of having the manual training shop (at present used as a schoolroom) moved from its present site to the newly prosed site during the coming summer holidays, which commence on June 27th and end on the last day of August.

In view of the possibility of the new building not being ready for occupation when the children return from their vacation, this building could then go on in its present use, without interruption, whereas if the moving were left till later, we would be without a schoolroom for a while, should the new plant not be ready, and if it were ready we would be without a manual training shop. I am sure that the Dept. will see the urgent need of having this building moved from its present site, primarily from the point of view of fire-risk.

In my opinion, it is essential that this building when moved, should be fitted up with radiation and electric light. Steam heat is necessary so that even temperatures may be kept for varnishing and other woodworking operations of this nature.

Would you also please inform the Department that we will require the use of the Principal's cottage, at present in front of the new building, for the use of married staff agents. Hence its removal rather than its demolition is strongly urged.

Believe me, Yours very truly,
