PART IV

DETAILED SPECIFICATIONS

Reservoir

The reservoir shall be of concrete construction reinforced with \(\frac{1}{2}\)-inch and \(5/8\)-inch round steel rods.

It shall be built to the dimensions shown on the plan.

It shall be finished in a workmanlike manner and when completed, the inside walls, floor and ceiling shall be given one coating of cement plaster, the outside walls below ground, a coating of pitch applied hot and the roof a coating of asphalt not less than \(\frac{1}{4}\)-inch in thickness.

PUMP HOUSES

Pump houses shall be of frame construction with concrete floor and curb wall, sumps, sub-engine beds and drains as shown on accompanying plan.

All material entering into the construction of these buildings shall be of No.1 grade.

They shall be built in a substantial manner with diagonal bracing at all corners between studding and securely fastened to foundations as shown on plan.

Galvanized nails shall be used throughout.

All windows are to be equipped with latches and easement adjusters.

Doors shall be of substantial construction and are to be equipped with Yale locks.

The completed structures shall be given two coats of shingle stain on roof and two coats of oil stain on siding and trimming. Sheet metal shall be
given two coats of graphite paint. Where interior is to be lined with sheet metal, lining is to be carried up through ventilator shaft to roof.

**HYDRANT HOUSES**

Hydrant houses shall be of frame construction built in a substantial manner of No.1 grade material and securely fastened to foundations.

Roofing shall be of best quality 3-ply prepared roofing of fire resisting type.

The doors shall be substantially made and hung and shall have fasteners as shown on plan.

Completed houses shall be given two coats of oil stain.

**VALVE BOXES**

Valve boxes shall be of concrete construction built to such dimensions as shown on the plan and finished in a workmanlike manner.

**CONCRETE**

All concrete used in the construction of the above buildings shall be composed of the following ingredients proportioned by volume into what is known as a 1:2:4 mixture:

- Cement: 1 part
- Fine aggregate: 2 parts
- Coarse aggregate: 4 parts
- Water

**CEMENT**

The cement shall be a first-class Portland cement, of standard brand, free from lumps or foreign matter, and until it is used shall be stored in a building which will protect it from the weather.
FINE AGGREGATE

Fine aggregate shall consist of sand, crushed stone or gravel screenings; the particles shall be hard, dense and durable and such that they will pass through a 1/4-inch mesh screen. It shall be clean and free from soft particles, clay, loam and all organic matter; and it shall be so graded that when dry and well-shaken the voids will not exceed thirty per cent.

COARSE AGGREGATE

Coarse aggregate shall consist of crushed stone or gravel having its smallest particles approximately 1/4 inch in diameter and its largest particles approximately 1½ inches in diameter. It shall be graded from the smallest to the largest particles and shall be clean, hard, durable and free from all deleterious matter.

WATER

Water used in mixing concrete shall be free from oil, acid, alkalies or organic matter.

MIXING

A mixer of the type which ensures the uniform proportioning of the materials throughout the mass shall be used for mixing the concrete and the mixing shall continue for at least one minute after all the ingredients are assembled in the mixer.

CONSISTENCY

The materials shall be mixed wet enough to produce a concrete of such consistency that it will flow sluggishly into the forms and about the metal reinforcements and which, at the same time, can be
conveyed from the mixer to the forms without separation of the coarse aggregate from the mortar.

STEEL REINFORCEMENT

All steel reinforcement used shall be of medium hardness, free from excessive rust, scales or coating, and shall conform to the standard specifications for Concrete Reinforcement Bars of the American Society for testing materials.

SPLICING

No splicing of reinforcement bars will be allowed at points receiving stress; and all splices made are to be subject to the approval of the engineer and may be rejected by him at the contractor's expense, should he deem them to be unsatisfactory.

CEMENT PLASTER

Cement plaster used on the inside of the reservoir shall be mixed by weight in the following proportions:

- Portland cement: 1 part.
- Sand: 1 part.

It shall be applied uniformly so as to give a smooth finish and shall in no place be less than 3/32 of an inch in thickness.

STEEL PIPE

All 6" diameter steel pipe called for in these specifications shall be of standard 6" diameter bituminous-coated, burlap-wrapped steel pipe, weighing not less than 14.5 lbs. per lineal foot exclusive of coating and wrapping. All 3" diameter steel pipe called for in these specifications shall be of standard 3" diameter bituminous-coated, burlap-wrapped steel pipe weighing not less than 4.5
lbs. per lineal foot exclusive of coating and wrapping. The pipes may be of random lengths, but their average length when taken over all shall not be less than 13'.

The pipes shall be straight and shall be true circles in cross-section with their inner and outer surfaces concentric.

They shall be smooth, free from dents, scales or lumps or any other defect which may unfit them for the purpose for which they are intended.

No plugging or filling will be allowed.

PIPE JOINTS FOR STEEL PIPE

All pipe joints for steel pipe shall be either standard hub and spigot lead-filled joints, or welded joints, as directed by the engineer, except where flanges are necessary to connect to flanged or screw fittings.

LEAD-FILLED JOINTS IN STEEL PIPE

Lead-filled joints of 6" diameter steel pipe shall contain not less than ½ of a pound of hemp yarn and ¾ pounds of lead.

Lead-filled joints of 3" diameter steel pipe shall contain not less than ¼ of a pound of hemp yarn and 2 pounds of lead.

Joints shall be poured hot and finished in a workmanlike manner and so made that when they are completed they shall be capable of withstanding a pressure of 200 pounds per square inch.

WELDED JOINTS

Each welded joint, if used, shall be made by the oxy-weld process, and shall be what is known as
the butt-welded, chamfered-end type.

They shall be so made as to leave a smooth surface on the inside of the pipe, and shall be subject to the approval of the engineer.

COATING AND WRAPPING OF JOINTS

All joints, either lead-filled or welded, shall, when finished, be coated with hot asphalt and burlap wrapped in such a manner that they shall have the same protection as the remainder of the pipe.

All coating and wrapping shall be subject to the approval of the engineer.

FLANGED JOINTS FOR STEEL PIPE

Where flanged joints are required to connect to flanged fittings, the pipe may be cut, threaded and standard cast-iron flanges fitted thereto.

CAST-IRON PIPE

All cast-iron pipe called for in these specifications shall be made of good quality cast-iron, strong, tough and of even grain, and free from all scabs, lumps, blisters, blow-holes, sand-holes, and "cold-shots", etc.

They shall be connected together where shown on plans by standard cast-iron flanges.

VITRIFIED SEWER PIPE

All sewer pipe supplied by the contractor shall be standard salt-glazed vitrified sewer pipe, free from all blow-holes, scabs, blisters or fire-cracks.

Each section of the pipe shall be of uniform diameter, straight and not less than 24 inches in length, and provided with a hub at one end of
sufficient width to leave a clear space all around between the spigot and the inside of the socket when the pipes are fitted together of not less than 1/2 an inch.

JOINTS FOR SEWER PIPE

All joints for sewer pipe shall be of the standard cement and gasket type and subject to the approval of the engineer.

LAND TILE

All land tile supplied by the contractor shall be standard land tile of size specified, and no section shall be more than 13 inches in length.

Each section shall be straight and of uniform diameter and free from all bad holes, cracks, blisters, etc.

CULVERT PIPE

Culvert pipe shall be 12 inch diameter corrugated pipe of 16 gauge galvanized iron.

GRADE

All pipes shall be laid accurately to the required depth and on the required lines and grades called for in the plans accompanying these specifications and which will be staked out for the contractor by the engineer.

CAST-IRON FITTINGS

All cast-iron fittings called for in these specifications, including all cast-iron tees, elbows, spigots, reducers, reducing tees, flanges, etc., shall be of good standard quality and capable of performing the work for which they are designed.
They shall conform in size to the standard dimensions for such fittings and shall be subject to rejection by the engineer should he deem them unfit for the purpose for which they are required.

**GATE VALVES**

All valves called for in these specifications shall be of good quality, iron-body, bronze-mounted valves equipped with non-rising stems.

Where extension rods are required, these shall be connected in a workmanlike manner, and such connections shall be subject to the approval of the engineer.

**CHECK VALVES**

All valves called for in these specifications shall be of good quality, iron-body, bronze-sealed with bronze faced also, swing check valves.

**INTAKE SCREEN**

Intake screen shall be of cast or wrought iron, not less than 10 inches in diameter, flanged to connect to 10-inch diameter check valve. Screen openings shall be not greater than \( \frac{1}{2} \) inch wide and 2 inches long and shall aggregate not less than 200 square inches in area.

**FLEXIBLE JOINTS**

Flexible joints shall be of cast iron flanged to fit to 8-inch diameter flanged pipe and capable swinging through an angle of 45°.

**MANHOLE FRAMES AND COVERS**

Manhole frames and covers shall be of good quality cast-iron of standard design and shall have a circular aperture as specified.
Covers shall be required to fit snugly into the places for which they are provided and when in place shall present a neat and workmanlike appearance.

HYDRANTS

All hydrants supplied by the contractor shall be of standard design and of such dimensions as are called for in these specifications.

They shall be constructed of good quality iron and bronze fitted throughout.

Each hydrant shall be supplied with a drain valve in the base of the body so arranged that this drain valve shall be open when the hydrant is closed and closed when the hydrant is open.

They shall be connected to pipe line with flanged or leaded joint.

Where leaded joint is made, hydrant clamps must be provided to be securely fastened to second pipe length from hydrant, as shown on plans.

They shall be made suitable for use in a 3-foot trench.

They shall have two outlets 2½ inches in diameter, threaded with City of Vancouver hose thread. Each hydrant shall be fitted with one 2½ inch hydrant gate valve and shall be equipped with outlet caps and hydrant wrenches.

GASKETS

Where copper gaskets are specified they shall be full face, of the required diameter and of 26 gauge sheet copper.
Where lead gaskets are specified they shall be half face, of the required diameter and of 16 gauge sheet lead.

BOLTS FOR CONNECTING FLANGES

All bolts used for connecting flanges shall be of steel of standard dimensions and not more than 1/8" smaller in diameter than the holes in the flanges through which they pass.

They shall be equipped with square heads and hexagon nuts and threaded so as to permit the nut to run the entire length of the thread.

NUTS

Nuts shall be hexagonal in shape and of sufficient thickness to ensure against stripping of threads.

PIPE COVERS

Pipe covers shall be of cast-iron and may be either flat or semi-spherical in shape.

They shall be of sufficient size to properly protect the opening in the pipe for which they are required and shall be so made that when they are in place they do not interfere with the entrance or exit of air into or from the pipe.

An approved method of fixing the pipe covers to the pipe so as to prevent their removal shall be devised and carried out by the contractor.

TRANSMISSION LINE

Transmission line shall be constructed as shown on accompanying plan.

Poles to be buried to a depth of 5 feet.
Brackets shall be securely fastened to poles and wires to insulators. Where necessary guys for poles shall be provided in an approved manner.

Connections are to be made at both pump houses and school lighting circuit.

**WIRING**

All wiring shall be in accordance with standards set by the Inspector of Electrical Energy for the province of British Columbia.

Each pump house shall be provided with one 60-watt light installed with fused cutout switch.

**CEDAR POLES**

Cedar poles shall be 30 feet long, straight and free from rot. They shall be not less than 10 inches at the butt and 6 inches at top. They shall be spaced at not more than 120 feet distance.

**WIRE**

Transmission wire shall be of No.8 gauge double braided weatherproof covered solid copper conductor.

**BRACKETS**

Insulator brackets shall be of first quality oak, not less than 1\(\frac{1}{2}\)" x 2" x 12" in size and suitable for holding No.9 pony insulators.

**OPEN DITCH**

Open ditch shall be constructed to depth and grade shown on accompanying profile.

It shall be not less than 2 feet bed width and have side slopes of 1 in 1.
Material from excavation shall be evenly spread on both sides of the ditch to the satisfaction of the engineer.

MISCELLANEOUS

All other miscellaneous fittings and other items of minor importance necessary to the installation of the above water supply system and not mentioned in detail in these specifications shall be supplied by the contractor and shall be subject to the approval of the engineer.

WORK

EXCAVATION:

All excavation necessary for the proper installation and construction of the above buildings and pipe shall be undertaken by the contractor and the contractor will be required to carry such excavation down to the grade lines or stakes, as set out on the ground by the engineer, notwithstanding any errors or omissions in, or resulting from changes to, the plans accompanying these specifications.

BACKFILLING:

The contractor will be required to perform all backfilling upon all pipe, buildings, fittings, etc., as may be considered necessary by the engineer, but no backfilling shall be carried out during the absence of the engineer or before the engineer has had sufficient time to inspect the work upon which the backfilling is to be placed.

Work covered up without due notice first having been given to the engineer shall be uncovered and re-covered at the contractor's expense.
PIPE LAYING AND TESTING

All pipe shall be laid in straight lines on even grades at a depth of not less than 2½ feet below the surface of the ground when measured from the top of the pipe.

Where additional excavation is necessary to maintain these even grades, this excavation shall be undertaken by the contractor.

Where bends are required and elbows are not used for this purpose, the bends shall be made subject to the approval of the engineer.

All pipe installed by the contractor shall, before backfilling is carried out or before the pipe is covered in any way, be subjected by the contractor to either an hydraulic or air pressure test in the presence of the engineer so as to ensure that all joints are tight and properly made. All leaks found at the time of the test shall be made tight by the contractor.

The pressure which the pipe will be required to carry during this test shall not be less than 200 pounds or more than 250 pounds per square inch.

STEEL REINFORCEMENT

CLEANING

Steel reinforcement before being placed shall be thoroughly cleaned of rust, scale and coatings of any character that will destroy or reduce the bond.

Reinforcement appreciably decreased in section shall be rejected.

BENDING

Reinforcement shall be carefully formed to the dimensions indicated in the plans accompanying these specifications.
The radius of bends shall be 4 or more times the least diameter of the reinforcement bar.

STRAIGHTENING

Metal reinforcement shall not be bent or straightened in a manner that will injure the material. Bars with kinks or sharp bends shall not be used.

PLACING

Steel reinforcement shall be accurately placed and secured against displacement by using annealed iron wire of not less than No.18 gauge, or suitable clips at intersections, and shall be supported by concrete or metal chairs or spacers or by metal hangers.

Parallel bars shall not be placed closer than 1½ times the diameter of round bars.

The reinforcement shall be firmly and accurately placed so that the centre of the bars shall be the exact distance from the inside of the nearest forms as required by the plans accompanying these specifications, and so fixed that no sagging of the reinforcement against or away from the forms while the concrete is being poured can take place.

SPLICING

Splicing of tension reinforcement at points of maximum stress will not be allowed. Splices where required shall provide sufficient lap to transfer the strain between bars by bond and shear.

PART III

DETAILED SPECIFICATIONS

CONCRETE

Concrete used for the foundations of the machinery shall be composed of the following ingredients proportioned by volume into what is known as a 1:2:4 mixture:

- cement: 1 part
- fine aggregate: 2 parts
- coarse aggregate: 4 parts
- water

CEMENT

The cement shall be a first-class Portland cement of standard brand, free from lumps or foreign matter, and until it is used shall be stored in a building which will protect it from the weather.

FINE AGGREGATE

Fine aggregate shall consist of sand, crushed stone or gravel screenings; the particles shall be hard, dense and durable and such that they will pass through a 1/4 inch mesh screen. It shall be clean and free from soft particles, clay, loam and all organic matter; and it shall be so graded that when dry and well-shaken the voids will not exceed thirty percent.

COARSE AGGREGATE

Coarse aggregate shall consist of crushed stone or gravel having its smallest particles approximately 1/4 inch in diameter and its largest particles approximately 1½ inches in diameter. It shall be graded from the smallest to the largest
particles and shall be clean, hard, durable and free from all deleterious matter.

WATER

Water used in mixing concrete shall be free from oil, acid, alkalies or organic matter.

PUMP FOR FIRE PROTECTION SERVICE

The pump to be supplied by the contractor shall be a high grade, cast iron split casing, double suction, centrifugal, pump, bronze fitted throughout.

It shall be equipped with a bronze impeller of the non-overloading type.

It shall be capable of delivering 500 U.S. gallons per minute at the discharge against a head of 200 feet when operating with a suction lift of 10 feet and at its rated speed.

GASOLINE ENGINE

The gasoline engine to be supplied by the contractor shall be of suitable power to operate the above pump at its normal rated speed.

It shall be water cooled and equipped with governor and double ignition.

The engine shall not be of greater horsepower than is required to operate the above pump with good overall efficiency.

The engine shall be direct connected to pump both engine and pump to be mounted on a suitable cast iron bed plate.

DEEP WELL CENTRIFUGAL PUMP

The deep well centrifugal pump to be supplied shall be capable of delivering 30 U.S. gallons per minute against an operating head of
175 feet when driven at its rated speed.

The pump shall be of such dimensions to operate in a 6 inch well coring with a depth of 80 feet. It shall be of such design as to be easily accessible for inspection and be free from lubrication leakage.

CRUDE OIL ENGINE

The oil engine to be supplied shall be of the semi-diesel type of sufficient power to operate the above pump with good overall efficiency. It shall have a cooling system of sufficient capacity so that the engine may operate for a period of 10 hours without excessive temperature rise. Engine shall have a pulley of sufficient size to carry a 6 inch belt, and to operate the pump at its rated speed without increasing the speed of the engine beyond that recommended by the manufacturer.

BELTING

Belt shall be of best quality oak tanned leather belting, free from stuffing or loading.

It shall be at least 6 inches in width.

PRESSURE GAUGES.

All pressure and vacuum gauges shall be of high grade manufacture with 5 inch dial, brass case and cocks. Graduation shall be sufficient to indicate the range of pumping heads of the pumps on which they are installed.
GATE VALVES

All gate valves called for in these specifications shall be good quality, iron-body, bronze-mounted gate valves, flanged or threaded as required, and equipped with non-rising stems.

CHECK VALVES

The check valve to be supplied by the contractor shall be standard iron-body, bronze-mounted, horizontal swing check valve of such design that the check when it is open does not interfere with the passage of the water.

GLOBE VALVES AND COCKS

All globe valves and cocks specified on attached plans shall be high grade bronze valves and cocks and suitable for the use for which they are intended.

RELIEF VALVES

All relief valves called for in these plans and specifications shall be of good quality iron-body, bronze filled relief valve of standard design.

They shall be of such dimensions as to be capable of relieving the pressure in the pipe lines where they are placed and shall be capable of passing the maximum capacity of the several pumps.

They shall be capable of adjustment and shall be free from objectionable features such as dripping and leaking when not performing the work for which they are intended.

CAST-IRON FITTINGS

All cast-iron fittings called for in these specifications, including all cast-iron tees, reduc-
ing tees, elbows, increasers, crosses, flanges, reducing flanges, etc., shall be of good standard quality and capable of performing the work for which they are designed.

They shall conform in size to the standard dimensions for such fittings and shall be subject to rejection by the engineer should he deem them unfit for the purpose for which they are required.

PIPE - MISCELLANEOUS

All other miscellaneous lengths of pipe required in the above installation and including priming pipe, drain pipe, pipe used for connection between valves, fittings, etc., shall be standard cast-iron, wrought-steel or wrought-iron pipe of suitable diameter, as required by the engineer.

EXHAUST PIPES

Exhaust pipes shall be carried through walls of buildings in insulators with at least \( \frac{1}{2} \) inch of air space surrounding pipe. End of exhaust pipe shall be not closer than one foot from building. The crude oil engine exhaust pipe shall have a head with drip pipe to carry condensation to the ground.

SPRINKLER HEADS

Sprinkler heads shall be installed as shown on plans and shall fuse at a temperature of not less than 150° F.

PIPE JOINTS

Flanged joints shall be used where shown on accompanying plans.
GASKETS

Lead gaskets where specified shall be of 16 gauge sheet lead half faced type.

Copper gaskets where specified shall be full faced and of No.26 gauge sheet copper.

BOLTS FOR CONNECTING FLANGES

All bolts used for connecting flanges shall be of steel of standard dimensions and not more than 1/8" smaller in diameter than the holes in the flanges through which they pass.

They shall be equipped with square heads and hexagon nuts and threaded so as to permit the nut to run the entire length of the thread.

NUTS

Nuts shall be hexagonal in shape and of sufficient thickness to ensure against stripping of threads.

REMOVAL AND DISMANTLING OF PUMP

The contractor shall remove the present pump from the well and dismantle the same without damage.

Dear Mr. Orr:

On the 24th January last you wrote me with regard to the possibilities of installing oil burners in the new school at Alert Bay, but I did not feel disposed to write to you until I could get some definite information as to whether there was any likelihood of electric power being available at that place.

For your information I may say it is proposed to establish a large power plant on the Nimpkeesh River, but so far as I can learn this is not liable to take place for a number of years and if current was to be supplied to Alert Bay it would be necessary to run a submarine cable across Johnson Straits about two miles. In view of this I feel it can be taken that any current that would be supplied to Alert Bay would be at a very heavy cost.

The Principal of the School has recently taken up with me the question of installing some sawdust burners at the School, one for the big boiler and a smaller one for the high pressure tank for the laundry, and I am now looking into the matter of cost. The Principal has informed me that he can be assured of a supply of sawdust from Telegraph Bay for the next five years at least and at a very reasonable price. The sawdust burners, I may say are being used somewhat extensively on the coast and are proving very satisfactory not only in residences but also in the larger buildings. There is one installed in the Sayward building, Victoria, and the engineer informed me yesterday this building is heated at a 30% less cost than was the case when they were using slab wood.

I am attaching hereto for your information copy of a letter I received from Mr. Anfield on this particular subject in order that you may have it before you in the event of my making a recommendation at a later date that two sawdust burners should be installed. You will observe, however, that the Principal has stated a 24-inch burner would be sufficient for one of the larger boilers and a 16-inch burner on the boiler for the laundry. I have my doubts as to whether either of these burners would be sufficiently large for our purposes as in the Sayward building, the burner for one of the main boilers, which are about the same size as those at Alert Bay, is a No. 40, 60-inch over all, and on the high pressure tank supplying hot water for this building, it was a 20-inch burner. Therefore, it would appear to me that sawdust burners of practically the same dimensions as those in the Sayward Building would be needed for

Relative to the question of fuel for the heating plant for the new building shortly to be completed at this centre, please be advised that I have made a careful investigation into the possibility of burning sawdust in standard sawdust burners, and beg to submit the following information for your consideration.

A. Suitability. It is pretty generally conceded that where conditions are equable, this type of fuel is from all points of view more economical and more easily handled than any other, excepting oil, which as far as this plant is concerned, is not at present very practicable, due to lack of electrical energy.

B. Storage. We have a coal cellar here of 20' x 20' x 10', or 4000 cu. feet, or 20 units of sawdust. There is also available the coal cellar of the Girls' Home, with a capacity of 5000 sacks, or 120 units of sacked sawdust. Working on a basis of 200 units per year or at the most 300 units, it will be seen that we have sufficient storage space for all our needs.

C. Source of supply. Whilst it is conceded that the sawdust burner is suitable, yet everything depends on a guarantee of supply. This has been very carefully gone into, and the Telegraph Cove Mills, Ltd situated only 48 minutes towing time from the school beach, is prepared to guarantee unconditionally a full supply of sawdust for at least five years. We have at present, on a personal check, sufficient sawdust on hand to last us for three years, and as their investment is sufficiently large to preclude any quick closing up of the business, we are reasonably safe for that time, and the saving on this type of fuel in that span of time will have been sufficient to offset the capital expenditure made for the initial installation of this equipment. This firm proposes to ship the sawdust in large 100 lb. sacks, which worked on a basis of 4000 lb. to the unit, means 40 sacks to the unit.

D. Comparative Heating values. In order to ascertain the comparative heating values of sawdust and coal, our present fuel, I have approached the Forestry Dept. for a report. Remembering that the "unit" of sawdust is derived from the approximate equal content of 1 cd. of wood, they find as follows:

- 1 cord or unit of fir equals 1 ton of coal
- 2.10 = cedar =
- 1.60 = hemlock =
- 1.60 = spruce =
- 1.15 = larch =

The wood in these tests was air dried, with 12% moisture only.

The coal on which the test was based was of 14,000 B.T.U's per ton. We should remember however, that the sawdust to be supplied here would have a considerably greater moisture content than 12%. On the other hand, it must be borne in mind that the coal used here is of only approx. 10,500 B.T.U's, or at the outside 12,000 B.T.U's per ton. The exceptional comparison would therefore remain approximately the same. The Telegraph Cove Mills cut over a year is on an average 50% hemlock, 40% fir, and 10% cedar which would give us a norm of 1.50 units of sawdust to the ton of coal. Taking into account the moisture content of this sawdust, which on account of open air storage would be somewhat heavy, we could reasonably say that we would use 2 units of sawdust to the ton of coal.

E. Cost.....

This price is f.o.b. the mills at Telegraph Cove. Assuming 40 sacks to the unit, this would mean a price of $2.50 a unit. (Victoria and Vancouver prices are $2.25 - $2.50 a unit delivered.) The Mills are prepared to haul our small scow to and from the Mills for $1 a unit, and the scow would hold approx 3 units. On the other hand, if the school had a boat of its own, we could haul ourselves and save 50% of the hauling cost. The scow will be delivered at the school wharf, and we could empty the 120 sacks in about one half hour, enabling the scow to return on the same trip.

F. Objections to Sawdust burners. The primary objection to these burners is of course instability of fuel supply. This, in my opinion is reasonably covered. Another objection which we have given serious consideration is the question of the action of salt water sawdust to the tubes of the boilers. Whilst I have record of certain of these burners being removed for this reason yet we have close to hand the case of the Alert Bay steam boiler, which for fifteen years has burned sawdust in a saturated state direct from the saws. They have not had to replace a tube in the fifteen years of operation. One other objection raised is the question of blow-back through the hoppers. This is danger only met with in certain types of burners, but any burner well guarded with triangular plates in the feed lines should not have any trouble in this connection.

G. Recommendation. In view of the foregoing, I would recommend that serious consideration be given to trying out these burners on the following basis:

1. To install on one only of the two furnaces a 24 inch burner of approved and satisfactory make. I might mention here that the Fuel Mills, Ltd., Vancouver, B.C., have a 24 inch burner, second hand, that they are willing to install for $150.00, subject to satisfaction. Should the burner be not satisfactory, it may be returned and we will only be out the freight.

2. To install on the high pressure steam boiler for the laundry one only 16 inch burner of approved type. This would give us the other furnace and the jacket heater for coal, providing double protection in the event of either not functioning.

Dear Mr. Orr:

Further to my letter of the 5th ultimo having reference to the recommendation of the Principal of the Alert Bay School that a large sawdust burner should be installed on one of the big boilers and a smaller one on the high pressure boiler, I beg to say the Mill Fuels Limited, of Vancouver, have had a representative go to Alert Bay to see what size sawdust burners would be most suitable and he has now reported that a 40" one would be necessary for the big boiler and a 15" one for the high pressure boiler. The cost of these two burners installed at the School would be $950.00.

At first they wanted 20% down and the balance on installation but they were informed that the Department did not purchase on terms of this nature and it would be necessary to give some kind of guarantee as to their proving satisfactory. I have received a further letter stating they are willing to install these burners for the Department and payment to be made after thirty days trial upon the same being found satisfactory, failing which the burners will be removed at the expense of the Company. I am, therefore, of the opinion it might be a good idea to give these sawdust burners a months trial as undoubtedly if they are satisfactory the cost of fuel at the Alert Bay School will be a very great percentage less than would be the case if they had used coal. As stated in my previous letter the Sayward Building, Victoria, has a saving of 30% over the cost of slab wood which is also a very cheap fuel, but with coal the saving should be a much larger percentage. Sir:

Re - Alert Bay Water and Sewer System.

I am enclosing herewith certified account in triplicate rendered by Messrs. Bartholomew, Montgomery & Co. for extra work undertaken in connection with the above. The reasons for this extra work are stated numerically as they appear on the account.

Item No.1.

Owing to the fact that the contractor for the school building placed all the sewer outlets on one side, there was no longer a necessity for the centre farm drain. In consequence the drain at the east side had to be deepened and owing to the nature of the soil, slouching was liable to occur to a serious extent. It was considered advisable to till and backfill an additional length of the ditch as stated in the account.

Item No.2.

It was considered advisable at points where the sewers passed in close proximity to the new building to provide revetment or the trenches owing to their depth in order to obviate any chance of settlement occurring and orders were given to provide the necessary shoring.

Item No.3.

Owing to the limited time that the water system could be shut down if trouble developed in any way, it was decided that a bypass should be available for the employment of the old storage tank and water system. This expenditure was incurred in this connection.

Item No.4.

This was for a valve box not originally intended to be provided with a cover.

Item No.5.

This incurred for the same reason as Item No.1.
Item No.6.

It was found that the sewer of the cottage had its outlet too close to the high tide mark and had become blocked up. As the sewage outlet at that particular point was considered undesirable it was decided to lengthen it and to provide a suitable end to prevent it being buried. This sewer had not originally been provided for.

Item No.7.

This expenditure was suggested to the Department of Indian Affairs as being desirable and was subsequently authorized by them.

Item No.8.

It was found necessary to provide anchorage for the intake pipe of the fire pump. Owing to the backpressure developed by the pump on priming, the joints were damaged. To obviate this and to prevent the possibility of future damage or break in the pipe line, it was thought necessary to provide suitable anchorage for the exposed portion of the pipe line and was authorized on a contract basis of $125.00 for labor plus the cost of material to be provided by the contractor. This outlay also included providing a float indicator for the storage tank.

Item No.9.

A change in the size of the wire was found necessary owing to the added connections placed on the line by the inclination of outbuildings not originally provided for. This expenditure included only the difference in cost of the two sizes of wire. If this work had to be done later, it would mean an outlay of possibly $175.00.

In connection with these extra expenditures it was considered advisable that this work should be done in the best interests of the Department of Indian Affairs and as found necessary by modifications of the original plans of both the school building and of the sewer and water system.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

The Department is now considering the erection of a stock barn for the Alert Bay School and I should like to have some information from you as to just what size herd you propose keeping in order that the Department may know what accommodation should be provided.

Enclosed herewith please find blue print of a barn erected at the Cariboo Indian Residential School at Williams Lake which has thirty cow stalls. The dimensions of this barn are 71'6" by 33'. It will, of course, be unnecessary to build a barn at Alert Bay with as many cow stalls as is the case at Williams Lake in view of the fact it would be absolutely impossible for you to feed a herd of thirty cows and a bull owing to the fact there is very little feed on the land which has been cleared. At Williams Lake, however, the Roman Catholic Church have thousands of acres from which feed can be obtained. Generally I would think that provision for twelve cows with calf and bull pens would be all that would be required at your School, but before writing to the Department I thought I would like to hear from you on the subject.

Kindly let me have your reply by return mail as I wish to report on this and other matters in connection with the Alert Bay School at as early date as possible.

Yours respectfully,

Sir-

Would you kindly advise me what is intended to be done with the surplus material in the old school buildings. The Missionary Society of the Church in Canada have an idea they have some claim on it, but on the other hand, a great deal of the material was purchased directly by the Department. There are two kitchen ranges, one in each building, and unless something is done with them, they will very quickly deteriorate.

I should also like to be advised what is intended to be done with the old Boys' School, whether it should be sold for the material that is in it, or whether it should simply be destroyed and burned. I do not think that any great sum could be obtained from it, as when a building is torn down and the lumber taken, it is usually so full of nails and other blemishes as to be not worth very much, in fact hardly worth the tearing down.

Has any decision been arrived at yet regarding the old Girls' Home? There has been a good deal of discussion regarding this building, and personally I am of the opinion that if the Department intend establishing a tubercular sanitarium for the Indians, that this would make a good central station for it, being used as an administrative building, while the patients themselves could be put in small huts outside. As you are aware, there have been many recommendations made on this matter, and some of the most eminent specialists on tuberculosis have made extensive researches regarding this disease. If this place was set aside for incipient cases, more particularly for children, and a competent staff appointed to look after it, the children could be educated, as there are classrooms in this building itself, and I think there would be very little danger on account of its close proximity to the new building.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

In a letter just received from Mr. Anfield, Principal of the Alert Bay School, he directs my attention to the urgent need of a steel safe wherein may be deposited for safe keeping valuable documents belonging to himself and the School, as well as those of various staff agents. The need of this item of equipment is so obvious that I do not think it necessary to add anything further in this connection. It will be a great help to the School management and also to our Commission if your Department will either provide the same or authorize our Commission to do so. For some time I have felt that our Indian Residential School buildings should be provided with a vault wherein valuable account books, important letters and other such like things could be securely placed. On different occasions I have suggested to your Department that a vault should be placed in every new School constructed, but for some reason or other the suggestion has not been acted upon. Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 30th ultimo in which you inform me that the Church authorities have requested the Department to arrange for the following outbuildings at the Alert Bay Indian Residential School: stock barn, root house, hen house, hog pen, implement shed, wood shed and dairy.

In reply I beg to say that I consider it is necessary that a new barn, implement shed, wood shed and dairy should be constructed at this School as all the present outbuildings are very old and have outlived their usefulness.

So far as the barn is concerned, I may say I am of the opinion that a structure similar to that put up at the Cariboo Indian School, shown on plan No. 563, would suit the purpose except that possibly its length could be cut down approximately seven feet as the number of cows which will be housed will not be over sixteen. I am attaching hereto a pencil sketch of a layout as proposed by Principal Anfield, but he has not reduced the length, also blueprint No. 563 of the barn for the Residential School at Williams Lake. If, however, eight stalls for cows on each side of the barn are provided for, this could be quite easily done and would, no doubt, materially reduce the cost of the structure from what it would be if it were built of the same dimension as that at the Cariboo School, which is 32' wide by 71'6" in length, particularly as the principal would like to have the cement walls run up 4½" above the flooring. The Principal would also like to have all floors and mangers of cement; but I do not think this would be a good thing to do as the cement floor in the cow stalls would be too hard on the feet of the cattle and in the long run we might have to cover these over with boarding afterwards. Cement litter alleys and gutters should be sufficient so far as the floor is concerned.

It is proposed to have the dairy form part of the building with the root cellar under the dairy, and I think this is a good idea instead of having to put up separate buildings.

I am of the opinion there should be a small building erected to be utilized as a cooling plant, the same as we have at Lytton and Sechelt. This building could be of

Mitchell, of Vancouver, installed the plants at Sechelt and Lytton and would be ready to undertake the installation of the one at Alert Bay. The building could be erected by the contractor and the compressor and engine installed by Mr. Mitchell.

You mention in your letter the removal of the old workshop at the Boys' School to the manual training building and attached thereto for a blacksmith shop. This I approve of.

So far as the barn is concerned, I am of the opinion it should be done by contract and a separate figure be obtained from the contractor for the removal of the old workshop at the Boys' School to the manual training buildings.

It is essential that an implement shed and wood shed should be erected and this work should also be done by the contractor after it is known just what is required.

So far as the hen house and hog pen are concerned, Principal Anfield has agreed to put these up if supplied with the material, but I am of the opinion that there ought to be sufficient lumber from the old wood shed and school when torn down which could be utilized for this purpose. I do not see it will be necessary to have any concrete work in either the hog pen or the hen house.

I would also recommend that the Principal be supplied with sufficient cedar poles for a bull corral as he has agreed to erect this if supplied with the material.

The tearing down of the old school and the wood shed could be done by day labor, preferably by some of the local Indians under the supervision of Mr. Indian Agent Halliday who should see that the old material is stacked up as it will be of some use to the school for fuel purposes at least after what has been taken for the chicken house and hog pens. Dear Mr. Ditchburn:

We have to acknowledge with pleasure your 15/6/16520 of the 16th instant, conveying the information that the Department is contemplating the early construction of a stock barn for this School. The enclosed blue print has been carefully studied in conjunction with your request, and we have the honour to place before you the following suggestions:

(1) Size of herd.

This in our opinion should take into consideration our capacity for providing feed, and also and very important the capacity of the school, which we might say will average less than 175. It is, we know, the earnest desire of the Department that their Indian children receive as much milk as possible, and we must expect to have to provide hay and feed for some two years or more yet. May we amend your suggested number of 12 to a total stall capacity of 16.

(2) Additional needs to stalls:

We would suggest that the plan include a bull pen, calf pen, and calving pen for cows. A sketch is enclosed which we pass on to convey our ideas to you. Instead of the large amount of space allocated to cow stalls we would suggest accommodation for one team of horses with harness room, one dairy with concrete cooling pit, and beneath this a root cellar with a capacity of at least 25 tons of roots and vegetables.

(3) Weather conditions:

In view of the vast amount of rainfall at Alert Bay, we place before you for consideration:
(a) The need of a concrete manure pit.
(b) The essential need of careful tile drainage around this barn.
(c) That the walls of the weather side be waterproofed as much as possible (we draw to your attention the fact that the weather side walls of the residence of the new school are always damp).
(d) That the concrete walls of this barn be built up to 4 feet 6 inches from the floor.
(e) That all floors and mangers be of concrete rather than plank. We would estimate that the weather here especially in winter would render plank floors a poor investment.

(4) Ventilation Shafts.

We have only one man on the farm here and......
and the boys will necessarily have a lot of work in the barn, and in view of the fire risk, would recommend metal vents rather than wood.

(5) Water:

Provision is made for connections for the barn on the present pipe line from the well, by closing off certain valves on the pump, a constant pressure can be maintained from the storage tank.

(6) Equipment:

We would be most grateful for your favourable consideration to the installation of the barn complete with either Beatty (BT) or Louden Barn equipment, with a preference for the former as we really believe that in the long run such equipment is cheaper than wooden materials. It is important in our opinion, that the steel stanchions be of the swivel type and that the manger partition be movable for cleaning purposes.

(7) Bull Corral:

Would the Department consider a cedar post corral. There is no cedar on this island and we can ill afford to buy.

(8) Electric Light:

Provision is made on the present power line for a hook up to barn. We suggest that the necessary lights be installed.

(9) Colour:

We place before you the suggestion that the roof be painted green, the walls light grey with green trimmings.

(10) Chicken House (a), Hog pen (b), Implement shed (c).

Our Commission are anxious that these subsidiary buildings be erected as soon as convenient to the Department. We are anxious to aid in every possible way and would be pleased to recommend to our Commission that should the Department care to include in this contract the plans and materials for (a) and (b), that we would undertake the construction ourselves. In the case of (b) we would suggest that if the contract included the concrete work necessary, and the materials were provided, we would build this also apart from the concrete.

All of which is respectfully submitted and thanking you for this opportunity of placing our views before the Department.

Believe me, very truly yours,

(Sgd.) F. Earl Anfield.

Principal.

Memorandum:

Mr. Commissioner Ditchburn has replied to the Department's request for a recommendation concerning outbuildings and related matters at the Alert Bay Indian Residential School. He recommends the erection of a barn with dairy and root house combined, at an early date; and, as funds will be available, I wish to recommend that the work be proceeded with. Mr. Orr states that it could be done by contract or day labour. Mr. Ditchburn recommends a contract, but Mr. Orr believes it might be done at less cost if on a day labour basis.

Whoever builds the cow barn should be responsible for the repairs to the wharf, which have already been authorized, and also for the removal of the old work shop at the old Boys' School to the manual training building on the new site.

Mr. Ditchburn recommends an implement shed and wood shed and a hen house, hog pen and cold storage; but, as there are no funds available for these purposes, their provision will have to wait, unless the school authorities can arrange to erect some of the outbuildings without cost to the Department. They could use the materials in the old boys' building.

Mr. Ditchburn recommends the early demolition of the old boys' building and the levelling of the ground. Funds for this also are available. You will remember that there is included in the Main Estimates an item of $10,000 for these purposes.

Sir:-

I am enclosing a copy of a letter just received from the Principal of the Alert Bay Indian Residential School regarding additional fire equipment.

In connection with this, I may say that it is not good policy to take any unnecessary risks for want of extra equipment, and the department officials through long experience, know what equipment has been provided for other schools, and what equipment is necessary, but in my estimation this building is well equipped so far as fire fighting is concerned. However, I leave the matter for your consideration.

Your obedient servant,

(W.M. Halliday)
Indian Agent

WMH/SMT

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.
March 8th, 1930.

W.M. Halliday, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Alert Bay, B.C.

Dear Mr. Halliday:

The recent disastrous fire at the R.C. School at Cross Lake, Manitoba, with a most regrettable loss of precious lives, has once more prompted us to take stock of our fire preventive measures, and also of our fire fighting equipment. Steps are being taken to improve fire drills, and we have to inform you that at the last drill the school was cleared from the dormitories via the fire escapes, in just over two minutes.

We wish however to draw to the attention of the Department that we really consider the provision of two extension fire ladders on wheel trucks an absolute necessity, both for life saving and fire fighting. This is a large and high building, and in the event of a conflagration at the rear of the building, there is no way of getting children out from the top floors. Would you please give this matter your earnest consideration, and advise your Department accordingly.

Yours very truly,

(S'gd)"F. Earl Anfield"
Principal.
Government of British Columbia

Memorandum to Mr. Webb:

RE - Alert Bay School,
Water and Sewer System

Work was commenced on the above project on the 22nd of August and completed early in November.

Some few alterations were made and some additional work required as outlined in my memorandum of December 2nd, 1929.

The total cost of the work was $18,095.20 including all extras, fire equipment and supervision. The equipment supplied by the contractors, Messrs. Bartholomew and Montgomery Co., was procured through Messrs. Pumps and Powers, Ltd., as manufacturers' agents. Types and manufacturers' names are given below.

Fire Pumping Equipment.

Pump. Worthington Pump Co. Type 4L5.
6-inch suction and 4-inch discharge which has been enlarged to 8-inch suction and 6-inch discharge.

Engine. The pump is direct connected to a 60 H.P. 6-cylinder 4-cycle continental engine, with a governed speed of 1800 R.F.M. This engine is provided with dual ignition consisting of magneto and battery type. This pumping unit is capable of a considerable increase in output over its specification rating of 500 g.p.m.

Domestic Pumping Plant.

This plant, also supplied through Messrs. Pumps & Powers, Ltd., consists of Petters 5 H.P. crude oil engine (Mfrs. agents B.C. Equipment Co.) belt connected to a Pomona deep well pump.

The installed length of pump and casing is 65 feet, the depth of the well being 76 feet and depth to water 55 feet.

The pump is a 15 stage type fitting into a 6 inch casing. A full description is given in Messrs. Pumps & Powers quotation, dated March 22, 1929.
Tests run of the pump showed a capacity of 45 g.p.m. into the reservoir but the engine at this output was apparently overloaded and the pump capacity was reduced to 30 g.p.m., the output for which the plant was designed.

When it was originally decided upon adopting this type of pump no information was available as to the capacity of the well, nor was there means at hand for testing this, the greatest output possible with the old pump being 12 g.p.m. The object in view was the development of the well to its full capacity so as to obviate the necessity of long hours of pumping. When it becomes necessary to renew or overhaul the present Petters engine I would suggest that an 8 h.p. size be installed in its place. This will allow an increased output to 60 or possibly 65 g.p.m., which is more desirable for the school where so much water is used.

Alterations have been made in the working drawings corresponding to the changes noted in my memorandum previously referred to herein.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of April 15th, 1930, #15-6-17399 and also your letter of more recent date, I deeply regret that I have been for the last few weeks quite ill, and unable to attend to this matter at an earlier date.

I now have pleasure, however, in submitting my report together with a letter given me by Principal Anfield at the residential school at Alert Bay, of May 5th. This letter I am glad to say will show that with the exception of the remarks which I have to make regarding the seepage and the raising of the chimneys that Mr. Anfield appears to be from the enclosed letter perfectly satisfied with all else in connection with the building.

I now beg to submit my report. Upon arriving at Alert Bay, I first got in touch with your Indian Agent, Mr. Halliday. He seemed to be perfectly satisfied that I should simply act upon the former list of complaints submitted to you by the Principal, of which at the time he also sent me a copy, with the result that I went up to the school and for two or three days made a thorough investigation of everything even before going up I was convinced that it was not the roof which was leaking, and upon investigation was further convinced that this was the case. I know of two or three places in town here which have given exactly the same trouble, and it is simply a matter of heavy drifting rains penetrating the brick and getting into the plaster. The methods used here have always been to thoroughly waterproof sections of the outside, and I feel sure that if this is done on certain portions of the school at Alert Bay, that the question of dampness will be eliminated. I need scarcely go into the matter of which portions of the building this need be applied to, but would say that the extent needing such a thorough waterproofing is not one half of the entire exterior of brick work. The front of the building, as you are probably aware was done under instructions at my request. Mr. Halliday however appears to be fully conversant with the portions needing such treatment and has even got prices of certain waterproofing material. I imagine I need not go any further into this matter. It is not that the job of necessity would be very expensive, except for the fact that at Alert Bay there would be no one capable of carrying it out. It would therefore mean that men and equipment must of necessity go from Vancouver. This matter I took up with the Principal and his wish in the matter was that the work in any case be not carried out until July, when the summer holidays started, and of course we were both agreed that if the proposed barn was going to be built, that the question concerning the waterproofing with the contractor on the job would be materially lessened.

The only other matter as seen by the principal's letter was the matter of the raising of the chimneys. These chimneys are constructed according to specification (or at least within a few inches of such) but I am fully convinced that to get...
got the best results from the large chimney carrying the two main boilers, that it should be raised to a height of twenty feet in excess of what it is at present. The chimney from the kitchen and laundry would not of necessity need to be raised more than another four or five feet to obtain good results I think. The only remaining one then, is that on the residence, which undoubtedly should be carried up to a height two or three feet in excess of the main building, or I am afraid no matter how they cap it, with certain winds it would be liable to give trouble.

I am deeply sorry that this report has not been submitted at an earlier date, but it was absolutely unavoidable.

Referring again to your letter of May 27th, 15-6-17821 and referring to the last paragraph re account for services rendered, I herewith enclose accounts in triplicate as requested and would ask that owing to having been laid up for such a length of time, that if possible the account be forwarded to me from Victoria instead of Ottawa.

Yours truly,

(Sgd.) A.M. Gow
Inspector of Works.

Dear Sir:

I have received various letters from the Principal of our Alert Bay School advising me of the damage sustained by the new School building through the heavy rains which obtain in that part. From this information it is obvious that prompt and vigorous action is necessary to make it possible for the School management to carry on their work. The Principal has reported different staff agents who are suffering from minor ailments and it is possible that these have been either brought on or aggravated by the damp condition of the building. Sir:

Several reports have been forwarded you regarding leaks in the new Residential School. During the past winter we have had several extremely heavy rains with wind, and the walls all through on the south-east end of the building were saturated; in fact one night it ran over the floor. The building, as you are aware, is a brick and tile structure, with only one thickness of brick on the outside walls, and it is quite apparent that the moisture comes through the walls themselves. I have taken this matter up with a view of finding a remedy for it, and I wrote to Marshall-Wells B.C. Ltd to see if they had any paint that could be used.

In reply they sent me a small pamphlet on a water-proof cement which is called "Bondex" and which comes in sixteen different colors. It seems to be made of Portland Cement with other materials in it. In their pamphlet they say it can either be put on with a large kalsomine brush or can be sprayed on, and will only adhere to such substances as brick and concrete. If it is sprayed onto wood it will wash off. The cost would not be very great. It sells at $19.00 a hundred pounds, and will cover approximately 25 square feet per pound with one coat. It is usually mixed seven pounds to a gallon of water. They add that "Bondex is a dry powder type of paint made on a basis of white Portland Cement and for this reason only tends to harden in rain, and will wear like iron under any and all weather conditions."

I would recommend that this matter receive consideration of the architect or those in charge of the buildings, as it would appear from the reports that I have received from it that it would be a splendid thing to use on the building, and would not cost a very great deal. Of course I am aware that nothing can be done
during the present fiscal year which is now almost expired, but it might be done before the next fall rains start in. Owing to the fact that it is a compound of cement, it should be put on in rather damp weather, or the walls damped before being applied, so that it will adhere to the brick work.

Your obedient servant,

(W.M. Halliday)

Sir:

I am enclosing a copy of a letter which I have just received from the Principal of the Indian Residential School at Alert Bay. With regard to the last paragraph of his letter, in which he states that wide cracks are showing in the corners of the rooms, suggesting to him that subsidence is taking place in the two heavier wings of the building, I have to advise you that I went into this matter very carefully and there is no appearance of any subsidence, but there is an appearance that the walls have not been properly tied to the floor joists, and that there is a certain amount of shrinkage, leaving a crack on both walls of about one-quarter of an inch. This, however, could be very easily repaired.

The roof and walls of the Principal's residence are leaking badly, and on the time of my inspection, on the 4th instant, the wall in one of the bedrooms was saturated, and he advised me at the same time that on the sleeping porch of the residence, the water poured through freely with the heavy rains.

To my mind, the most serious defect in the construction has been entirely overlooked by the Principal, although we discussed it on the 4th instant. There are two chimneys or flues in the back part of the building. One takes away the smoke from the heating furnaces and the steam boiler, while the other takes away the smoke from the kitchen and bakery. Both these chimneys are altogether too low, and should be raised at least fifteen feet higher. The winds are very variable here, and when it blows in certain directions, it strikes from the main building, and blows down the chimney, filling the whole place with smoke. I understand they had the same trouble with the Lytton school, and that they raised the chimney three or four times, but I would recommend that this be brick to a height of not less than three feet higher than the top of the main building, to absolutely protect it from the squalls which strike the building and blow the smoke down.

Your obedient servant,

(W.M; Halliday)

Dear Mr. Halliday:

We have to advise you that after a careful inspection of the school and a study of the specifications pertaining to the construction, we find that the following items have been either omitted by the contractor or are in need of attention from him:

(1) Specifications call for 2 coats whitewash for boiler room. This has not been done.

(2) Liquid door checks are specified for all outside doors with exception of residence. None are installed and they are badly needed.

(3) No storm windows have been supplied. Whilst it is possible that they are not needed for all windows, we recommend that they be installed on all windows on south and southeast walls.

(4) Section 13 calls for a drainage plan to be supplied. We would appreciate a copy of this for use in locating drains, sewers, etc.

(5) Specifications call for new slip safety treads on all outside steps. None are installed.

(6) Section 25 not carried out at all, as no steel plates have been put on any doors in school.

(7) No screen doors have been supplied (Section 37).

(8) There are no ventilating registers in bathrooms or kitchens.

(9) No fastenings or catches installed on windows in kitchen corridor.

(10) Several cupboards without necessary fittings.

(11) One large pane muranese glass broken by carpenters not replaced.

Dear Sir:

During my recent visit to Alert Bay, I went carefully over the new Indian Residential School building provided by your Department on behalf of our Society, and also over the land attached thereto, which is in process of being cleared, and made a list of certain requirements which I now beg to submit for your early and favourable consideration. These are, in part, as follows:

1. Furniture for the Principal's residence. (The only room in this part of the building which may be said to be fully furnished is what is known as the guest room).

2. A dairy with full dairy room equipment, including cream separator, churn, etc.

3. Mechanical dough mixer with a capacity of one barrel of flour. (The school management will make the kneading trough, if the materials are supplied).

4. Enlargement of the storage space for the coal required for the kitchen ranges. (The freight on coal is much cheaper if delivered in large quantities, and the coal bin provided can be extended without great additional cost).

5. Storm windows for the front and South-east walls of the main school building.

6. Rug for the staff sitting room. (Size of room, 14' x 16').

7. Chesterfield suite for the staff sitting room.
Linoleum rugs for the visitors room. (Size of room 11' x 14').

To complete the ceiling of the boiler room with metallic sheets. (This will add to the appearance as well as to the safety of this part of the building. At present only the space above the boilers is covered in this way).

10. To exchange the 33 vertical tubular boiler for one with a capacity of 10, as the smaller one cannot possibly meet the needs of so large a School.

11. To cover the main lead pipe in the store room, and all uncovered pipes with asbestos lagging. (At the time of my visit the lead pipe in the store room was sweating badly, and injuring the supplies).

12. To provide a steam mangle for the laundry and a suitable stove for heating the smoothing irons. (The stove provided is altogether too small, the top having a diameter of about 18" only).

13. To put a V-joint ceiling in the work shop, 20' x 40', and to install 4 radiators of the long wall type in this building for heating purposes.

14. To make a roadway from the School to the Cannery wharf to facilitate the transportation of supplies. (The Deputy Supt. General received an estimate of the cost of this, I was informed, at the time of his visit last year).

15. To raise above high water mark, and to extend further out from the shore, the temporary wharf built by the contractor in front of the School. Pender logs should also be provided.

16. To make a path from the School to the salt water fire defence engine house. (This is very necessary, as this house is approximately 300 yds. from the School, and if it is to be reached quickly, a good path should be provided.

17. To build a stock barn, root house, implement shed (100' x 30') poultry house and piggery. These buildings are very urgent, especially the stock barn, as the provincial authorities have informed the Principal that they cannot place the School herd on the pure-bred stock list until a suitable building for the herd's accommodation has been provided. In the Deputy Superintendent General's letter of March 30, 1927, 160-2, he expressed the hope that the contract for the new School would be let as a unit, and that there would be no interruption in the activity.

18. To build a wood wheel or provide the materials for the same.

19. To provide a 1½ ton refrigerator plant, the same to be housed in a separate concrete building.

20. To provide fencing material, milk cows (Red Foles desired) pigs and poultry.
To provide 12 dozen Yale locks, 300 lbs. red clover seed, and 100 lbs. lawn grass seed.

22. To provide a motor truck for hauling supplies from the wharf to the School, also a motor boat.

In addition to the above, all of which, I think you will agree, are very necessary, and for the most part urgent, I beg to request that the services of a man be provided by the Department for one year, to assist in getting the School grounds, especially around the main School building, levelled up, in building fences, making roads, planting trees, etc. The salary expected would be about $50.00 a month, and if your Department will agree to this for one year, our Commission will undertake to find the man and to give him his board and accommodation. The condition of the grounds at present make it practically impossible for the School management to keep the School clean, especially in wet weather, and that is the kind which usually prevails in that part. Moreover, there are certain old buildings to be removed, and play ground space provided for the children. The services of the man requested will be a great help to the School management, and I shall be obliged if you will let me know at the earliest date possible, if your Department will agree to his appointment.

There are a number of other requirements which I wish to submit to your Department, but I am awaiting certain measurements and further information with regard to kinds and quantities, which the Principal undertook to send me. When these have come to hand I will write to you again.

The question of the disposal of the buildings which constituted the old schools is one which should receive your immediate attention, especially the disposal of the Boys' Industrial School building. This stands at present on ground which should be incorporated in the recreation space for the boy pupils, and unless it is removed, the work of laying out the School grounds will be delayed.

With regard to the building which was used as a class room and work shop at the Boys' Industrial School, before the new frame class room was erected, and which is now used for manual training, I beg to suggest this building be placed at the end of the building which is used for manual training and carpentry work, and equipped for giving manual training in iron work. The two buildings might be connected with a closed passage, and heated from a central heating plant.

I commend the above matters to your earliest and most sympathetic consideration, and have the honour to remain, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

DOMESTIC PUMPING PLANT

This plant, also supplied through Messrs. Pumps and Powers, Ltd., consists of Petters 5 H.P. crude oil engine (Manufacturers' agents B.C. Equipment Co.) belt connected to a Pomona deep well pump.

The installed length of pump and casing is 65 feet, the depth of the well being 76 feet and depth of water 55 feet.

The pump is a 15 stage type fitting into a 6-inch casing. A full description is given in Messrs. Pumps and Powers quotation, dated March 22, 1929.

Tests run of the pump showed a capacity of 45 g.p.m. into the reservoir but the engine at this output was apparently overloaded and the pump capacity was reduced to 30 g.p.m., the output for which the plant was designed.

When it was originally decided upon adopting this type of pump no information was available as to the capacity of the well, nor was there means at hand for testing this, the greatest output possible with the old pump being 12 g.p.m. The object in view was the development of the well to its full capacity so as to obviate the necessity of long hours of pumping. When it becomes necessary to renew or overhaul the present Petters engine I would suggest that an 8 h.p. size be installed in its place. This will allow an increased output to 60 or possibly 65 g.p.m., which is more desirable for the school where so much water is used.

Alterations have been made in the working
drawings corresponding to the changes noted in my memorandum previously referred to herein.

W. C. Warren,

Dear Sir:

On the 20th instant, I visited the Alert Bay School and was pleased to learn from Mr. Indian Agent Halliday and Mr. Principal Anfield that steps were being taken by your Department to build a stock barn for this institution. I carefully examined the plan of the barn which you have authorized, and although I am of the opinion that it will not provide sufficient accommodation to meet the needs of a school with so large an enrolment, I fear it is now too late to alter it, as your representative informed me that he had ordered the material, and this was ready for delivery, for a building of the dimension authorized, namely 35 x 65' 8".

As I learned from your representative and from the Principal, that a competent man was not available locally to supervise the work of construction, I beg to submit the following suggestions for your immediate and sympathetic consideration:

1. That Beatty Bros. Ltd., 1100 Hamilton St., Vancouver, B.C., be asked to send one of their men to take charge of the erection of this building. In this connection I may state that Mr. Indian Agent Halliday informed me he had placed an order with this firm for the metal manger fixtures required. I may also state that I met a representative of this firm on my way back from Alert Bay, and he informed me that an expert in cement and carpentry work was available at once if required. Where so large an expenditure is involved I consider it would be a prudent step to take to engage the services of this man.

2. As the barn is to be built on the slope of a hill, I beg to recommend that cement walls be installed in all four sides of the foundations, and that these walls be raised to the height of the top of the windows. Mr. Indian Agent Halliday stated that he purposed raising these walls to this height on the
upper side only, but the representative of Beatty Bros. Ltd., whom I consulted stated that the results would not justify the saving effected, and this coincides with my own opinion in the matter.

3. That eight steel tubular standards be installed to support the loft instead of six as recommended by Mr. Halliday.

4. That the cement wall facing the upward slope of the hill be waterproofed to prevent seepage. Mr. Indian Agent Halliday stated that he was having weeping tile installed, but the representative of Beatty Bros. Ltd., the Principal, and I, all felt that the waterproofing process should also be undertaken.

5. That the feed room be made rat proof with metal lining such as tin or galvanized iron. Rats are very numerous, hence the necessity of this action.

6. That a cement closed receptacle, not less than 6' x 8' x 6' be constructed, forty feet from the barn, with gutter traps and drainage, so as to receive the washings from the stable gutters. Where the terrain contains so much gravel and so little soil, it is important that all nitrates be conserved, and I strongly recommend that this receptacle be provided in addition to the manure pit. The manure pit will be located on the slope above the barn, and this receptacle on the slope below.

While writing about matters pertaining to this School, I beg to direct your attention to the necessity of having the brick walls of the main School building waterproofed before the autumn rains begin. It would be a help to the School management if this work could be done while the pupils are on holiday. Mr. Indian Agent Halliday stated that he had recommended to you that Bondex Waterproof Paint be used, and I beg to suggest that you wire him to have the work undertaken immediately.

I also beg to direct your attention to the urgent need of a motor truck. As the school has no private wharf and all supplies, coal, etc., have to be transported from the cannery wharf about ¼ of a mile distant, the need of this item of equipment is obvious. When the main school building was under construction your Department kindly provided a grant of $200.00 to buy a second-hand truck. This truck rendered sufficient service to justify its purchase. When it became useless another used truck was purchased by the Principal, but this is now practically worn out, and must soon be replaced. At one time the Principal felt that a boat would be necessary, but if the road to the cannery wharf is completed, or the saw-mill wharf is repaired and made available for the school's use, the cost of the boat may be saved. A good Ford truck can be delivered at Alert Bay for $900.00 and I beg to strongly recommend that this expenditure be authorized at the earliest date possible.
On the whole, I find that very satisfactory progress is being made towards placing this institution on a basis which will enable it to fulfil the purposes for which it is intended, and any steps your Department may be able to take to meet the requirements mentioned will be greatly appreciated.

I have the honour to be

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Dear Sir:

With further reference to my letter of July 21st, dealing with certain matters pertaining to our Alert Bay School, I now beg to direct your attention to certain other important requirements at this institution, and to ask you to kindly undertake to provide the same. They are as follows:

1. The height of the brick chimney above the engine room should be increased by not less than 15 ft., so as to improve the draught. The Principal's residence was not warm last winter, as the heat from the central heating system failed to reach it with sufficient power to affect the temperature. He believes that this will be remedied when the furnace room chimney has been heightened.

2. A larger box stove for heating the sad irons is required for the laundry. The stove already installed for this purpose would be suitable for a smaller school, say for one with a capacity of 25 or 30 pupils, but is practically worthless in a school like Alert Bay.

3. Either bedside chairs or stools with a box top should be provided for each bed. The Principal pointed out that the pupils when dressing and undressing generally sat on the side of the bed with the result that bed springs are broken and the bedding worn out prematurely. The provision of chairs or stools with box tops for holding smaller articles of clothing such as collars, ties, etc., would prevent this. Possibly if the material were supplied the stools which I have suggested might be made as part of the manual training course. The chairs would cost about $2.00 each, and approximately 200 of these would be required. The stools could probably be made for less if the material were supplied by your Department.
The school management will require some help in removing the multitude of big stumps from the land which has been cleared of the forest. I spoke to Mr. Indian Agent Halliday about this and he informed me that the services of a man could be procured at once to blast the stumps with dynamite. He felt sure that the man he had in view could blast at least 100 stumps a day. If the stumps were dynamited the school management could do the rest, and I beg to suggest that Mr. Indian Agent Halliday be authorized to engage the man he has in view and ask him to undertake this work at once. The enclosed photos, (1) and (2) will give you some idea of the number of stumps to be removed and the difficulty of the task. Number (3) will show you in the foreground all the material of the old Boys' Home which has to be removed and the work which must follow to incorporate this bit of ground into the boys' recreation field.

I commend the above requirements to your prompt and sympathetic consideration.

I have the honour to be

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.
