Ottawa, August 8th, 1930.

Sir,

The Church authorities have recommended certain improvements at the Alert Bay Indian Residential School. It is represented that the brick chimney above the engine room should be heightened at least fifteen feet so as to improve the draught and that a larger box stove is required in the laundry. I shall be grateful if you will let me have your recommendation, with estimate of the cost.

Bedside chairs or stools with box top are requested for each bed in the children's dormitories. As a rule, the Department does not supply this equipment but it has been suggested that the materials necessary be allowed and that the manual training class make up the stools. Please make inquiries in this connection and let me have your recommendation, with estimate of the cost.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

W. M. Halliday, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Alert Bay, B. C.
Ottawa, August 8th, 1930.

Reverend Sir,

I am going to make the suggestion to Mr. Halliday that the manual training class make them if the materials are provided.

Sir:

I acknowledge receipt of your letter of August 2, with reference to water-proofing the walls of the Alert Bay Residential School.

I have given this matter considerable study, and I find that Bondex Cement Paint is recommended as being the best obtainable. I have a quotation from a wholesale firm in Vancouver in which they state that Bondex sells at nineteen dollars a hundred pounds, and each pound covers twenty-five square feet. It is usually mixed seven pounds to a gallon, and requires two coats to give a perfectly satisfactory job. This will make the material for the painting amount to probably three hundred and fifty dollars. It is made in white and sixteen tints, but as all the building does not require to be done, only the portions exposed to the south-east storms, it would be as well to use the brick-red, which is practically the same color as the other walls of the building.

This can either be put on with a spray or by means of brushes like whitewash, and the advantage of it is that if it touches the woodwork or the glass windows, it washes right off, while on the brick it sets and wears like iron, according to the advertisements, under any and all weather conditions. I would suggest that the work be done by day labor, as it would only require two men with a portable scaffold which would hang from the roof, and there are men living at Alert Bay, who while not expert painters, could do the work perfectly, and would keep the money in the village. I could not say definitely how much it would cost to put on the paint, but there will be close to fifteen thousand square feet to cover.

Your obedient servant,

(W.M. Halliday)
Indian Agent

Alert Bay, B.C.,
Sir:

Since the receipt of your letter of August 8th, referring to the heightening of at least fifteen feet to the top of the brick chimney above the engine room at the Alert Bay Indian Residential School, I would advise you that I have gone into this matter and I find that it will take 4500 brick and about four barrels of lime to do the necessary work. I have a quotation from Evans, Coleman & Evans, who handle practically all the brick on the coast of B.C., and they give me a quotation delivered at Alert Bay, for common brick $34.16 per thousand, and lime per barrel $3.71, making a total cost of material $168.58. It would require about $20.00 worth of material for scaffolding. Mr. Gibbens, who is the foreman on the building of the new barn at the School is a fair bricklayer, and he estimates the labor at about one hundred dollars.

I may say that this really should be done, as being situated in a hollow, the wind blows down from the top of the hills and strikes on the chimney and creates a bad smoke through the whole building.

Regarding a larger box stove for the laundry, I would recommend that a 36" box stove be obtained for them instead of the one they have. It is used for heating the irons for their work, and the one they have is too small to keep their irons hot for the number of girls needed to carry on the ironing, and a new stove 36", all cast-iron, would cost in Vancouver $23.75, with a probable extra $5.00 for packing, shipping and freight.

Your obedient servant,

(W.M. Halliday)
Indian Agent

Dear Sir,

I am writing you to let you know how I have been treated by the Indian Agent at Alert Bay B.C. I was appointed as foreman by someone at Ottawa or Vancouver Department to be sure to build a barn 38 x 60 ft. on the Indian Industrial School grounds at Alert Bay B.C. I never did get any notice of the appointment until I got a note from the agent here saying he was instructed to put me on as foreman. He gave me the blueprint but refused to let me have the specifications saying he would tell me when the time came, but never did, not until he would see that I was not following the plans then he would hollow me out of my job. He had changed the plan of the ground floor a number of times, he made it miserable for the man as well as me. At the end he gave the order to quit.

We started to excavate the ground on the 18th of July and finished on the 24th of August. It's a bank barn site, but the farm is a flat one. I told him...
before we started that it was no place to build a flat barn, it will cost another thousand or so dollars before they can drive at the ends to unload the wagons; as there are no roads to it. We started at nothing but when we got the 33 ft. the barn was 7 ft high. She says its costing too much to build this blasted thing on me. She had no grounds to fire me the whole substitute as this, she had hired a man to be foreman from Vancouver and I was appointed by some gentlemen from Vancouver or Ottawa and that made him sore. He has ordered stuff that he did not know what they were for.

I was never consulted when anything was ordered. I blame that I have had a helluva deal from start to finish and claim that I should be paid until this barn is finished.

If you wish to write any of the men write to J.E. Blackstone Alert Bay B.C.

awaiting a reply

yours respectfully,

A.A. Gibbon

Sir:

I am enclosing you voucher No. 169 in my own favor for $112.00 for cash paid out on account of wages for the raising of the chimney at the Indian Residential School.

It will be noted that I have slightly exceeded the estimate in the matter of labor, but it was found when the work came to be done that it cost a great deal more for the erection and destroying of the scaffolding than what had been figured, on account of it having to be built on the flat roof of the auditorium, and an extra floor had to be laid there to insure the safety of that building, and then the floor taken up again after the work was done.

The chimney was raised about seventeen feet, and has materially increased the draft from the furnaces, and the engineer in charge tells me has very materially reduced the consumption of fuel.

The school is, as you know, under a hill, and occasionally even when the wind is blowing toward the hill it circles down and blows down on top of the building, and this was the cause of the trouble before. Since the completion, we have had two very windy days, and it has been very closely watched, and while occasionally a puff of wind seems to cut the smoke off at the top of the chimney, none of it has ever come back, so it is to be hoped that the cure has been effective.

I also wish to make some reference to the chimney from the two fireplaces in the Principal's residence. This has proved very unsatisfactory, as if there is any wind at all both fireplaces smoke very badly. It had been my inten...
to submit an estimate for material to raise this chimney above the coping of the roof, but before doing so I have arranged with Mr. Anfield for him to conduct two different experiments to see if the chimney cannot be remedied without raising it. The danger in raising the chimney is that it would have to be well stayed, or the wind might cause it to topple over, and it would require some sixteen or eighteen feet additional height to get above the top of the building.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I have to advise you that during the past week we have had unusually heavy rains at Alert Bay which probably only occurs at periods of some five or six years; the last one was four years ago. It brought a serious condition of affairs at the Residential School at Alert Bay; it so happened that I was away for a few days holiday, and while I was in Vancouver I received two letters from the Principal of the School drawing my attention to the state of affairs.

In past letters, particularly to those of March 22nd and August 11th, attention was drawn to the fact that the walls of the School were not water-tight, and a recommendation was made to the Department in these communications that they should be covered with a water-proof paint on the stormy side of the house, and while a complete estimate of the cost was not given, it being rather difficult to figure on the cost of labor in this place, a complete inventory of the cost of the paint was submitted, but to this there has been no reply received up to the present time. I have just returned from an inspection of the school, and have before me the letter from the Principal referring to the walls. He says the outstanding defects are:

(a) The two girls' dormitories on the first floor had walls, the entire face of one and large sections of the other, streaming with water.
(b) Serious leaks were discovered in the boys' two top dormitories.
(c) Five electric light shades were found half filled with rain water, which apparently had followed the conduit and got into the lamp shades. This must be looked into or we will have serious trouble with our light plant.
(d) Six window sills in the basement were allowing water to leak through, one in the boys' side so badly that children have been kept mopping up the floors almost all day.

(e) Bad leaks, with consequent flooded floors, were noted at the rear kitchen entrance, in the laundry, one of the infirmaries and in the electric light room.

(f) The entire face wall of the residence abutting the main building has streamed water all day, and those occupying these rooms have had to move.

Regarding the above, which are copied from the Principal's letter, I may say that I looked into them all, and find that the statements are quite correct, and in my opinion if the walls were water-proofed these would all be avoided. Had the water come in through leaky roofs it would come in during any ordinary heavy rain, but these conditions have never prevailed excepting during continuous heavy rains accompanied by south-east winds, and as you are aware, the building is built of tile with a brick veneer, and all brick will absorb water up to a certain point and hold it, but after that point it will leak through. This, getting into the hollow tiles is, in the opinions of all who have looked at it, the reason for the walls being wet, and this can easily be avoided by having the building water-proofed.

On December 10th the Principal wrote again, but this had to do more with outside matters. If you will look at the plan of the drainage system as prepared by the Department of the Interior Dominion Water Power Reclamation Service, their file No. 114, you can see the layout of the outside drainage. On the extreme right of the blueprint there is an open drain approximately 320 feet long, and a twelve inch tile drain coming through the bank to the fields at the back of the school. This tile drain has an inlet made of a concrete block in which the tile is set, and at the exit has another concrete block, but for 250 feet of its length there is very little fall, and apparently it chokes.

While in Vancouver I took the matter up with the engineer who had laid out the works, Mr. W.C. Warren, and obtained from him blue-prints showing all the drainage system for which his Department was responsible, and I discussed the matter with him, and he was of the opinion that had the inlet end of the pipe been kept clear, the water would have been kept down, but
on examination today I find that this is not quite the case. When the water rose in the field, which it did all in one night, they tried to clear the end and found nothing there, and so went about six or eight feet down the length of the pipe, shovelling the earth from above it, and broke open the tile, and immediately a rush of water ensued which drained the field fairly well, and in doing so it washed away the bridge at the road next the beach.

I have gone all over this matter today, and have compared it carefully with the profile plans of the blueprint, and I am of the opinion that the system should be somewhat changed. I would recommend that I be allowed to take up all the covered drain, give it at least two feet more pitch, as there is plenty of fall available, put in sixteen inch tile at the upper end with three man-holes so it can be cleaned out in event of any dirt getting in, and continue the twelve inch tile right to the beach, and make a concrete culvert commencing at the bridge and coming right through to the beach, where the water would be discharged. The expense would not be very considerable, excepting for labor, which could all be done by Indians, but it is urgently recommended. It would require possibly forty sacks of cement and one hundred feet of sixteen inch tile and possibly one hundred and fifty feet of twelve inch tile, which is not very expensive. This is urgently recommended, although possibly there may not be another flood such as we have had in the past week for several years; but there is no reason why it should not occur again within the next month, as it has occurred several times before, to my recollection.

There is another difficulty equally as bad, and that is in connection with the drainage of the boiler room. When I was there this morning there was six inches of water in the floor of the boiler room, and from what the Principal tells me, during the worst of it they had to work practically day and night with buckets and pumps to get any fire at all, and I believe for one day they were without any fire in the furnaces. This condition, in my opinion, has arisen from two sources. The clogging of the drain from the field behind allowed the ground around the building to become super-saturated with water, and in the drainage system there is no evidence to be found of any outlet from the small drain which shows in the floor of the boiler house. There was a row of weeping tiles put round the building which
should have been connected with the sewerage system, but I can find no evidence of it having been done, and Mr. Warren tells me that he does not know if this drainage was connected with the sewerage, for which he was responsible. The Principal is of the opinion that this little drain that was put in only was connected with a weeping tile drain which ran a short distance and then died away in the gravel. This would take care of a small amount of water, as gravel does not hold water, but during the last flood time that they had the water came into the boiler room through this pipe, showing that it is choked someplace, but nobody knows where it is, or with what it is connected, and I would recommend that a six inch glazed tile be put from the beach following round the west end of the School and being connected with the engine room, to prevent any such things in the future, with one clean-out manhole about twenty feet away from the boiler house. The chief expense in doing this would be the labor in digging the ditches, as the cut through the bank would require to be about seven feet deep, and there is always trouble with the banks caving in while the work is being done. However there would be no occasion to have any engineer or inspector come to take charge of the work, as I am quite capable of looking after it myself, and I can get local labor to do the work, as a number of the Indians are idle and looking for work, and there are several white people who would be glad of a few days work at even minimum wages.

As mentioned before, it might be that we have flood conditions again this year, or it may be that we do not have them again for three or four years, but with an institution of this kind having upwards of two hundred people living under the roof, their health should be the first consideration, and I would earnestly recommend that immediate authority be given me to have the necessary work done along the lines that I have suggested.

I am sending a copy of this letter to Mr. W.C. Warren, the engineer in charge, and if he makes any objection or has any suggestions with regard to it, I should be very glad to entertain them, but it would seem that haste is very necessary in connection with it. I am also sending a copy of this communication to Mr. Ditchburn, Indian Commissioner in Victoria.

Your obedient servant,

(W.M. Halliday)
Indian Agent

Dear Mr. Halliday:

During the past two days rain has fallen almost incessantly, with the result that the building once more presents a deplorable picture to those charged with maintaining the health and welfare of the pupils of this school. The following outstanding defects were noted on an inspection of the school:

(a) The two girls' dormitories on the first floor had walls, the entire face of one and large sections of the other, streaming with water.

(b) Serious leaks were discovered in the boys' two top dormitories.

(c) Five electric light shades were found half filled with rain water, which apparently had followed the conduit and got into the lamp shades. This must be looked into or we will have serious trouble with our light plant.

(d) Six window sills in the basement were allowing water to leak through, one in the boys' side so badly that children have been kept mopping up the floors almost all day.

(e) Bad leaks with consequent flooded floors were noted at the rear kitchen entrance, in the laundry, one of the infirmaries and in the electric light room.

(f) The entire face wall of the residence shutting the main building has streamed water all day and those occupying these rooms have had to move.

We might say that we have carefully inspected all the roofs and have to advise that all the rain hoppers are clear and functioning normally.

The urgent attention of your Department is requested so that this condition may be remedied. We are of the opinion that the Department hardly realises that we have children in this school sleeping in dormitories, the walls of which are streaming with water, and are hardly ever free from damp.

We are having enough worry with health these days, and we really cannot be asked to take the responsibility for what must inevitably result unless conditions are remedied forthwith. Our regret is keen indeed that you are not here today to see for yourself the prevalent condition of affairs.

At the same time we must report that, in spite of the drainage provided, the fields behind the school are now badly
flooded, and though we have opened emergency ditches, the water is still steadily rising and we are becoming somewhat worried about the boiler rooms and basements. In our humble opinion, the concrete drainage is totally inadequate to handle flood conditions which periodically visit Alert Bay in the winter time.

Yours very truly,

(Sgd) F. Earl Anfield.

Dear Sir:

Further to ours of the 9th instant, we have to advise you that the rains of the past three days have caused most serious flood conditions at this school. The field behind the school flooded and the water rose to such a level that we were compelled to break open the concrete drainage to release the pressure on the building. This caused a wash out at the main gateway, washing out the bridge and a part of the roadway.

More serious still is the fact that the boiler room is flooded with nearly two feet of water, rendering it impossible to operate any of the heating apparatus of the building. The coal cellar is flooded and there is imminent danger of the electric light room being flooded as well. In fact only prodigious efforts continuous day and night for the past 48 hours has prevented the entire basement floor from being flooded out. We have had nearly twenty boys at a time bailing water out, in addition to a two line gasoline pump borrowed from the Cannery, and combined efforts of both have only held the water level. The walls are leaking in all directions. There is a drain in the boiler room but instead of discharging the water it has been the place where most of it has come in. Water has poured up this drain in huge quantities. We may say that this drain has been a source of trouble ever since entering this building. It was put in very early during construction to drain water from the boiler room excavation - made of tile we think. As far as we know it was never hooked into the main drainage system and was supposed to run out somewhere in front of the building. Put in as a temporary drain it was made to act as permanent drainage hooked into nowhere at all. It was surrounded with weeping tile and now all the flood water has rushed up this drain into the building. We are today wiring Mr. Carson as follows:-

"Boiler rooms out of commission under two feet water. Wire at once construction and approximate outlet of boiler room drain, water pouring up this drain and through concrete walls. Anfield."
We are forwarding copy of this letter to Mr. Ditchburn also the following wire:

"Flood condition field rear school also boiler room, coal cellar under two feet water plant out of commission, boiler room drain not hooked to main drainage, wire authority engage men dig for this outlet. Principal, Residential Schools, Alert Bay B.C."

We have done what we can, and would ask that you come up to enquire into this matter as soon as possible. We are wiring Mr. Ditchburn on account of your absence on business in Vancouver and Victoria.

Yours very sincerely,

(Sgd) W. Earl Anfield,
Principal.

(c) Five electric light shades were found half filled with rain-water, which apparently had followed the conduit and got into the lamp shades. This must be looked into or we will have serious trouble with our light plant.

(d) Six window sills in the basement were allowing water to leak through, one in the boys' side so badly that children have been kept mopping up the floors almost all day.

(e) Bad leaks with consequent flooded floors were noted at the rear kitchen entrance in the laundry, one of the infirmaries and in the electric light room.

(f) The entire face wall of the residence abutting the main building has streamed water all day and those occupying these rooms have had to move.

We might say that we have carefully inspected all the roofs and have to advise that all the rain hoppers are clear and functioning normally.

The urgent attention of your Department is requested so that this condition may be remedied. We are of the opinion that the Department hardly realizes that we have children in this school sleeping in dormitories, the walls of which are streaming with water, and are hardly ever free from damp.

We are having enough worry with health these days, and we really cannot be asked to take the responsibility for what must inevitably result unless conditions are remedied forthwith. Our regret is keen indeed that you are not here today to see for yourself the prevalent condition of affairs.

At the same time we must report that, in spite of the drainage provided, the fields behind the school are now badly
flooded, and though we have opened emergency ditches, the water is still steadily rising and we are becoming somewhat worried about the boiler rooms and basements. In our humble opinion, the concrete drainage is totally inadequate to handle flood conditions which periodically visit Alert Bay in the winter time.

Yours very truly,

(Sgd) F. Earl Anfield.

Dear Sir:

Further to ours of the 9th instant, we have to advise you that the rains of the past three days have caused most serious flood conditions at this school. The field behind the school flooded and the water rose to such a level that we were compelled to break over the concrete drainage to release the pressure on the building. This caused a wash out at the main gateway, washing out the bridge and a part of the roadway.

More serious still is the fact that the boiler room is flooded with nearly two feet of water, rendering it impossible to operate any of the heating apparatus of the building. The coal cellar is flooded and there is imminent danger of the electric light room being flooded as well. In fact only prodigious efforts continuous day and night for the past 48 hours has prevented the entire basement floor from being flooded out. We have had nearly twenty boys at a time baling water out, in addition to a two line gasoline pump borrowed from the Cannery, and combined efforts of both have only held the water level. The walls are leaking in all directions. There is a drain in the boiler room but instead of discharging the water it has been the place where most of it has come in. Water has poured up this drain in huge quantities. We may say that this drain has been a source of trouble ever since entering this building. It was put in very early during construction to drain water from the boiler room excavation made of tile we think. As far as we know it was never hooked into the main drainage system and was supposed to run out somewhere in front of the building. But in as a temporary drain it was made to act as permanent drainage hooked into nowhere at all. It was surrounded with weeping tile and now all the flood water has rushed up this drain into the building. We are today wiring Mr. Carson as follows:-

"Boiler rooms out of commission under two feet water. Wire at once construction and approximate outlet of boiler room drain water pouring up this drain and through concrete walls. Anfield."

We are forwarding copy of this letter to Mr. Ditchburn, also the following wire:-

"Flood condition field rear school also boiler room, coal cellar under two feet water plant out of commission. Boiler room drain not hooked to main drainage. Wire authority engage men dig for this outlet. Principal, Residential Schools, Alert Bay B.C."

We have done what we can, and would ask that you come up to enquire into this matter as soon as possible. We are wiring Mr. Ditchburn on account of your absence on business in Vancouver and Victoria.

Sir: Re - Alert Bay School.

As requested by you, I made an inspection of the above mentioned school and submit for your consideration as follows:

On arriving at Alert Bay I interviewed the Principal of the school, Mr. Anfield, and was informed that prior to my visit by about two weeks, a very heavy rain had occurred extending over the greater part of a week, and as a result of insufficient drainage facilities, the boiler room had become flooded to a depth of two or three feet. He also pointed out that a considerable amount of seepage had taken place through the exterior walls of the building on the exposed face, that is the south east side. The evidence of this was quite noticeable and the outside wall was still in a saturated condition.

From examination of the premises and from information obtained from others, it is apparent that extremely heavy rain prevailed for three or four days, quite possibly in excess of that recorded by the meteorological station. To the heavy rains and to the fact that the relief drains were not in working condition, owing to accumulation of debris in them, may be attributed the flooding which occurred. Material damage was very small but the discomfort must have been very great owing to the dampness within the building and to the impossibility of keeping the heating plant operating.

C.E. Webb, Eng.,
District Chief Engineer,
Dom. Water Power & Hydrometric Bureau,
739 Hastings Street, West,
Vancouver, B.C.
DESCRIPTION

The school is situated about 200 feet from the seashore and on ground approximately 20 feet above high tide. Immediately to the rear of the school is a depression about 1000 feet long and several hundred feet wide. Beyond this depression the ground rises with a moderate slope for a quarter of a mile or more.

At the time the school was built a drain was installed to prevent the accumulation of water in the depression. A part of this drain is open ditch and part covered, the covered portion consisting of 12-inch pipe 385 feet long. This drain has an ordinary capacity of 2.5 c.f.s., and was designed for a maximum rainfall of 3 inches in 24 hours, the heaviest recorded at Alert Bay between the years 1923 and 1929. It is, however, capable of handling double this quantity without serious flooding.

The floor of the boiler room of the school is several feet below this depression and is provided with its own drain. The contractor for the school installed this for his own use and did not connect it to drains leading from other parts of the school system, but carried it out under the school to its outlet at a point about 50 feet in front of the school. To this drain in the boiler room he connected all the tile drains around the rear of the school.

On examination I found this drain blocked at some point under the school and several inches of water on the boiler room floor. Apparently the intercepting tile at the rear of the school had brought its drainage into the room without means of exit.
All other drains were reported as functioning satisfactorily, and I found them quite clean.

RELIEF FROM FLOODING

To obviate the possibility of future flooding of the boiler room it is necessary to provide a new drainage system for this part of the building, either in whole or in part.

The interceptor drain at the rear of the school should be provided with a different outlet, preferably to the existing system. This may be attained by re-laying this drain and reversing the direction of flow and providing it with an outlet into the inspection chamber immediately to the east of the school.

The boiler room floor drainage may be taken care of by a sump pump discharging to the laundry drain if it is found impossible to recondition the present drain. The cost of this work would be $599.00, including the cost of the pump installed.

To provide a gravity drain from the boiler room including connections from interceptor drain and additional outlet for the depression at the rear of the school would cost $1286.35. While the cost of this is high, it has the advantage of providing additional drainage facilities, should a storm of such proportions or, for that matter of greater intensity, again visit the locality.

Improvements and repairs to the farm drain are suggested at a cost of $329.00. These include a new road crossing to replace that washed out and a gutter from the present end of the pipe to the new culvert, as well as a screen on the intake.
In addition it is suggested that the boiler room walls be waterproofed on the inside and that the leaky windows in the basement be caulked at an approximate cost of $50.00.

A summary of the cost of carrying out the suggested improvements including the alternatives suggested for drainage is appended.

WALL SEEPAGE

The most serious result of the heavy rains was the seepage through the outside walls, especially those with a south east exposure. The effect of this was quite noticeable along the wall above the adjoining Principal's residence and between the engine room and boiler room and as reported to me, around a number of windows. Some seepage was reported as coming through the basement walls of the boiler room and coal bins, below ground level, although this had ceased at the time of my visit.

The seepage through the exterior walls I am informed has taken place ever since the school was built and that it attained maximum proportions during the heavy rain previously referred to.

While I am not able to confirm these statements, I observed that the walls were in a saturated condition and a very heavy efflorescence was evident on the interior surface.

The only solution of this difficulty appears to be the complete waterproofing of the exterior walls on the south and east exposures. While the expense involved is considerable, the probable resulting damage under present conditions may exceed any expenditure for such a purpose by a wide margin.
Aside from the material damage such conditions, if allowed to continue, would undoubtedly seriously affect the health of those resident in the institution.

**WATERPROOFING**

Several methods are available for waterproofing. The most widely used and possibly the best commercial form is Minwax, a colourless preparation of bitumen which does not discolour the brick. This preparation is applied by brush or spray to a clean dry surface.

The Sylvester process consists of the application of one or more pairs of soap and alum solutions, alternately. While the cost of materials in this process is very reasonable, the cost of application is high and as the method of application determines the effectiveness of the process, it is hardly to be preferred to the first mentioned preparation, especially as the ultimate cost would be about the same.

The area of walls necessary to process is about 14,000 sq.ft., consisting of the south and east faces and projections. The cost of the Minwax treatment is estimated at $3½ cents per sq.ft., or $1890.00.

Waterproofing can only be carried out in the dry weather and for this reason July would probably be the best time.

The unit cost of the work includes material, pointing, labour and supervision.

Your obedient servant,

W. C. Warren,
Assistant Hydraulic Engineer.

Memorandum to Mr. Webb:

Re: Alert Bay School

Since forwarding you my report of the 7th inst., I have received information that the heavy rain storm referred to, occurred during the 7th, 8th and 9th of December, when the precipitation was 1.75, 3.95 and 0.36 inches respectively, as recorded by the Meteorological Service. There need, however, be no uncertainty as to the ability of the drain to handle storm water. Sir:

Re: Alert Bay School

In accordance with your instructions, repairs and replacements were carried out to the drainage system at Alert Bay School, as suggested in my report of January 5th. The work was commenced February 9th and completed February 24th.

The accompanying plan shows in red the location of the improvements. Detailed description of work carried out follows:

INTERCEPTING DRAIN

The intercepting drain, which had originally been laid around the rear of the school building, with its several outlets in the boiler room, was relaid and diverted to the inspection chamber immediately to the east of the building. This drain throughout its length was laid below the footing so as to intercept all seepage to that depth. In all 220 feet of tile was laid for this purpose, consisting of 110 feet 6" tile and 110 feet 4" tile.

BOILER ROOM DRAIN

It had been intended to provide

C.E. Webb, Esq.,
District Chief Engineer,
Dominion Water Power & Hydrometric Bureau,
VANCOUVER, B.C.
a pump for taking care of the seepage into the boiler room but efforts to clean out the old drain were successful.

The drain was therefore reconditioned where it could be got at, and extended to the beach. Sizes of tile are as shown on plan. Underneath the building the slope is very flat so that the drain soon silts up. In clearing the drain it was found that about fifty feet had been completely filled up with silt. The old inlet in the boiler room was unsuitable as it did not provide access to the drain for cleaning purposes.

In re-constructing this drain a sump 3' x 3' x 3' was installed to allow for the accumulation of debris and to provide means of access for cleaning. A cover and screen were installed and a cleaning cable provided.

It will probably not be necessary to install a sump pump if reasonable precautions are observed in keeping the drain in working order.

SEEPEAGE

As stated in my report of January 5th, seepage occurred through the walls of the boiler room and coal bin. I have since found that such was not the case but that the seepage occurred along the joint between the floor and the walls. Nowhere could I find the concrete basement walls porous.
The new drains and the clearing of the boiler room drain should provide for all surface water likely to accumulate around the boiler room which is the lowest part of the building.

While excavating for the sump constructed in the boiler room, at a depth of four feet below the floor surface, a water bearing stratum was encountered. Although water rose in the pit to the drain outlet or about three feet in depth it is not anticipated that trouble will be experienced from this source, as sufficient drainage has been provided. This seepage would appear to be from a source not in the immediate proximity of the school.

SURFACE DRAINAGE

Owing to stoppage of the covered portion of the farm drain during the extremely heavy precipitation of last December it was found necessary to provide a screen chamber to prevent a recurrence of such obstruction. In addition an inspection chamber was added midway in the length of this drain to facilitate cleaning. The screen chamber consists of a concrete chamber with a sump and supporting a substantial steel trash rack 3' x 3'. The inspection chamber is of sufficient size to provide for the ordinary cleaning operations.

As a result of the release of the accumulated water by the clearing of the drain, a very heavy washout occurred from the end of
the covered drain to the beach including the road culvert. The metal road culvert was replaced by one of reinforced concrete 24" x 20" x 25' long and a concrete lined gutter 160 feet long, with 24" bed, provided from the end of the covered drain to the culvert.

The gutter should be re-surfaced at some future time as it was spoiled by bad weather at the time it was laid. The cost would be approximately $30.00.

Regarding the request that a fire gong be installed adjacent to the laundry and boiler room, I have to say it is considered that it should not be necessary to have a gong installed at this point. Any children employed in these services should be able to easily escape from the building in case of a fire occurring in the laundry, boiler room, or in any part of the building.

Your obedient servant,

A. P. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

W. M. Halliday, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Alert Bay, B.C.
Fire Protection:

The fire escapes were badly placed in the rear of the school. The greatest fire risk in the school is within thirty feet of the foot of the fire escapes.

The doors from the girls' dormitories to the Fire Escapes are kept locked. The supervisors in rooms quite near but across a corridor had keys to these doors. This for various reasons seems a very dangerous plan. I pointed out some of the dangers to the Principal and suggested the provision of small glass boxes with spare keys placed near the doors leading to the escapes. The Principal had these glass boxes and keys in position within 48 hours.

Fire Drills are regularly held. At the one held while I was inspecting the school, everyone was clear of the building in less than two minutes from the first sound of the fire gongs. Delay was caused by those in the laundry and boiler room not hearing the alarm. A large fire gong, at least 10 inches, is required. It should be placed near the laundry. The present system of gongs is quite inaudible there when machinery is in operation.

I also beg to recommend that a 50 foot rope ladder with wooden steps be placed in the sun-room off the infirmary, one end being bolted into the wall or the verandah under the window. This would aid the escape of patients under extreme emergency.

Sanitary Conditions:

The drains run to the sea. The school is experiencing trouble at times with the sewers. These are, I understand, FOUR INCH to the outlet. The Principal has had to place a temporary wooden man hole clean out at the outlet. A permanent cement man hole will be necessary here. May I please be permitted to state that a four inch sewer pipe in such a building as this is in my opinion quite inadequate. If you will please refer to the plans for the building, you will see that a SIX INCH sewer was called for under the floors of the basements. The kitchens, lavatories, toilets and boiler rooms are kept clean.

Floors:

There is considerable shrinkage in the soft wood floor of
of the auditorium.

Walls:

The rain has been driven through the walls on the S. E. side of the buildings. During the wet weather, the rain came in by gallons and collected in the dormitories. Effervescence has set in badly in the plaster of the dormitories and in the Principal's Residence. Mr. Indian Commissioner Ditchburn has this matter in hand. The school will need replastering in part at an early date.

Laundry:

About 2600 articles pass through the laundry per week. No proper guards were placed over the belting and the more dangerous parts of the machines. The Principal is having wooden guards placed wherever there is any danger. There is far too much hand ironing required. One steam ironer is needed as soon as funds will permit the Department to supply such a machine. The 5 H. P. boiler for laundry steam is far too small. At least a 10 H.P. boiler is required. I watched the engineer try to keep the pressure up to 100 pounds in the present boiler. When the laundry machines were turned on the pressure fell from over 100 pounds to less than 80 pounds in less than 30 seconds.

Farming:

There is a small Dairy Building. The concrete cooling tank leaks. The rectifying of this is in the hands of the Indian Agent. A large new barn has been constructed. In this a hopper system of feed bins has been constructed by the manual training class. The concrete floor of this new barn has been very badly laid. The concrete did not set properly, hence it is very uneven. Temporary planking has been laid over the concrete to act as cow stands.

Dear Sir:

In connection with the flooding which took place in the basement of the Alert Bay Indian Residential School during the past winter, I beg to say that as a result of an investigation made by Mr. Engineer Warren it was found that a drain pipe from the boiler room had become blocked up apparently from ashes, and in order that this might not occur again I wrote to Principal Anfield pointing out the necessity for him taking precautions to see that the drainage works did not again become clogged.

On the 29th April in a letter received from Principal Anfield he pointed out that although the specifications called for a hydrant stand in the boiler room and ample hose, the same had not been installed when building the school, and that in his opinion the safety factor in regard to flooding conditions would be considerably augmented if a proper hydrant stand and hose were supplied for the boiler room in question.

In looking up the specifications for this school I found a clause which stated that the contractor was to "provide and put up a stand pipe protection service at centre of main corridor on each floor and in the boiler room".

I, therefore, deemed it essential to write to Mr. Carson, the contractor, asking him why this connection had not been made, and I am today in receipt of a letter from him to which he has attached a letter from the contractor who installed the plumbing system. From this communication it would appear that there was an extra room added above the coal room which meant raising the roof drainage pipe 11 feet, also hose tap and piping over floor drain in the boiler room, as well as steam and hot water connections to soap barrel in the laundry. The contractor states that he was arranged at the time with the Clerk of the Works that if no exceptions were to be made for the above, the hose and valve could be omitted in this place, but that a tee was left in the main for valve in future use.

I am attaching hereto copy of Mr. Carson's letter also that of Mr. Beck, the plumbing contractor, but I would like to know from you as to whether the Department was made cognizant of the arrangement referred to at the time the building was in progress of construction.

I am of the opinion, however, that it would be advisable to install a suitable hydrant with sufficient hose for the proper flushing out of this drain from the boiler room.

Your obedient servant,

W.M.D./K.D.

Sir:

With reference to past correspondence regarding the water at the Alert Bay Indian Residential School, in which it was promised that a report of the analysis would be forwarded, I would advise you that I have just received from Mr. Anfield his correspondence regarding it. In the letter which I wrote you I stated that the Boiler Inspector believed that there must be a heavy vegetable matter in the water, but the report from the G.S. Eldridge Company, who are probably the best chemists operating in British Columbia, states as follows:

Marks - None

Reaction - Very slightly (PH 6.8-6.9.) Acid.

Suspended Matter - Parts per Million, 2.0.

Analysis Filtered Sample

| Component                  | Value |
|---------------------------|-------|
| Organic and volatile solids | 57.0  |
| Fixed                     | 61.0  |
| Total                     | 118.0 |

Analysis of Fixed Solids

| Component                  | Value |
|---------------------------|-------|
| Silica SiO₂               | 10.0  |
| Ferric Oxide and Alumina   |       |
| (Fe₂O₃, Al₂O₃)            | 5.0   |
| Lime CaO.                 | 25.0  |
| Magnesia MgO.             | 8.0   |
| Sulphur Trioxide SO₃      | Trace |
| Chlorine Cl.              | 8.0   |
| Alkalies and undetermined | 5.0   |

"The above analysis shows the chief scaling compounds in this water to consist of lime sulphates, lime carbonate and magnesium carbonate. We would suggest as a
corrective that 0.15 to 0.20 lbs of tri-sodium phosphate be added to every 1000 gallons of feed water. This should prevent scale formation and precipitate the solids in the form of a sludge, which can be readily eliminated by means of "blowing off" after suitable periods of operation."

You will see from this that they are in error as to the presence of organic matter being the cause of the trouble in the boilers; it is a scale which forms in the water through the combination of Silica and Lime, and they suggest a corrective for it.

Mr. Anfield has informed me that he has sent another sample of water for a bacteriological analysis, and when this is received, I will again forward it to you.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I am enclosing voucher No. 198 for $49.37 in favor of the Vancouver Iron Works for repairs to the upright boiler at the Alert Bay Indian Residential School, used in connection with the laundry.

The Principal has forwarded this account to me on instructions from the Commission who have informed him that it is the obligation of the Department to keep the major items of mechanical repairs at the School in working order. They found that the tubes in the boiler were leaking, and it was necessary to send the machine to town for retubing. They are in receipt of a letter from the Vancouver Iron Works stating that the trouble was caused by water conditions, being impregnated with vegetable matter, and requesting a sample of the water for chemical analysis. The Principal states that this has been forwarded, and the results will be sent to me on receipt of the analysis. However with regard to the water conditions I cannot see how it could be at fault, as it is artesian water and is pumped from a depth of ninety feet in the earth, and I cannot see how it could be impregnated with vegetable matter.

The Boiler Inspector recently went over the three boilers at the school, and reported the same thing to the Principal in person, and he advised the use of Milk of Lime in the water in all the boilers. He stated that otherwise there would be a constant recurrence of the trouble.

The Commission have also desired the Principal to draw the attention of the Department to the fact that the high-pressure boiler is too small for the requirements of the laundry, for which it supplies the necessary steam. The Boiler Inspector's report shows this plant is registering 3.6 H.P., but they state that the specifications for the installation of this equipment in the school on page 87, paragraph 1, state as follows:
"The Contractor shall furnish and install where indicated on plan or directed a five H.P. vertical tubular steam boiler of standard type, subject to a hydrostatic test of 150 lbs. before shipment."

Your obedient servant,

(W.M. Halliday)

Sir:

I have the honor to transmit herewith the report of the Inspector of Indian Agencies for B.C. upon his inspection of the Kwawkewlth Indian Agency.

"4 School".

In regard to the washing, lavatory and steam heater for laundry purposes, reference to the specifications accompanying plan 577 (St George's school, Lytton) on which the Alert Bay school was apparently built and equipped shows (on the last page but one) that a 5 H.P. boiler was to have been installed. There is nothing on file to either support or question the statement of the Principal to the Inspector of agencies that the allegedly inadequate steam heater is only 3½ H.P. nor have we any previous reports that the washing and lavatory accommodation has been found to be inadequate.

In regard to the smoky chimneys in the principal's house, however, I would refer to the letter of Indian Agent Halliday to the Department dated January 7th, 1930 and also the Department's file No. 156-0-18 especially letters dated January 30th, 1930 and April 1st, 1930. The complaints subsequently dealt with by correspondence between the Commissioner and the Department touch rather upon certain deficiencies of attention to requirements of building specifications than upon new work to be done. Hence the question of raising the chimneys appears to have been held in abeyance. In a letter received here by the Commissioner from Principal Anfield, dated May 5th, 1930, he stated:

"Something must be done about waterproofing the brickwork, if the health standard of our children is to be maintained; and in the interests of economical administration, the stacks should be hoisted. We would also appreciate your report on the condition of the Principal's residence."

In a letter to Mr. Ditchburn, dated June 3rd, 1930 M. Gow, the Building Inspector who was appointed to supervise the erection of the Alert Bay Residential school stated:

"I am fully convinced that to get the best results from the large chimney carrying the two main boilers, that it should be raised to a height of twenty feet in excess of what it is at present. The chimney from the kitchen and laundry would not of necessity need to be raised more than another four or five feet to obtain good results I think. The only remaining one then, is that of the residence, which, undoubtedly, should be carried up to a height of two or three feet in excess of the main building, or I am afraid no matter how they cap it, with certain winds it would be liable to give trouble."

The foregoing was sent to the Department by Mr. Ditchburn on June 16th, 1930, under cover of a letter for the attention of Mr. Orr.
The Department by letter No. 156-0-5, dated January 16th 1931, advised the Commissioner that the Dominion Water Power Branch were being instructed to have the outside walls of the building waterproofed. This, however, was not carried out and the Department advised, by letter dated August 6th, 1931, that it would be impossible to authorize the work in that year as there were no funds available. Hence the waterproofing has not been done, and the raising of the chimneys seems to have disappeared as an issue until the receipt of Inspector Pragnell's report.

We have no estimate on the cost of raising the chimneys, but if the Department is now able to have this attended to, I shall be pleased to obtain an estimate of the cost, if instructed to do so. The Department will also be able to advise if or when funds can be made available for the waterproofing of the brickwork.

Perhaps it would be advisable to have Mr. Orr consider the questions, mooted by the Inspector, as to his idea of the inadequacy of the washing and lavatory accommodation as well as the question of the laundry steam heater referred to previously herein.

Chas. C. Perry,
Asst. Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Kamloops, B.C., July 30, 1932.

Dear Sir,

I beg to submit the following report upon the above agency. (Kwawkewlth Agency No.2.)

SCHOOL

During my visit the Indian residential school was closed for the holidays, a few children being in residence for various reasons. I went over the school with the Reverend Principal, Mr. Anfield. The washing and lavatory accommodation in this school seems to me to be inadequate. Some classrooms were being moved to the old building to make more room in the new. The principal informs me that the steam heater for laundry purposes is inadequate being only 3½ h.p. and should be 10 h.p. The chimneys in the Principal's house smoke badly and should be raised in height. I found the building well kept and in good order, though the leaks through the porousness of the brick on the window sills show up badly. I believe the Department is attending to this. I found cultivation being well attended to and greatly improved since my last visit. The rather scrub stock of cows at the school are being gradually replaced by guernsey cows.

Geo. S. Pragnell,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Dear Mr. Halliday:

At the opening of the present term we placed four of our five classrooms in the building previously known as the "Girls' Home", now utilized as an Academic Block. In this building we have placed electric light, have done a great deal of painting, and have overhauled and put into first-class shape the heating plant, all at the cost of school grants. Tremendous relief has been experienced in the main building as a result of moving the classrooms to the academic block; we have more room available for play room space during the long wet winters, and we have been able to turn one of the former classrooms into a manufacturing room where the girls can under proper tuition take dressmaking and sewing in a proper way.

We have already formed a conclusion, however, that it will be necessary to build a covered walk from the rear of the present main building to the front steps of this academic block. As you are aware, the rainfall here during the winter is extremely heavy, and though all our children are equipped with coats or slickers, yet we feel that the health of the youngsters demands that there be a covered way from one building to the other. Dear Sir:

I have the honor to acknowledge receipt of Departmental letter dated September 21st, No.156-0-5, in regard to the amount of $2500.00 which the Department has been good enough to make available for work at the Alert Bay Indian Residential School, and in which it was requested that I advise the Department what I considered the most urgent repairs and estimate of the cost, and also state how I would recommend having the work carried out. In reply I beg to say:

1. The special report dated January 5th, 1931, prepared by Mr. Engineer W. G. Warren of the Dominion Water Power and Hydrometric Bureau on repairs and improvements to the school draining system and waterproofing of building indicates that the cost of what is known as the Minwax treatment to be given the school walls on the south and east exposures will amount approximately to $1890.00, which waterproofing could only be carried out in dry weather, preferably in the month of July. It appears therefore out of the question to undertake any expenditure on waterproofing since the rainy season has now begun. It is to be hoped therefore that this appropriation could be held in abeyance for expenditure after the end of the current fiscal year.

2. The raising of two chimneys to an additional height of 15 feet each, from the kitchen and laundry on the one hand and from the Principal's residence on the other, should be proceeded with immediately. It is understood from Mr. Indian Agent Halliday that the main chimney was raised at the same time a barn was constructed recently at Alert Bay. It may be necessary to secure the services of a carpenter at Vancouver to go to Alert Bay to attend to the scaffolding, while the services of a bricklayer may be obtainable in the vicinity of Malcolm Island, and such a man I am informed by Agent Halliday resides there and is able to do excellent work. Under separate cover I am writing the Department in regard to the removal of old buildings from a sawmill site recently acquired under lease by the Department from the Synod Authorities of the Anglican Church. It is thought that the carpenter who does the work connected with the chimneys might also be able to supervise the demolition of the old buildings at the same time and his rate of pay for such work will not of necessity be the same as paid for ordinary carpenter work. The prevailing rate of pay for this work would be that of the Public Works Department, whatever that may be. It is estimated that the cost of erecting the chimney extensions together with material, freight and fare of the carpenter to and from Vancouver should not exceed approximately the sum of $425.00. Of course the cost would be kept as low as possible compatible with a satisfactory job. I would suggest that Mr. J. Woods of Vancouver, who has done some very good work for the Department before at the Indian villages of Klahoose, Homalco and Pemberton, be sent to Alert Bay to supervise both of the above mentioned jobs. Sir:

I have the honor to transmit herewith copy of a letter dated October 21st, instant, signed by Reverend Dr. Westgate, Field Secretary, Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada, together with copy of a letter covered thereby, dated October 21st, addressed to the Secretary, Indian Residential School Commission, M.S.C.C., Winnipeg, Man., by Mr. Anfield, Esq., Principal, Indian Residential School, Alert Bay, B.C., these letters being in regard to certain financial grants asked for from the Department for expenditure upon the St. Michael's Indian Residential School at Alert Bay, Kwawkewlth Indian Agency, B.C.

In this connection I beg to inform the Department that Reverend Dr. Westgate called at the Victoria office on October 17th, instant, at which time our discussion was brief but pleasant. Dr. Westgate referred incidentally to the matter of an issue in March last which arose from the inquiry made by the Inspector of Indian Schools regarding the financing of the Alert Bay School from per capita grants, in which connection the report of the Inspector dated March 14th, last, together with Commissioner Ditchburn's covering letter dated March 15th, 1932, so the Department's reply dated March 23rd, 1932, No. 156-0-6, might be referred to. Dr. Westgate said he did not wish to have the Principal of the Alert Bay School interrogated in regard to the School's financing as the Department was furnished with statements from the Winnipeg office. I replied that I was given to understand that such an arrangement existed, and that Inspector Barry had considered it his duty at the time of his inspection, having no instructions to the contrary, to ask for particulars of school financing as in the case of other schools under his general directions. I told him, further, that I understood that Inspector Barry belonged to his Church, and hoped that the Doctor would be able to find a mutual ground for understanding in his contacts as well as those of his officers with him.

Since Dr. Westgate's visit to Victoria, he has been to Alert Bay, where he met Inspector Barry and had a lengthy discussion with him. I understand from Inspector Barry that during his interview with Dr. Westgate, the latter suggested that the former might make a charge of fraud against the Missionary Society if he felt that there was anything wrong with the Society's method of financing the Alert Bay School, the suggestion having been offered as a result of the Inspector's hesitancy in the matter of supporting the Society's requests for further Departmental grants unless he was satisfied that the per capita grants voted for the School were being used wholly for this purpose, of which he was not then satisfied.

Memorandum:

MR. BUSKARD.

There is available, in the Appropriation for Indian Education for the current fiscal year, an amount of $2,500 to carry out certain work at the Alert Bay Indian Residential School.

Mr. C. C. Perry, Assistant Indian Commissioner, was requested to advise the Department what he considered the most urgent repairs and to give an estimate of the cost. He recommends the raising of two chimneys to an additional height of 15 ft. each, at an estimated cost of $425, also the removing of old sawmill buildings from the school site, at an estimated cost of $500, in connection with an agreement with the Anglican Synod of British Columbia regarding the lease of certain land and a wharf for use in connection with the school. Dear Sir:

Re: Bake Oven at Alert Bay School.

On October 20th, I sent you the following night lettergram from Alert Bay re the above:

"Bake oven at school here practically out of commission through burnt out flues caused by back draft in chimneys which must be heightened next year stop to place in permanently workable condition cost new brick flues and labour estimated at one hundred fifty dollars please wire authority principal Anfield incur this expenditure immediately as smoke from bake oven disfiguring building and spoiling the bread."

No reply was received to this message before I left Alert Bay on October 23rd., but I have just learned from the Principal, in a letter dated November 4th, that the repairs requested were authorized by your Department in a letter dated Ottawa, October 22nd., #156-0-5 and subsequently cancelled in another letter from your Department, dated October 27th, #156-0-5. From copies of the above letters which the Principal has forwarded to me, I am of the opinion that he has misunderstood the same. I understand your letter of October 22nd, as giving the authority requested in my night lettergram of October 20th., to spend approximately $150.00 to have the bake oven repaired immediately, and I understand your letter of October 27th, to mean that you desire the work of having the chimneys raised to be deferred until next year. If my understanding
of these letters is correct, and I think it is, then I beg to state that the question of raising the chimneys next year will be agreeable to our Society. But this work should certainly be undertaken as soon as weather conditions will permit early next summer. I understand that the sum of $2,500 was made available by your Department for this work to be done during the current fiscal year, but for some reason or other, the work was not done, and the school management have been greatly inconvenienced as the result. For one thing, as the Principal could not light a fire in either of the fire-places in his residence, without filling the building with smoke, he was obliged to purchase a gasoline heater to heat his study. Another result of the short chimney from the kitchen is the burning out of the flues in the bake oven and which prompted me to send the telegraphic message quoted above. Nothing but the most urgent need of immediate action, would have prompted me to send that message, as I saw for myself how the bread was being ruined and the walls of the bake oven room being blackened by the clouds of smoke which came from the bake oven itself as soon as the fire was lighted.

On behalf of our Commission, as well as on behalf of the school management, I desire to thank your Department for authorizing the expenditure necessary to place the bake oven in serviceable condition again. I am hopeful that the school management may be able to use it without any further great inconvenience from smoke until the kitchen chimney is heightened by about fifteen feet. I feel well assured that the draught will never be satisfactory either from the bake oven or from the kitchen range until the kitchen chimney is heightened, and this will explain my request that this work be undertaken not later than the early summer of next year.

The Principal informs me that the repairs to the bake oven have already been effected, the necessity of the same being clearly revealed by the fact that every flue in the oven was burned out and the furnace grates and protecting bars were in the same condition. Vouchers for the work done will be forwarded by the Principal to your Department through the local Indian Agent, and I am instructing him to quote your letter of October 2nd, #156-0-5 as his authority for incurring this expenditure.

Dear Sir:

During my recent visit to the Alert Bay School my attention was directed to a number of very urgent needs, only one of which has been specifically brought to the attention of your Department, namely, that of repairs to the bake oven. The other needs have been tabulated in the comprehensive list of requirements sent forward to you on the 7th inst., and most of which our Society hopes you may be able to supply next year. There are some, however, which cannot, with safety, be allowed to stand so long, and I now desire to direct your attention to these, in the hope that it may be possible for your Department, despite existing financial stringency, to provide the same.

(1) A 6 H.P. Petters semi-diesel engine to take the place of the 5 H.P. engine now in use in the pump-house. The 5 H.P. engine is seriously overloaded, and should it break down, the school will be left without a water supply. The estimated cost is $845.00.

(2) A steam drying cabinet for the laundry. This is unquestionably a very urgent need, as clothes can seldom be dried in the open air and must be dried in the main building. The laundry work is so heavy that without better drying equipment the work of the school is disorganized, and the health of the children endangered. I enclose herewith the original of a letter received by the Principal of our Alert Bay School from the Stanley Brock Ltd., giving a quotation on their Canadian Wood Truck Dry Room. You will note that they estimate the cost at approximately $845.00. The Principal states that the sum of $40.00 should be added to this amount for a pulley for the main shaft and for a suitable oak tan belt.
The drying tumbler installed at this school is altogether too small for the amount of work to be done, and to install the second-hand referred to in the latter part of the enclosed letter would not help matters very much.

(3) A wooden arcade with concrete foundations between the main school building and the class-room block. The cost of materials is estimated at £250.00, and if these are delivered at the school, the school management will do the work. When I visited the school last month it rained practically all the time I was there, namely, from Wednesday October 19th, until Sunday, October 23rd. The children were unable to take much exercise in the open air and I thought it a great pity that they should have to walk from the main school building to the class-room block through heavy rain when an arcade could be built at such a moderate cost.

I fully realize, Sir, the difficulty in securing funds to meet requirements such as the above, at the present time, but the need in each case, is so urgent that I feel I would be neglecting my duty if I did not direct your attention to the same. I must ask you, therefore, to give to these needs the prompt and sympathetic consideration which they demand and deserve, and to do your utmost towards supplying the same with a minimum of delay.

Dear Sir:

I have been raining steadily here for approximately seven weeks, and it would be as well to make a report on the condition of the building under such circumstances. An inspection made this afternoon showed the following:

Boys' Basement - The boys have been engaged three times today in mopping up the floor following the serious leak coming through the walls. It would appear that the rain is beating through the bricks higher up in the building, and the water is running down either between the bricks or in the hollow tile and settling on the top of the concrete foundation, and from there running back into the building. We would estimate that water is coming in at this source at approximately a gallon in every three minutes.

Primary Class Room - The rain is beating heavily against the south-east wall of the boys' wing and has worked itself through and is now running down the walls of this classroom, and also on the wall of the store room immediately next to this room.

Children's Dining Room - A similar condition exists here to that in the boys' basement; water is quite obviously getting through the bricks and is running down and on the inside of the dining room on which we spent a great deal of work this year applying three coats of paint.

Electric Light Room - The entire south-east face of the auditorium is soaked through, and water is running into the electric light room from the face wall of the auditorium above. We would estimate that it is running here at about a gallon in two minutes.

No. 8 Dormitory, Girls' Side - The entire south-east face of this dormitory is soaking wet, and is running in streams of water. We held our hand against the plaster and filled it with water whilst we counted fifteen.

No. 7 Dormitory, Girls' Side - This is also running water on the south-east face.

Dear Sir:

With further reference to items submitted for replacement by the Department next year, we wish to draw the attention of the Commission to the condition of the batteries in the electric light room, bearing in mind a statement in the press that the recent fire at the Roman Catholic School in Saskatchewan was caused by short circuiting.

Mr. Cowling our engineer reports, and we have investigated and found his statements correct, that the batteries in the lighting room are worn to such an extent that they are short circuiting within themselves, causing serious leakage of electric current which is impregnating all the metallic surfaces of the engine room, and so much so that on climbing up to fill the water tanks for the main engines one gets a decided shock on handling the valves. These tanks are approximately ten feet from the batteries. What is really happening is that the contact plates within the batteries are fusing causing complete short circuits within the cells.

As the engines operating this plant are gasoline type, it is our opinion that this condition should be brought immediately before the attention of the Department, and to this end we are forwarding today under separate cover quotations on new battery installation.

Memorandum to Mr. Webb:

I visited Alert Bay School on the 4th to 7th of January for the purpose of examining the fire pumping plant of the school. The principal of the school, Mr. F. Anfield, had reported under date of December 16th that on frequent trials the pump would not deliver water in sufficient quantity or at a great enough pressure to cover the school building. He further reported that the difficulty was probably due to stoppage of the intake screen which had frequently become corroded.

Upon examination I found that the cause of the difficulty reported by Mr. Anfield was due to clogging of the pump impeller, several pieces of wood and some small stones having become lodged in the suction side. No damage was caused to the pump however, and it functioned perfectly when cleared. It is probable that this foreign material found its way into the suction pipe when first laid and took some time to work up to the pump. On test two streams of water at 85 lbs. pressure were obtained which were capable of covering the roof of the building with a moderate wind blowing and without making use of the reserve power of the engine.

The suction screen was found to be fairly free having recently been cleaned by the school engineer. It appears that the screen, which is of cast iron and has an aggregate opening area in excess of 200 square inches, grows tubercles over the openings and requires frequent cleaning in order to be kept open. The intake may only be reached during very low tides and in winter time it is exceedingly difficult to reach at all due to the prevailing wind. It would be desirable to have the cast iron screen changed for one of cast bronze which would not grow tubercles and which could readily be cleaned with a wire brush on a pole if found necessary.

From observations I have come to the conclusion that the intake is now in shallower water than when first laid. This appears to be due in part to the shifting of the pipe line about 8 to 10 feet and to the movement of sand. While ordinarily the working of the pump is not affected, during very low tides it is possible that the pump might not operate due to insufficient water over the intake. To overcome the difficulty the pipeline should be extended for about 40 feet.

The cost of the proposed alterations has been estimated at $265.00 and could be most cheaply
carried out in June or July when extremely low tides prevail.

The suggested changes are recommended to maintain the fire preventive service at its greatest efficiency.

In regard to the project of raising chimneys an extra fifteen feet for the Kitchen, laundry and Principal's residence at the Alert Bay Residential School, for which an approximate appropriation of $425.00 has been granted, less the payment of labour and fare of a foreman-carpenter to and from Vancouver who is now employed supervising the demolition of old sawmill buildings, and who was also to have been employed in supervising the erection and demolition of scaffolding around the said chimneys, I beg to state that Mr. F.E. Anfield, the Principal, has now raised the question as to the safety of erecting brick chimneys, and has suggested as an alternative that steel metal jacks be used instead. A copy of an estimate for this latter work is attached.

To my mind Mr. Anfield's idea is quite logical; to erect chimneys single-ply an additional fifteen feet undoubtedly would be dangerous, but the whole proposition needs to be viewed from many different angles. The price quoted on the attached copy of estimate would make this extremely difficult to cover within the appropriation of $425.00 and pay the foreman-carpenter also. There is also the disadvantage of giving the school building a most unsightly appearance; this would also be the case if the original idea was proceeded with and they were raised another fifteen feet with brick, but not so much so as by the use of metal jacks.

However if it is possible to use brick the necessary safeguards will have to be provided to ensure that the three chimneys will not collapse in the course of another three years or so. I would therefore ask if you would be good enough to forward if possible the plans of the Residential School at Lytton, where I understand similar alterations were carried out some years ago. These will enable us to arrive at some decision in a more satisfactory way. So far it has not been possible to carry out Mr. C.C. Perry's suggestion that the bricklayer who has already been selected should examine the work before writing to the Department for authority, owing to this man being sick.
To my mind this work is a totally distinct project to the work at present being undertaken in connection with the demolition of old sawmill buildings in accordance with the Department's agreement with the Columbia Anglican Synod. Some saving could be effected if the services of a foreman-carpenter had been dispensed with. Mr. Dodson, although probably a good carpenter has not proved to be a good foreman, and in any case in the demolition of these old buildings rough carpentry was all that was needed, and many of the Indians are adept at this. What was needed was an experienced foreman who would conscientiously push the work forward and who knew how to handle men. However I have instructed that this work is to be completed in another two days in order to keep somewhere within the bounds of the appropriation of $500.00 which was allowed for this.

Referring again to the matter of erecting chimneys, I would state that if it is decided to use brick, the bricklayer already referred to, who has been previously employed in similar work at this Residential School, would erect and demolish the necessary scaffolding himself with the aid of his son and two Indians. Therefore this work could be delayed until authority is furnished to proceed with it, but at present I am handicapped in not being able to immediately furnish you with the cost of raising these chimneys with brick and having the work done thoroughly with the necessary safeguards provided.

Mr. C.C. Perry also suggests that the Department architect who designed the building would probably advise as to the advantage of either one or the other, either metal work or brick, and also as to the possibility of the appearance of the building itself not being unduly spoiled.

Your obedient servant,

E.G. Newnham
