With reference to the second paragraph of your letter, in which you state that labour returns in triplicate should be kept, I would state that these are being made out in accordance with your instructions and are being forwarded to the Assistant Commissioner in Victoria as instructed.

The work on the demolition of sawmill buildings in accordance with the Department's agreement with the Columbia Anglican Synod or Diocese is not completed, but has been stopped owing to the appropriation for labour of $500.00 having been slightly exceeded. This was referred to in my letter to you dated January 21, and also in my letter to the Assistant Commissioner of January 24th.

Other work provided for was the raising of three chimneys, not two, at the Alert Bay Residential School to an additional height of fifteen feet each. This is held in abeyance owing to the Principal raising the question of safety. This is referred to in my letter to you of January 21 in which I requested that plans of the Residential School at Lytton if possible might be forwarded as similar work was undertaken there some years ago, also that the Department architect might be asked for his opinion on the matter as there are so many phases to be considered.

In regard to the building of a wooden arcade connecting the main school building and the classroom block, material for this has been ordered and is being delivered here and handed over to the Principal immediately after inspection. Every effort will be made to have this completed before the end of the fiscal year.
To complete the work of demolishing the sawmill buildings it will be necessary to employ ten Indians for a further six days at relief rates. For this work there is no white foreman needed, as a reliable Indian can take charge of it. This would consist mostly of tearing down the platform and moving piles which still stand and clearing up the land generally.

The quickest method of raising the three chimneys at the Residential School would be to use the metal jack method as recommended by Mr. Anfield. However only one estimate can be received for this locally, and I think the figure quoted, $300.00, is somewhat excessive. To use brick, three ply, with all the necessary safeguards, would cost more than the balance of the appropriation which has been granted for this, namely $312.00 from the original appropriation for this phase of the work, i.e., $425.00. Payment has been made to the foreman-carpenter at the rate of $6.00 per day for fifteen days and his transportation from Vancouver and return has been paid; this amounted to $113.00.

Kindly inform me if authority can be given to complete the demolition of the Sawmill for which a further sum of $120.00 would be required.

Your obedient servant,

Laundry:

There do not appear to be any proper facilities for the drying of the laundered articles. Some sort of steam drying cabinet is badly required at this school. There is far too much hand ironing. The belts of the various machines are now guarded.

Bakery:

The flues of the oven are worn out. These should be replaced and I would recommend that brick fire box and flues be placed here. The cost, I am informed, would be about $150.00. The school ought to be able to do this repair work out of per capita grants. Bread is made daily except on Saturday and Sunday.

Kitchen:

There is a three oven No. 5 Albion Range here. The top is not in perfect condition. There ought to be another two oven Range placed in this kitchen, as the present accommodation is not sufficient for cooking for 200 children and the staff.

Staff Dining Room:

There is a cement floor 20 feet by 15 feet. Inlaid linoleum should be placed on this floor for sanitary if for no other purposes.

Electric Light:

New batteries which would cost from $400.00 to $450.00 are required. It is possible that new positive plates would be satisfactory for some years.

Pumping Plant:

The present 5 H.P. Peters Engine is far too small for the school. An 8 H.P. Peters Engine is required and the present engine would be kept for instructional purposes.

Buildings:

The old veranda should be removed from the building known previously as the Girls' Home.

An Arcade should be provided between the school and the classrooms in the Girls' Home so that children will be protected going to and from the schoolrooms. This is estimated to cost about $250.00 and could be built by the boys under their Manual Training Instructor.

Sir:

I am enclosing copy of a letter dated March 17 which I have received from Mr. Anfield, Principal of the Alert Bay Residential School.

I do not recommend that this work be done at the present time, in view of the fact that there is a movement on foot locally to have a Government wharf erected for general community use at Alert Bay, which the Residential School authorities would be free to make use of in common with others. I have in mind the fact that these wharves are in constant need of repair and entail great expense and under conditions which prevail here need to be almost re-constructed every two years.

The Sawmill Wharf referred to is now of no further use but present conditions do not warrant any expense being incurred in demolishing it. The small wharf in front of the school is safe to be used for a little while longer until it is known whether the Government is putting in a wharf or not. If this is done, this small wharf in front of the school will be more or less of a luxury unless there are sufficient funds to provide for its upkeep.

I would also recommend that the Agreement between the Synod of Columbia and the Department be cancelled and a new one drawn up if necessary, as owing to change in conditions here several of the clauses would now be considered obsolete.

In any case I suggest that this whole matter be held over until the next fiscal year.

Dear Sir:

Under a lease with the Synod of Columbia, the Department has taken over the control and upkeep of the structure known as the "Sawmill Wharf" for the use of the school. Considerable work was done by a pile-driver on the main wharf shed over a year ago, but the school has been unable to use this wharf for over six months on account of the dangerous condition of the wharf approach, which to make safe at all, would require considerable repairs, consisting of complete repiling and redecking, also considerable number of piles driven under the shore end of the shed. This total cost would be prohibitive under present financial conditions.

On the other hand we consider that the school must have facilities available for its coal and other heavy freight. All the routine freight could be brought in on the local steamers to the Cannery and transported by truck through the new road through the reserve. Our coal, slabs, hay and other freight could be expeditiously handled by scow to the small wharf immediately in front of the school. This structure was built five years ago by the contractor for the main building. It was taken over by the Department for the sum of five hundred dollars, but no repairs have been done since. It now needs repiling and extending at least two bents. A local pile-driver concern has given us a tender for extending this wharf two bents or twenty-eight feet, putting in 20 piles and all necessary timbers and planking and leaving the structure in a first-class condition for $250.00 inclusive.

Memorandum to Mr. Webb:

I visited Alert Bay School on the 4th to 7th of January for the purpose of examining the fire pumping plant of the school. The principal of the school, Mr. F.E. Anfield, had reported under date of December 16th that on frequent trials the pump would not deliver water in sufficient quantity or at a great enough pressure to cover the school building. He further reported that the difficulty was probably due to stoppage of the intake screen which had frequently become corroded.

Upon examination I found that the cause of the difficulty reported by Mr. Anfield was due to clogging of the pump impeller, several pieces of wood and some small stones having become lodged in the suction side. No damage was caused to the pump, however, and it functioned perfectly when cleared. It is probable that this foreign material found its way into the suction pipe when first laid and took some time to work up to the pump. On test two streams of water at 85 lbs. pressure were obtained which were capable of covering the roof of the building with a moderate wind blowing and without making use of the reserve power of the engine.

The suction screen was found to be fairly free having recently been cleaned by the school engineer. It appears that the screen, which is of cast iron and has an aggregate opening area in excess of 200 square inches, grows tubercles over the openings and requires frequent cleaning in order to be kept open. The intake may only be reached during very low tides and in winter time it is exceedingly difficult to reach at all due to the prevailing wind. It would be desirable to have the cast iron screen changed for one of cast bronze which would not grow tubercles and which could readily be cleaned with a wire brush on a pole if found necessary.

From observations I have come to the conclusion that the intake is now in shallower water than when first laid. This appears to be due in part to the shifting of the pipe line about 8 to 10 feet and to the movement of sand. While ordinarily the working of the pump is not affected, during very low tides it is possible that the pump might not operate due to insufficient water over the intake. To overcome the difficulty the pipeline should be extended for about 40 feet.

The cost of the proposed alterations has been estimated at $265.00 and could be most cheaply carried out in June or July when extremely low tides prevail. The suggested changes are recommended to maintain the fire preventive service at its greatest efficiency.

Sir:

Mr. F.E. Anfield, Principal of the Alert Bay Indian Residential School, has furnished me with a copy of a letter which he has addressed to the Secretary, Indian Residential School Commission, M.S.C.C., Winnipeg, embodying a list of requirements which it is considered the Indian Department should be asked to provide for this school during the fiscal year 1934-35. It is possible that these items will be forwarded direct to the Department by Dr. Westgate, but the whole will need careful investigation by myself before I would feel justified in making any report or recommendation, with the exception of Item 6, which covers "Repair to School Wharf".

This wharf is situated right in front of the building, and is not the Sawmill wharf which is a different structure located some distance away from the school. I have examined this school wharf, and find that it is in dangerous condition and if it is to be continued in use, must be repiled at once. I have today had a discussion with Mr. Anfield regarding this matter, and he assures me that the estimate of $250.00 which he asks for will cover expenses of repiling and general renovation to keep this wharf in a state of good repair for the next five years. He also claims that the provision of this wharf is essential, not as a steamer wharf - no steamer could get in there - but as a scow wharf on which to unload fuel, which approximates 210 tons of coal and 200 cords of slabs per year. In its present condition, this wharf could hardly hold one ton of coal.

I also took up with Mr. Anfield the question of the Sawmill wharf which at present the Department is under an Agreement to keep in repair for a number of years. This wharf is of no use whatever either to the Church authorities or to the Department. It could not be repaired for any sum less than one thousand dollars, probably more, and even if it was repaired, it would be more or less of a white elephant. Mr. Anfield was in perfect agreement with me in regard to this, and assured me that if the Department would undertake to repair the school wharf in front of the building for the sum of $250.00, he would, in his capacity as Agent for the Anglican Synod, recommend that the agreement between the Anglican Synod and the Department in connection with the Sawmill wharf be cancelled and declared null and void, so that the Department would be released from all further expenditure in this connection.

It is possible that there might be a balance on hand from the appropriation of two thousand dollars which was provided for recent repair work at the Residential School covering the pipe line intake and the waterproofing of the outer walls, from which the sum of $250.00 could be provided. Mr. Anfield is very anxious that repairs to this school wharf should be proceeded with as early as possible, and has already made tentative arrangements locally for this to be done as soon as the necessary authority is received.
In view of the facts which I have outlined, I would recommend that authority be granted for this item to be dealt with as soon as possible. Mr. Anfield, of course, in his capacity as Agent to the Anglican Synod, is not in a position to anticipate what the decision of the Synod would be in regard to the proposal to cancel the agreement in regard to the Sawmill wharf, but he has assured me that he would forward his very strong recommendations along these lines trusting that as he is the man on the spot, his recommendations would be acted upon.

The other items referred to in the letter quoted above will be attended to by me very thoroughly with a view to my being in a position to render an accurate report to the Department on these matters as soon as my report is called for.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Mr. Perry:

Thank you for your letter of September 20th, with enclosed excerpts from a report of acting Indian Agent at Alert Bay regarding the local wharf situation there.

I have consulted my Committee in charge of this matter and, after careful study of the existing agreement between the Anglican Synod and the Indian Department, it has seemed to us that there is a very considerable equity for our Synod (Indian) account at Alert Bay in the present agreement, as it definitely provides an annual rental to be paid to this account by the Indian Department after a certain number of years' use of the old wharf. I draw attention to this element first of all, because we feel that it should not be lost sight of.

On the other hand, it was understood the school would make the main use of the old wharf, and if the school authorities really prefer the smaller wharf near the school we should not stand in the way of such an arrangement.

It would seem only fair, however, that if the change is to be made the Indian Department should be prepared to make some definite, new undertaking as between the Synod and itself regarding the school wharf.

If you will be prepared, for instance, to recommend that upon release from the former contract the Indian Department would contract to keep the school wharf in condition for a stated number of years, at its own charge, we should be prepared to endorse such a proposal.

I trust the fairness of these suggestions will appeal both to you and the Department and that the matter can be worked out satisfactorily to all concerned.

With kindest regards,

I remain,
Yours faithfully,
"Charles Columbi"

P.S. When taking up the matter further would it be possible to ask the acting Agent at Alert Bay to get a group of Indians to clear away the old wharf if the new contract is agreed upon; to leave it as it is would be dangerous.

Sir,

In compliance with instructions contained in your letter dated September 26th re the above, I have to report that I interviewed Mr. F.E. Anfield, both in his capacity as Agent to the Anglican Synod and as Principal of the Residential School in regard to the two wharves under discussion, and he definitely stated as follows:

(1) That there was an urgent need for the wharf in front of the school to be repaired. Departmental letter No. 156-0-5 dated September 20 has already given authority for this to be done at a maximum figure of $250.00. I have therefore given Mr. Anfield authority to have this work proceeded with immediately under local arrangements stressing the fact that under no circumstances must the sum of $250.00 be exceeded.

(2) In consideration of the foregoing, he had recommended to the Anglican Synod at Victoria that the Agreement dated June 1st, 1931, whereby a piece of land forming a portion of Section 4, Cormorant Island, Rupert District, was leased by the Bynod to the Department of Indian Affairs at a nominal rental, be cancelled.

In connection with No.1, I would state that the school wharf can be considered to be on the premises of the Residential School, therefore the Anglican Synod office at Victoria actually has nothing to do with it. What new undertaking which may be considered necessary - if any - would be dealt with by the Anglican Indian Residential School Commission at Winnipeg.

I attach a rough plan of the land referred to in No.2 by which it will be seen that the Department is saddled with unnecessary responsibility so long as the aforesaid Lease is in effect. On the left side of the public highway proceeding north is the site of the old sawmill now demolished. The sawmill wharf - now under discussion - is shown in red. On the right of the public highway are a number of buildings occupied by white persons who pay rent to the Synod. This site adjoins the Industrial School Reserve, but is not part of it, and I do not see any useful purpose either to the Church or the Department, by the aforesaid lease remaining in effect, especially in view of changing conditions.

In regard to paragraph 4 of the letter dated September 23rd addressed to you by the Bishop of Columbia, I would state that there is no need for any new undertaking between the Synod and the Department in regard to the school wharf, as this is already covered by the Agreement with the Anglican Indian Residential School Commission.
In the event of this aforesaid lease being cancelled it would seem that the Department would be under a final obligation to demolish the sawmill wharf which is now in a dilapidated condition - unless the Synod wished otherwise - after which there would be no further occasion for the expenditure of public funds by the Department in connection with this site which is actually private property and of no benefit to the Indians.

In view of the fact that the Anglican Church has for the past nine years maintained a self-supporting Parish at Alert Bay as distinct from an Indian Mission, and another denomination is now engaged in mission work here, being firmly established, the religious persuasions of Indians of course not being subject to official interference, it would seem that the only official contact which the Department need maintain with the Anglican Church at Alert Bay, is in connection with St. Michael's Indian Residential School, which is administered by the Anglican Indian Residential School Commission at Winnipeg.

Dear Sir:

re: Inspection of Boilers and Machinery,
Indian Residential School, Alert Bay, B.C.

On August 2nd, 1933, I inspected the mechanical equipment of this school, which consists of,

Two 54" x 90" x 77" Inglis Supreme Boilers, containing 82 - 2 3/4" tubes, Nos. 44261 B.C. and 44262 B.C., rated at 45.1 H.P. each, built in 1929, making them now four years old. Longitudinal joint welded.

One Gurney boiler, 5 section, 53" x 72" x 57", No. 44557 B.C., rated at 31 H.P., built in 1912, making it now 21 years old.

One Vertical Tubular boiler 26" Diameter, 48" high, containing 36 - 2" x 26" tubes, No. 44325 B.C., rated at 4 H.P. Longitudinal joint double rivetted lap, built in 1929, making it now 4 years old.

One 12 H.P. Lister Gasoline Engine direct connected to a 7.5 K.W. Generator.

One 6 1/2 H.P. Lister Gasoline Engine direct connected to a 3.5 K.W. Generator.

One 75 H.P. Continental Gasoline Engine direct connected to a Rotary Pump.

One 5 H.P. Petteer Semi Diesel, driving by belt a Ponoma deep well pump.

Boiler No. 44261 B.C.

I gave this boiler a careful hammer test and found all stays, plates and seams in good condition.

I then gave it a Hydrostatic Test of 50 Lb. per square inch and found it perfectly tight.

I then made an internal inspection and found it in fair condition. There had been some electrolysis action on the front plates which had caused a slight wearing away, and at some time pitting had occurred, but this appears to have stopped but will need watching so that it does not occur again.
Boiler No. 44261 B.C. Continued.

I would suggest that zinc plates 4" x 8" x 1" be suspended in the water space of this boiler and the present treatment of soda and lime be continued, using a solution of 1/2 lb. sal soda to 2 gallons clear lime water, using about 1 quart of this solution to each boiler per month, and blowing down one inch of water per week.

The test gauges, water gauges, blowdown cocks and pipes are in good condition. The safety valve works freely and blows off at 15 lb. pressure. The steam gauge is correct.

Boiler No. 44262 B.C.

This boiler is in a similar condition to 44261 B.C. The same treatment must be observed.

The water gauge is to be repacked.

The fusible plugs in both boilers are to be renewed.

I have issued a certificate for both boilers allowing a steam pressure of 15 lb. and condition good.

Boiler No. 44325 B.C.

I gave this boiler a careful inspection and found that it was in poor condition. This boiler has the appearance of having been badly used. It is much too small for the work required and steam has been raised too quickly causing a breakdown of the tubes.

Internally the plates and furnace crown are in fair condition. There is evidence of considerable pitting having taken place but in many cases it has stopped.

I would recommend that the same feed water treatment be continued but in addition when not in use that it be emptied and left dry and air be allowed to circulate through it.

I could not complete the Hydrostatic Test on account of several of the tubes leaking on the top tube sheet. These will need re-expanding. After the next season this boiler must be retubed. I would recommend that a larger boiler be installed at that time, as even if this boiler is retubed, on account of the forcing required to do the required work it would only last a short time, as it will take a boiler of approximately 15 H.P. to be economical.

The water gauge must be overhauled, cleaned and made to work freely.

The test and blow off cocks are in good condition.

The safety valve works freely by hand. The steam gauge is 1 lb. light. The fusible plug must be renewed.

I have issued a certificate allowing a steam pressure of 125 lb. and condition poor.
Boiler No. 44557 B.C.

I gave this boiler a careful inspection and found it in good condition. Traces of salt were showing which was caused by the feed water being temporarily connected to the same main which is used for the salt water fire protection system. This is now being changed and a separate main for each service installed.

The internal condition of this boiler is also good. I gave it a Hydrostatic test of 30 Lb. and found it perfectly tight.

The water gauge is to be changed on the water column so that it is visible from the front of the boiler, as where it is now placed it is impossible to see it unless you go around to the boiler side.

The test cocks should be placed at the side of the water column and the steam gauge placed on the top of the column where it can get dry steam.

The Main stop valve and blowdown cock are in good condition. The steam gauge is correct. The fusible plug is to be renewed.

I have issued a certificate allowing a steam pressure of 5 Lb. and condition good.

Laundry.

Consists of a double washing machine, one 26" Hydro Extractor, one steam drying machine. They all appear to be in good condition. A pipe guard should be placed across the sides to prevent the back of these machines where the belts and belt pulleys are, being used as a passage.

Lighting Plant.

The 12 H.P. and 6 1/2 H.P. Lister Engines and Generators have been overhauled and are in good condition.

Tire Service.

The Pump and engine is also overhauled and is in good condition.

Domestic Water Service.

This is also in good condition.

Dear Sir:

The need of a larger engine for our domestic water supply has been placed before you in previous correspondence and an estimate of at least $800.00 for an engine included in the requirements for this school for the fiscal year 1934-5. It is doubtful, however, if the present plant will continue to give the required service until that time and the following proposition is placed before you for consideration.

The B.C. Packers Ltd. operating the local cannery took out this year, a 12 H.P. Petters semi-deisol engine and replaced it with one of 25 H.P. capacity.

The presumed value of the 12 H.P. engine removed was $200 and they are willing to make a straight trade for our engine of 5 H.P. capacity for which they have a specific use next year. The big engine has been carefully surveyed and will cost $250 in repairs for which sum the engine will be as good as new. It requires a new cylinder block, piston and other minor parts following installation. The engine should be good for at least ten years service. Whilst this plant is slightly larger than that needed for our pumping equipment, it would have a double use in that any time we could add to it an emergency dynamo which, in the event of an accident to our lighting plant, would provide the institution with D.C. power during any period of protracted repairs. It is fully realized that conditions are difficult and that money available for anything, even of an emergency nature, is very limited. I have, however, asked the local manager to hold this engine for us until the first of January next year and I am convinced, should it be possible to raise the sum of $250.00, that the investment made would be a good one. It might also be possible, should the Commission see its way clear to financing this work under next years budget, that the Department could be induced to refund the amount expended when it is shown that a far larger sum had been saved by the acting taken.

Yours very sincerely,

"F. Earl Anfield"

In February, 1933, arrangements were made to raise the chimneys for the kitchen, the laundry and the Principal's residence at the Alert Bay Indian Residential School. The contract was placed, by Acting Agent Newnham, with the General Repair Shop, Alert Bay, B.C., for the sum of $300.

Dear Sir:

On September 23rd last, Mr. Principal Anfield of our Alert Bay School, reporting damage to the school boat "St. Michael", wrote, in part, as follows:

"I have to report damage to the school boat "St. Michael" following a storm of almost cyclonic proportions this week. It had been blowing southeast for three days and then without warning the wind swung round and one of the very rare but dreaded "Mamakish Winds" came over and in five minutes our boat, along with five others anchored out, had dragged anchorings and were literally picked up and thrown on the beach. After a terrific fight in which our senior boys and some Indians from the village worked up to their necks in the water, all these boats were secured and lashed down to the beach until the storm blew out. The "St. Michael" had its upper works badly stove in but at the time of writing, complete repairs have been effected and two holes in the hull plugged and caulked. I was compelled to wire for 100 ft. chain and put a heavy "deadman" down, so that now the boat is safe, no matter what blows. We will not have to depend on the anchor, which will hardly hold any boat in such a storm as we had this week. Every telephone pole along the school frontage was snapped and on the ground, and considerable other damage done to other parts of Alert Bay."

The "complete repairs" mentioned in his letter were subsequently found to be ineffective, and in another letter from the Principal, dated December 10th., enclosing an itemized statement of the cost of the repairs, he writes further as follows:
"It will be noticed that the total is considerably in excess of the first estimate, but when the work started it was found the damage sustained was such that it was necessary to remove the entire superstructure to get at the cause. The main stern had been broken in the storm and all the seams seriously sprung, so much so that the boat more than half filled with water every 24 hours. All the cabin and housing had been twisted out of line and required rebuilding and it was necessary to take out and replace all the caulking. A first class job has been done and the boat is now good for many years of work."

As the total cost of the repairs amounts to £65.75, and constitutes an expenditure which could not possibly be foreseen, it appears to our Commission that the same should be met partly by your Department, and partly by them, and I am writing for the specific purpose of asking if your Department will meet at least £50. of the total amount, on the understanding that our Commission will provide the balance, namely, £15.75.

Itemized statements of the total cost, in triplicate, are enclosed herewith, and our Commission will be obliged if you can furnish them with your reply at an early date, as their books for the year will close promptly on the 31st inst.

Wishing you the compliments of the season.

I remain, Sir,

Memorandum to Mr. Webb:

The following work was carried out at Alert Bay School during the months of July and August last, at a total outlay of $1820.96.

Waterproofing School.

All faces of the school building and residence facing south and east were given two coats of waterproofing material. In all approximately 14,000 square-feet of surface was treated. The unit cost of the work was approximately 10¢ per square foot, the total cost of the work was $1481.80, expended as follows.

| Material etc. | $887.83 |
|---------------|---------|
| Labour        | 502.92  |
| Supervision etc. | 92.09   |

$ 1481.80

The process of waterproofing consisted of the application of "Minwax" waterproofing materials carried out in the following order.

First, The application of one coat, to the point of saturation, on all exposed faces, south and east.

Second, The caulking of all windows, doorways, coping stone and roof flashings and the pointing of brickwork where necessary.

Third, A second application of waterproofing on brickwork only, after completion of caulking.

Prior to first application of waterproofing the surface was thoroughly cleaned by wire brush and all loose material removed. Where necessary acid was used for removal of efflorescence.

Conditions were ideal for the first application but some difficulty was experienced in making the second application on the east face owing to cool mornings and to the fact that this face of the building was in shadow during the afternoon.

The brickwork on the east end of the building above the residence was in very bad condition as was also brickwork on a part of the residence, the joints being incompletely filled with mortar. The coping stone also proved to have unfilled or loose joints.

Fire Pump System

An extension was effected to the suction line of the fire pump. The cost of this work was
$286.18. In addition the pump was overhauled and a new shaft and bearings provided at a total cost of $52.98.

The work carried out consisted of the extension of the pump suction line a distance of 48 feet and provision of a bronze intake screen. The full length of the suction line was re-calked and the pumping station generally overhauled and placed in condition to operate effectively.

W.C. Warren
Asst. Hydraulic Engineer.

I now desire to say that I have carefully perused the agreement above referred to dated June 1st, 1931, in the light of the three proposals which you have verbally made to me in behalf of the Anglican Synod of the Diocese of British Columbia. I have also examined our files in this connection.

Your letter of November 4th, 1933, and the letter of His Lordship Bishop Schofield, dated September 23rd, 1933, have been given especial consideration in this connection, and these letters will be referred to hereinafter. (1) It is presumed that the late Commissioner who assisted in drawing up the agreement dated June 1st, 1931, believed that the Anglican Synod of the Diocese of British Columbia had title to the property embraced in the lease, as there is nothing on file to the contrary. Upon review of the correspondence in connection with this matter, it is noted, as stated in official letter of October 19th, last, the wharf in question is not of further use for departmental or school purposes and that it also is in need of considerable repair. At the time the new school building was erected at Alert Bay, it was understood that the school would make the main use of this wharf, but, since that time, it has been found that the smaller wharf near the school would be sufficient to serve their purposes.

It is understood that Bishop Schofield would consent to cancellation of the lease of the "Sawmill Wharf" on the understanding that the Department would agree to keep the small wharf which is near the school in good condition. As stated in official letter to you of October 19th, last, the Department would be prepared to give favourable consideration to keeping in repair the small wharf near the school in so far as funds permit from time to time.

The Department is unable to consider the request of the Solicitor for the Diocese, made in an interview you had with him, that the sum of $1,000 be paid the Anglican Synod to terminate the lease of the sawmill wharf. I would point out that this wharf was leased at

Dear Mr. Perry:

Thank you for your letter of September 20th, with enclosed excerpts from a report of acting Indian Agent at Alert Bay regarding the local wharf situation there.

I have consulted my Committee in charge of this matter and, after careful study of the existing agreement between the Anglican Synod and the Indian Department, it has seemed to us that there is a very considerable equity for our Synod Indian account at Alert Bay in the present agreement, as it definitely calls for an annual rental to be paid to this account by the Indian Department after a certain number of years' use of the old wharf. I draw attention to this element first of all, because we feel that it should not be lost sight of.

On the other hand, it was understood the School would make the main use of the old wharf, and if the School authorities really prefer the smaller wharf near the School we should not stand in the way of such an arrangement.

It would seem only fair, however, that if the change is to be made the Indian Department should be prepared to make some definite, new undertaking as between the Synod and itself regarding the School wharf.

If you will be prepared, for instance to recommend that upon release from the former Contract the Indian Department would contract to keep the School wharf in condition for a stated number of years, at its own charge, we should be prepared to endorse such a proposal.

His Lordship, Bishop Schofield, has conferred with us on your correspondence with him concerning:

(1) The establishment of the wharf fronting on the Indian Industrial School at Alert Bay;

There is another consideration to which we would invite your attention. The mill site wharf has been in existence for a great number of years, and the title of the Anglican Synod to the site has been recognized. It has been the policy of the Church authorities to maintain and protect its title to this site by, amongst other things, seeing that the existence of the wharf is preserved. If the wharf is now to be demolished, we think that your Department may be able to assist the Church authorities, namely, the Anglican Synod, to procure from the Provincial Government, a recognition of its rights to this site, which are of value to the Church in connection with its work amongst the Indians at Alert Bay.

The writer will be pleased to confer with you on these questions at your convenience. We are now writing to specify them so that you may have an opportunity of considering them.

Sir:

Recently it has been brought to my attention the necessity of caring for perishable food at the Residential School here in Alert Bay, and to check up on this I have made several trips to the school in order that I could get first-hand knowledge of the whole situation.

I find the School is not provided with any means of taking care of this, and considerable difficulty is being experienced especially during the summer months. The school now have quite a large dairy, and as practically all their meat, butter, eggs, etc., are purchased in Vancouver and the boat service irregular, it is necessary that they order in large quantities to carry them over. It does appear that some form of refrigeration is necessary not only from a financial point of view but from a health viewpoint as well.

The necessity of economizing is fully realized at the present time, and with this in view we have endeavoured to find a means of obtaining satisfactory equipment to serve the purpose at the lowest possible cost. If the Department would consider the purchase of this equipment at the present time, the school are prepared to install the Walk-In-Cooler themselves and by doing this the whole equipment complete, fully installed, could be purchased for the sum of $690.00. This seems to me a very reasonable figure, and I would request that the Department grant us authority to have this refrigerating plant installed during the summer holidays. The School in order to assist the Department have agreed to do all the labour in connection with the installation, in the hopes that the Department will give favourable consideration to their request. This would mean a saving of approximately $265.00.

I might add this plant could be operated from the present electrical system with no difficulty whatever. I have gone to the trouble of having an expert get all the measurements and thoroughly go into it, and no difficulty will be experienced in installing this plant. In the ordinary course the Department would ask for tenders, but in this case a special price has been offered by Marshall-Wells when the school is prepared to do the work themselves.

I would appreciate very much if the Department would give this matter their serious consideration and if possible grant authority for this work to be undertaken. I assure you it is only after my fullest investigation of conditions at the school that I have decided to place the matter before you, and recommend that the installation of this equipment be carried out.

Your obedient servant,

(M.S. Todd)
Indian Agent

Sir:

As stated in my Monthly Report for April, I wish to make certain observations in reference to the St. Michael's Residential School during the time in which I accompanied Capt. G.H. Barry, Inspector of Schools, on his inspection.

The fire drill which was carried out was very good indeed. I timed the children leaving the building after the fire alarm was given and they were all out in less than two minutes, and the roll calls made and reported in four minutes. I might add the children were in bed when the fire alarm was given; they dressed sufficiently to withstand the cold and came out in a very orderly manner. I noticed only one thing which should be changed. The fire escapes are not sufficient as the four dormitories all lead into one general fire escape and some confusion was noticed at this point. The hydrants were operated, and I found them in first-class working order. There appeared to be sufficient pressure to force the water high enough to reach any portion of the building. The fire-fighting squad of the older boys of the school appeared to be well drilled and knew their work.

In making an inspection of the building itself I noticed one spot where the walls leaked, but I understand this is being repaired.

I also noticed in No. 2 dormitory there were some double beds, which I do not believe the Department approve of. It was brought to my notice there are no fire gongs on the top floor of the girls' dormitory nor in the laundry in the rear of the building. This I feel is not in line with Departmental regulations, and I would recommend that a fire gong be placed in each of these sections of the building.

It was pointed out that a new stove was necessary for the Dispensary. This I believe will be dealt with in Capt. Barry's report, and I concur in this.

In the old school, now used as a classroom block, I noticed the light was very poor in one room, and while I feel this should eventually be attended to, it is not an immediate necessity and I would not recommend that anything be done with this at present. I checked over the amount of lumber on hand for the annual training of the boys, and the amount which was agreed upon by Capt. Barry and Mr. Anfield I would suggest would be satisfactory for this year's requirements. The matter of fruit trees was taken up and as they have a portion of their orchard as yet not planted, a requisition is being forwarded to complete their orchard, and I would recommend that the Department have these trees sent to them in due course.

Your obedient servant,

I have the honor to acknowledge receipt of Departmental wire dated March 12th, ultimo, reading as follows:

"Please purchase eight horse power Petters semi diesel engine and ship same to Alert Bay Residential School. Stop. Prices should be obtained from firms on approved list. Stop. Forward account as soon as possible."

Upon calling for tenders, it was found that the engine required could only be obtained from one firm—the Canadian Fairbanks-Morse Company Ltd., of Victoria and Vancouver. It was discovered, however, that the 8 H.P. Petters engine is no longer made, but that the Petters 7 H.P. had been designed by the manufacturers to take its place. I therefore wired the Principal, Mr. Anfield, on March 20th, as follows:

"Would seven H.P. Petter engine be suitable your school pumping plant as eight H.P. no longer made (Stop) Next size twelve H.P. Advise by wire."

I received reply as follows:

"Seven HP automatic Petter OK for school pumping plant provided drive pulley twenty four inches diameter by eight inches face be placed on engine. Stop. Equipment should include twenty four feet two ply eight inch oak tan belt and large water tank."

With the exception of the belting which was not authorized the changes desired were made and these will explain the corresponding changes in the account for $596.59 which is herewith submitted attached to Voucher No. 136A, duly certified for payment together with an abstract of tender. It will be noted that the Petters engine was quoted f.o.b. Vancouver, so that the matter of freight may have to be adjusted unless the Principal agrees to pay it. I say the goods have been acknowledged by Mr. Anfield and the question of freight charges have not been mentioned. I have just telephoned the company who state they presume it has been paid by the Principal as it was sent collect. Mr. Principal Anfield may not ask the Department to pay the freight, but if he does, the matter could then be dealt with.

I am sending the account for the engine now as the Department has asked for it as early as possible.

Sir:

The Department is in receipt of the report of the Engineer, Department of Public Works, Victoria, on his inspection, in July, last, of the boilers and machinery at the Alert Bay Indian Residential School. He reports as follows:

Boiler No. 44325 - "I gave this boiler a careful internal and external inspection and found that its condition was very poor. It has been pitting for some time, and, although the pitting has stopped, the damage to the plates has been done, and, after the coming season, it must be taken out and another installed." The longitudinal seam was found to be slightly leaking.

Boiler No. 44557 - Found in first-class condition. The firebars are in need of repairs.

Boiler No. 44261 - In good condition. There was quite a lot of sediment in the wet legs, which must be all cleaned out, and care should be taken to keep these clean and free from sediment. The steam gauge is slightly light. The fusible plug must be renewed.

Boiler No. 44262 - The condition of this boiler was fairly good. The Engineer recommends that the same feed water treatment must be continued and that there must be more water blown off to prevent the collection of sediment.

The attention of the Engineer was drawn to the hot water storage tank. This tank is 12 ft. long and 3 ft. 6 in. in diameter and is suspended close to the roof of the boiler room in such a manner that it is very difficult to get at it. It was leaking at the longitudinal joint on the top. The water pressure being quite low, a screwed plug can be inserted if the leak gets worse. Both the inlet and outlet pipes are badly corroded and must be renewed. While this is being done, the tank can be advantageously lowered, at least 6 ft., so that the attendant can get around it to make repairs, if necessary. This is a small matter and can be done by the staff.

I would request that you draw to the attention of the Principal the recommendations of the Engineer regarding the boilers and hot water storage tank. He should arrange to have the suggestions carried out. The Department understands that the certificates of inspection of the various boilers have been forwarded to the Principal. He should see that these certificates are posted in a prominent place in the boiler-room.

Your obedient servant,

K. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

August 29th, 1934.

Dear Sir:

Re: Inspection of Boilers and Machinery,
Indian Residential School, Alert Bay, B.C.

BOILER No. 44325.

I beg to report that on July 25th I gave this boiler a careful internal and external inspection and found that its condition was very poor. It has been pitting for some time and although the pitting has stopped the damage to the plates has been done and now after the coming season must be taken out and another installed. In my last report I stated that it had been badly used and was much too small.

I gave it a Hydrostatic test of 190 lbs. and found the Longitudinal seam slightly leaking, which from the internal conditions proves that it is past its usefulness and should be replaced. When this is done a boiler having submerged tubes should be considered as the vertical type boiler is not suited for the class of work it has to perform.

The safety valves are in good condition and are set to blow off at 125 lbs.

I have issued a certificate for this season allowing a steam pressure of 125 lbs. and condition poor.

BOILER No. 44557.

On the same date I gave this boiler a careful inspection and found it in first class condition. I then gave it a Hydrostatic test of 15 lbs. and found it perfectly tight. All the recommendations in my last report have been carried out. I set the safety valves to blow off at 5 lbs. water pressure. The firebars are in need of repairs. The steam gauge is correct.

I have issued a certificate allowing a steam pressure of 5 lbs. and condition good.

BOILER No. 44261.

On the same date I gave this boiler a careful internal and external inspection and found that all stays, crowns, plates and welded seams were in good condition. I then gave it a Hydrostatic test of 30 lbs. and found it quite tight.
There was quite a lot of sediment in the wet legs which must be all bled out and every care taken to keep these clean and free from sediment. The steam gauge is slightly light. I set the safety valves to blow off at 15 lbs. water pressure. The fusible plug must be renewed.

I have issued a certificate allowing a steam pressure of 15 lbs. and condition good.

**BOILER No. 44262.**

On the same date I inspected this boiler in a similar manner and found its condition similar to No. 44261, and have issued a certificate allowing a steam pressure of 15 lbs. and condition good.

The same feed water treatment must be continued but there must be more water blown off to prevent the collection of sediment.

While I was there my attention was drawn to the Hot Water Storage Tank. This tank is 12 feet long and 3'6" in diameter and is suspended close to the roof of the boilerroom in such a manner that it is very difficult to get at it. It is leaking at the longitudinal joint on the top. The water pressure being quite low a screwed plug can be inserted if the leak gets worse. Both the inlet and outlet pipes are badly corroded and must be renewed. While this is being done the tank can be advantageously lowered at least 6 feet where the attendant can get around it to make repairs if necessary. This is a small matter and can be done by the Staff.

**AUXILIARY MACHINERY.**

The auxiliary machinery is in a very good condition and well kept. All the bearings are quite tight no play being visible.

All the recommendation guards in regard to my last report have been carried out and the Laundry Machinery is now properly protected.

Yours respectfully,

T. J. Arnall,
Engineer.

Winnipeg, Manitoba.

Dear Sir:

In spite of all the work done here last year, I have to report that in a very heavy rain today, water has poured into the building from many points.

There is a lot of water in both basements, the dining room and kitchen, laundry and engine rooms. Rain is also pouring through the front wall into the infirmary and many of the window frames in the dormitories are letting water through in considerable quantities.

The situation is well in hand and we are not fearful of any emergency though the main ditches are running at full capacity. Every precaution is being taken to keep all drains clear and all roof traps have been inspected personally today.

My object in writing is to suggest that the Department be notified of this condition as these inroads of water in the building cannot but have a very bad effect on the structure; creating a situation that in time is going to cost considerable money to correct; and for which the school management through the Commission can in no way be held responsible.

The Local Indian Agent is away at the time of writing or I would have asked him to come and see the situation for himself.

Yours very truly,

(Sgd) F. Earl Anfield.
Principal

I am sorry to have to report we are again having trouble with our drainage system at the residential school here. Last evening I was called to the school by the principal, Mr. Anfield, to look over the situation, and I found the field or flat at the rear of the school which has two cement drains leading from it to the sea were not large enough to take away the flood waters which had backed up on the farm. Mr. Anfield also showed me how the school building itself was badly leaking. It appears the water is getting in through the brick wall penetrating through to the plaster; this was noticeable in the upper dormitories as well as in the basement of the school.

As it was of such a serious nature, I wired Mr. C.C. Perry, Assistant Commissioner at Victoria and suggested that an engineer be sent to Alert Bay to deal with the situation and make a report to the Department. I am under the opinion unless something is done to stop this leakage the Department will have a tremendous bill on their hands as the plaster no doubt will come off the wall and possibly the foundations of the school be undermined. Today the weather has cleared somewhat and the situation may be eased up a little; however we are constantly watching it and if necessary will have to dig another ditch alongside one of the present drains.

Sir:

Re: Alert Bay Indian Residential School

On February 26th last you were advised of an inspection by Mr. W.C Warren of damage to the walls of the above school caused by seepage through them during the early winter months.

It appeared from Mr. Warren's inspection that the waterproofing which was done to the building in the summer of 1933 had not been a success and the Vancouver agent of the Minwax Company, from whom waterproof material had been purchased, was communicated with under date of February 20th. In this letter he outlined how the waterproofing of the building had been carried out under the Minwax Company's instructions and specifications and under the most favourable weather conditions, and in view of the fact that the desired results had not been obtained we suggested that the company should assume responsibility to making the walls in question thoroughly waterproof. We have had some correspondence with the Canadian Minwax Company Ltd., 1176 Benoit St., Montreal, Quebec and up to the present no definite settlement of the question has been reached.

A copy of our most recent letter of May 10th to the Canadian Minwax Company is enclosed, from which you will note we have put the matter up to them as to whether they are going to undertake the satisfactory waterproofing of the building or not. It seems to me the responsibility is theirs.

I am enclosing copy of Mr. Warren's memorandum of March 22nd, reporting the result of his inspection. I think the Department of Indian Affairs would be well advised to immediately have a row of Lombardy poplars planted along the south and west sides of the building to act as a windbreak against the driving rain which occurs each winter, and at the same time a row of fir should be planted which, when grown, will make a much more permanent wind break.

Your obedient servant,

Memorandum to Mr. Webb

Re: Alert Bay School

I made an inspection of the above school building on the 9th of February and found that the inside walls of the school and residence on the sides facing south and east showed unmistakable signs of dampness penetrating through the walls.

I was informed by the principal of the school that the amount of moisture had been very great since the exceptional storm of the week of January 20th to 26th and that the school people had been employed more or less constantly during the latter part of that week and the following week in drying out the floors and walls of the building. There was, however, at the time of my visit, sufficient evidence of moisture penetration on the walls to satisfy me that the seepage had occurred to a considerable extent.

Examination of the outside walls of the building did not disclose any breaking down of mortar or any weakness in the wall and the waterproofing material which had been applied two years previously did not appear to have been washed out by rains. The inside walls of the building are commencing to show signs of breaking down. The metal lath on the exposed walls apparently is rusting away as the plaster is very weak in places.

It would appear that the Minwax waterproofing material applied in 1933 has not been effective. As to the reason why this material has been non-effective I am not prepared to express an opinion. I would suggest, however, that it would be desirable during the coming summer to make some further tests on the building with the same material and with other types of waterproofing before adopting any other expedient.

It would be desirable in my opinion, to plant a hedge of trees along the south and west sides of the building in order to provide a wind-break and to minimize the effect of the driving rains on the exposed faces of the building. The Lombardy poplar would be suitable for this purpose as it grows very fast and to a desirable height. Its life, however, short and it should only be employed until such time as a more lasting tree, such as the fir, can be grown to the necessary height.

W.J. Warren
Asst. Hydraulic Engineer
May 10, 1935.

Sir,

Replying to your letter No. 156-0-5 dated May 28th regarding the installation of a cold storage plant in St. Michael's Residential School, Alert Bay, I beg to advise I have taken this matter up with the Principal who arranged to have an expert of the firm of Marshall-Wells B.C. Ltd., Vancouver, B.C. come to Alert Bay and take measurements, etc., and after thoroughly discussing the proposed amended plan with the Principal and myself he has submitted the enclosed Tender in the full price of $825.00 with one year's full service guarantee. In addition, $75.00 would be necessary to provide lumber and material to erect a small building to house the compressor and engine. The school have agreed to supply all the labour in connection with this.

It might be as well to state the original tender submitted to the Department was from Marshall-Wells B.C. Ltd. in which they agreed to install the equipment for the amount of $690.00 but this was intended to operate from the lighting plant. When it was discovered the Department regulations would not permit this, it was necessary to ask for an amended tender and make certain alterations for the new equipment. This has now been worked out and as stated before, it can be installed for the sum of $825.00 with an additional sum of $75.00 required for the erection of a small building, making a total cost of $900.00.

As we are anxious to get the Department's decision as quickly as possible in order that we may proceed with the installation we are trying to give you all the particulars. When we found it necessary to make the change and work out a new plan we decided we would use a storeroom in the school adjacent to the boiler room and by doing this we could have considerably more storage capacity for general food stuffs.

It is noted in your letter an item of $1300.00 was included in our Estimates for the supplying of laundry equipment. Mr. Anfield now advises the Commission are going to purchase part of the laundry equipment which we had previously asked for, and therefore I feel in view of this and the urgent need of the cold storage equipment, the Department should supply this refrigeration plant, and I strongly recommend that the Department approve of the enclosed Kelvinator Refrigeration System submitted in the enclosed Tender. If the Department will approve, I would recommend that they request either this office or our Assistant Commissioner at Victoria to arrange for the purchase of same and have the plant shipped direct to St. Michael's School, Alert Bay. Would you kindly advise us at your earliest convenience as we are anxious to proceed with the installation during the summer months.

Sir,

Replying to your letter No. 156-0-5 regarding the installation of a new boiler at St. Michael's Indian Residential School, Alert Bay. I beg to advise Dr. T.B.R. Westgate of the Indian Residential School Commission visited me yesterday accompanied by Mr. Anfield, the Principal, and we thoroughly discussed what was best to do in our difficulty.

We all agreed the boiler and steam ironer were much more important and necessary at the present time than the refrigeration plant. The boiler and ironer are more or less hooked up together and one cannot function properly without the other. At present the boiler is too small and is being used far beyond its capacity, and it being in poor condition we are afraid of an accident. This year there are a great number of primary grades and it is not possible for the older girls to do all the work necessary. After considering our position, Dr. Westgate decided to wire the Department as follows:

"After consultation Indian Agent Todd and Principal Anfield strongly recommend immediate installation steam ironer and high pressure boiler Alert Bay School as suggested in Mr. Todd's letter to you August 20th last. Season now so far advanced refrigeration plant mentioned in your letter August 29th to Mr. Todd may be held over until next year. School management will install machinery and our Society will meet all cost beyond fifteen Hundred Dollars. As School now open with capacity enrollment, kindly wire instructions Indian Agent Todd."

"T.B.R. Westgate"

I feel we have taken the only course open, and therefore would recommend to the Department they arrange for the installation of a suitable boiler as well as a steam ironer to take care of the work. This is urgent, and I would kindly ask the Department's immediate consideration.

Your obedient servant,

(M.S. Todd)

Sir,

Recently the Dominion Government Boiler Inspector, Mr. T.J. Arnall, made his annual inspection at St. Michael's Residential School, Alert Bay, and again informed me boiler No. 44325 which he had reported unfavourably on last year, must be replaced. In his last report Mr. Arnall stated as follows:

Boiler No. 44325: "I gave this boiler a careful internal and external inspection, and found that its condition was very poor. It has been pitting for some time and although the pitting has stopped, the damage to the plates has been done. After the coming season it must be taken out and another installed. The longitudinal seam was found to be slightly leaking."

In the Department's letter of May 28th, No. 156-0-5, they stated an item of $1300.00 had been provided for the supplying of laundry equipment for the Alert Bay Residential School this year. In my letter to the Department dated June 15th it was recommended that a refrigerator plant be installed, but it is now realized with the necessary expenditure for a new boiler this amount of $1300.00 will not cover both items.

The matter was thoroughly discussed with Mr. Anfield, and he decided, in view of the lateness of the season, he would manage without the refrigerator plant, and asked me to write the Department requesting that the money originally intended for this purchase be used for the purchase of a boiler and laundry equipment, which is urgently required. I am enclosing an illustration of the type of Steam Ironer requested by Mr. Anfield, and I would therefore now recommend that the refrigerator plant be left in abeyance and that the $1300.00 approved for expenditure at the school this year be used to purchase the new boiler and Steam Ironer.

The boiler recommended by Mr. Arnall is as follows:
1 Vertical Boiler, size 38" x 90", 142 square feet heating surface, 14.2 H.P., 125 pounds working pressure, at an approximate cost of $600.00.

The Steam Ironer required, shown in the enclosed illustration, would cost approximately $800.00. If $1300.00 is all that is available, I would suggest that the Department purchase the boiler and apply the balance on the Ironer and let the Commission make up the remainder.

I regret that so much correspondence has taken place in connection with the amount of money approved, but we are trying to get the most urgent requirements and that is our reason for requesting the installation of a larger boiler for the laundry. Would the Department kindly advise us as quickly as convenient as the school will be reopening shortly and with so many primary grades this year the laundry equipment is considered urgent.

Your obedient servant,

Re: Vertical Boiler No. 44325 B.C.,
at Indian Residential School,
Alert Bay, B.C.

Having reference to the above, upon looking over my previous reports on this boiler I find that the following various conditions have been reported on.

In 1933 I reported that this boiler had the appearance of having been badly used and Hydrostatic inspection could not be completed on account of tubes leaking on the top end and recommended that they be rerolled, and this was done.

In 1934, during the Hydrostatic test the longitudinal seam started to leak and taking into consideration the internal condition of the plates I reported that it was getting past its usefulness, and again reported that a new and larger boiler be installed.

In my 1935 report the longitudinal seam was again leaking during test. I then reported that it must be renewed as soon as possible, as I would be obliged to cut the steam pressure considerably below usefulness, which was done in 1936, reducing the steam pressure from 120 lbs. to 100 lbs. If it had not been for the extreme care and attention to instructions given to it by Mr. Ward, the Engineer, it would not have lasted as long as it has.

In answer to the request of Mr. Todd, the Indian Agent, about selling it for commercial purposes, this would mean that it would come under the Provincial Inspection Act and as lap longitudinal seams are not now allowed I expect that they would not pass the boiler except for low pressure. I think that $60.00 would be a fair price for it. The suggestion that it be used in another school is in my opinion the only way to dispose of it.

Yours respectfully,

"T. J. Arnall"

Dear Mr. Loney: Re: Alert Bay Indian School

I have your letter of June 17 and I'm really delighted to see that Mr. Webb takes a more considerate attitude.

I honestly do feel in connection with Brick and Cement Coating that under the conditions as they will exist on the job, it would be dangerous to use it. Those walls are full of moisture, you've got slow drying conditions and a lot of rain apparently, even in the sun, and there would be great danger of peeling and then there would be lots and plenty of trouble.

I think the thing to do is to say that we will supply, without cost, F.O.B. the steamer here in New York, or F.O.B. cars for freight, the Clear Waterproofing necessary to do the balcony. Probably ten gallons should be sufficient, fifteen gallons we could be able to furnish if it was desirable. Then if they desire to go thru with the balance of the job we will be glad to talk with them about supplying material for the balance although I'd be inclined to hope that when it came to the balance they would have discovered that really weren't so much to blame and that they could afford to pay at least a cost price on the material. However, I wouldn't quibble about that point.

Now as to specifications I do not see how I can write more explicit specifications than I have already done. To attempt to do so might be misleading for it is very difficult to line out the work from this distance.

The thing that must be accomplished is that they must have sound and solid and full joints. If I was on the job I'd test every joint with a hammer - every one that seemed at all loose I would cut out and cut it out ¼" deep and I would point it up with a high lime cement mortar. I think probably I would use a mortar with one part cement, two parts lime and seven parts sand and I'd do a mighty careful pointing job. If I wanted to be sure of myself I think on that job I'd cut out and re-point every single joint. It's difficult to recommend that from here because it might be spending more than is necessary. Wherever that isn't done I would certainly take the greatest possible care and rub every joint or crack in a sound joint full of Caulking Compound, rubbing it on and rubbing it off the surface so that it'll well filled and then I'd give the whole surface another coat of Clear waterproofing. One coat should be sufficient.

I wish I was going to be out in your section for I think that if this was done, you and Mr. Webb and myself would be able to celebrate and make merry not only at the Golden Jubilee but because this job was finally licked.

Best regards,

Very truly yours,

Sir,

On May 27th I received a telegram from Mr. C.E. Webb, District Chief Engineer, Vancouver, stating Mr. H.J. Loney, representative of the Minwax Company of Canada would arrive in Alert Bay the following day to make an inspection of the work done in 1933 in which the above firm's material was used in waterproofing the walls of St. Michael's Indian Residential School in an effort to stop water leakage penetrating the brick walls of the school.

Upon Mr. Loney's arrival at Alert Bay, I accompanied him to the school and spent five hours going over the work that had been done by their representative as well as examining every portion of the building where it was thought possibly a leakage was taking place. After a very thorough inspection, certain conclusions were arrived at by myself and I feel in the interests of the Department I should make a personal report giving only my own personal views. I think I should also state that for a great many years I handled building material and had considerable experience in the construction of buildings, and therefore my views are being expressed through the knowledge which I have along these lines.

Exterior of Building - I thoroughly examined the quality of material used in the construction of this school. I refer now to the brick used in the veneer work. The bricks supplied for this school were just common clay red brick, and in my opinion should never have been used for an outside wall in a wet climate. I am under the opinion hard-pressed, No.1 brick should have been used in this building in this climate.

The bricks used were found to have many defects, including airpockets, checks, and blisters running generally peaking through a great portion of the bricks used in the building. Where a blister appeared it has either peeled off or so thin that the moisture gets into the brick and keeps the wall damp. Some of these holes and checks would appear to go clean through the brick although it is difficult to determine this. There are many cracks in various joints where with the storm continually beating against the wall, the water could seep through and run down the wall between the brick and the tile in the wall.

I particularly examined the work done by Mr. St.Cyr, representative of the Minwax Company, and I find there are cracks in the wall which were never touched. Upon investigation I also found that when he arrived here several Indians were employed by someone to assist him in doing this work. There are places on the building where this material was put on that the naked eye cannot see any reason why it would be put on. It appears no systematic way of doing the work was established; they simply went over the building and put a little daub on wherever they saw a crack, and it would appear that many cracks were missed. I do not think Indians should have been employed to do this very important work, and in my humble opinion the whole face of the building must be gone over before a satisfactory result can be obtained.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.
The roofs were thoroughly examined, including the main roof, roof of the residence and the roof of the balcony. The three drains of the main roof were found to require repairing; the screens were partially closed with stones and other refuse washed in from the roof. One or two of the screens were completely closed. I have requested the Principal to have these replaced. The asphalt or tar preparation used on these roofs has to some extent deteriorated, leaving much loose gravel on the roof, and it would appear that a new roof will be necessary very shortly.

In my opinion, this is not the most suitable type of roof to be used in this locality where we get so much rainfall at certain seasons of the year. The roof on the balcony was found not to have a proper drain as there was water still lying on the roof twenty-four hours after the last rainfall.

It was our considered opinion that the water getting into the walls of the building was caused partially by the roof where it joins up to the walls and through the main walls themselves, through defective material being used in the original construction which later cracked or developed seams.

Interior of Building - Upon examining the interior of the building the walls were found to be damaged through moisture to the extent that plaster is falling off in spots and in other places a great deal of discolouration has taken place which eventually will cause the plaster to come off. Upon examining the metal lath it was found to be badly rusted and in some places rusted entirely away. The water seeping down through the walls enters the building in the basement coming through the wall at the point where the brick wall joins the cement foundation. The portion of the building which is affected is the east and south side of the main building and residence.

I consider the condition of the building is now a major undertaking and that it would be useless to spend a little money trying to patch it up; however, that matter can be determined by the Department's engineers.

Your obedient servant,

Sir: Re: Alert Bay Indian Residential School

From previous correspondence you will understand we have been in communication with the representative of the Minwax Co. regarding the waterproofing job which was done several years ago at the Indian Residential School, the results of which proved unsatisfactory. The question of responsibility for the fact that water still seeps through the building remains unsettled and as a matter of fact it seems to me we will not arrive at any definite decision in the matter.

From all reports it appears that the weather conditions at Alert Bay during the winter months are extremely severe and with driving rains which last for several days at a time, any building must be absolutely water-tight if seepage is to be avoided and this does not seem to be the case in the Alert Bay School.

Mr. H.J. Loney, Vancouver, representative of the Minwax Co. Inc. made an inspection recently at the expense of his company, of the Alert Bay School. He reported to his principals that the building was not in a satisfactory condition as far as water tightness was concerned. He reported finding cracks between bricks and mortar in many places. He also reported finding in quite a number of instances, bricks with thin holes in them into which moisture had seeped and lodge which might possibly be the cause of considerable seepage. The condition at this school is unfortunate in view of the fact that so much seepage has occurred that now the walls of the building are almost continuously wet, in fact it is doubtful if the interior of the walls dries out during the summer months. This condition makes it very difficult to determine what would satisfactorily waterproof the building. Frankly I am at a loss to know what to recommend.

Mr. Loney is very anxious to have his product used in an endeavour to finally seal the building against moisture. In order to definitely determine if this Minwax product will satisfactorily waterproof the building it has been suggested that a surface of approximately 600 square feet be

treated as a test. The area selected is one which has given considerable trouble and is located just over the main entrance to the school on the southern exposure from the roof down to the first floor. The Minwax Co. are prepared to furnish ten gallons of Minwax free, f.o.b. New York, we to pay the duty and freight charges. In addition to this some 30 lbs. of caulking compound would be required and five gallons of black Minwax coating for treating the back of the parapet over the main entrance. Something must be done at an early date as possible to waterproof this building and from the information now available I do not think we can hold the Minwax Co. wholly responsible for the fact that their product did not make a satisfactory waterproofing job.

How to Iron Bed Sheets, Pillow Cases,

1. Sheets that are wider than twice the width of the Beatty roll should be folded in two first, then passed through the ironer twice, and folded to put away.

Table Cloths

3. Table Cloths are ironed after being laid once with opening at the operator's right end with as much of the article in the ironer as possible. Embroidered Doilies

The Yoke

1. The first part of the shirt to iron on the Beatty is the yoke. Place the yoke of the shirt over the open end of the roll and iron across the shoulders. This flattens down the shoulder seams and gives finish to the work.

Back of Shirt

2. Next iron the back of the shirt on the inside from the bottom up to the arm. Release, and move to the left to clear arm and then iron up to the neckband. Turn neckband over if still damp.

Front of Shirt

3. The left or button hole side of the shirt is next. Place it the right side up, and iron from the bottom up to the arm. Release and move to the left to clear arm, and then iron up to the neck band. Then iron the right front from the bottom up on the inside. Always turn the buttons in towards the roll.

Sleeves

4. Flatten out each sleeve along the seam. Slide the cuff on the roll until it passes shoe and iron from top of cuff to the shoulder. Iron both sides of sleeves.

How to Iron Dresses, Bloomers,

1. When ironing children's dresses, slip the skirt over the roll with the waist band of the dress at the open end. Fold the sleeve of the dress and iron all the way round.

2. Iron one sleeve of the dress at a time. Place the sleeve flat on the roll and iron from the cuff to the armpit.

3. Iron the yoke of the dress next. Continue to iron over the shoulder and across the yoke to the other sleeve.

4. The collar is ironed by placing it around the open end of the roll and allowing it to take its own shape.

5. Slip the dress over the open end of the roll. Place the pressing lever in the "Press" position. Set the pleat and turn the roll forward. Apply the pressure and allow the shoe to press for a few seconds, then release the pressure lever.

6. When ironing under-bloomers which have the elastic band at the waist and on the legs, iron the top portion of the bloomers first from one side to the other as shown in illustration No. 6.

7. Iron across the legs of bloomers, letting the top portion extend over the open end of the roll. Be careful to stretch the elastic so that the gathers will be ironed out in both legs and waist.
Smocks, Collars, Press Ties, Trousers

1. Smock Being Ironed

Smocks or Hoover Aprons
1. Smocks or Hoover Aprons are ironed in a similar way to a man's shirt as illustrated and described on pages 4 and 5.

Detachable Collars
2. Soft, detachable collars are ironed by placing a number of them on the roll while the pressure is being applied. Then fold them in the centre and iron the right side up. This gives them a natural shape. If collars are to be starched use cold starch and only a small quantity.

When small articles like collars are being ironed, their position on the shoe should be varied so as to keep the heat in the shoe evenly distributed across its whole length.

Pressing Ties
3. Ties are pressed by placing a damp cloth over the shoe and pressing them. Then iron them with the inside facing shoe.

Pressing Trousers
4. Press each trouser leg separately on both sides. To do this, turn the Shoe Release Lever so that the shoe is thrown right back from the roll. Place a dampened cloth over the shoe so as to completely cover it. Then turn the Pressing Lever to the "Press" position. Put the shoe release into place and the Beatty will automatically apply the necessary pressure. Allow to steam, and press for a few seconds, and then release in the same manner.

When both legs have been pressed separately, fold them together, and place in ironer as shown in illustration No. 4.

Steaming Velvet
5. To Steam Velvet, turn the hot shoe, so that it faces upward in a horizontal position. Place a wet towel on the shoe and draw the velvet back and forth over the steaming towel.
