Directions for Set-up, Operation and Care of the Beatty Ironer

Installing the Ironer
If the Ironer is delivered to you crated, remove the crate carefully so as not to scratch the ironer. Also remove the paper covering the roll. Attach castor brackets with screws and lock washers to be found in a small box under the castors under the ironer. The heat of the ironer may be adjusted to suit the individual by raising or lowering the castor brackets. Thumb screws are provided to keep the castors from turning too freely. Insert the castors and plug into a convenient wall plug.

Heat Control
The heat switch which controls the heat of the shoe is on the name plate at the right. When the heat is on, the pilot light just above the switch will show red. The switch for starting the motor is also on this plate.

Finger Touch Control
The finger touch lever controls the shoe and roll. Press gently, then release and the shoe will come up to the roll and the roll will turn. Press again and the shoe leaves the roll and the roll stops. If you hold it down the shoe will come up to the roll and move back again, continuing this forward and backward movement till the finger is removed.

Knee Control
The knee control lever is on the left beneath the base. Pressing the lever gently with the knee and releasing it has exactly the same effect as the finger control. It is more convenient as it leaves both hands free to feed in and smooth out articles being ironed.

Pressing Control
The pressing control lever is on top at the right. When turned to "PRESS" the shoe is brought up to the roll without the roll turning. In this position it can be used for pressing trousers, pleats, embroidery, etc.

For raised work, initials, etc., it is not necessary to release the shoe to press—simply turn the lever to the "PRESS" position, hold for the time required to press, then turn back to "IRON" position and roll will turn. Turn this lever to "IRON" for ordinary ironing.

Emergency Control
The emergency control lever is at the right and behind the shoe. If, for any reason, the roll stops turning when ironing, push the emergency lever back away from the roll. This will move the shoe away from the roll and prevent scorching.

To continue ironing, pull the lever back to its original position.

Try operating all controls before starting to iron the first time.

Heating the Shoe
To protect it previous to installing, the element is given a coating of gum. This is burned off when heat is applied, causing a slight odor which will gradually disappear. The shoe requires about 7 minutes to heat sufficiently for ironing. Test the shoe as you would a hand iron, by touching it with a moist finger. If it sizzles it is hot enough to iron.

If the shoe is not heating fast enough or not retaining its heat for continuous ironing, have your electrician check your voltage.

To prevent any part of the shoe from overheating when ironing small pieces, use first one end of the roll and then the other.

For silks and rayons, the shoe should be cooled.

When ironing is finished, before turning off the motor, make sure the shoe is clear of the roll by releasing the emergency lever. This will prevent scorching the roll cover.

Cover and End Tray
The cover may either be hinged back or lifted right off. For some operations, such as steaming velvet, it is better to lift the cover off. Before closing the cover, place the emergency lever in the "OFF" position and then turn it over behind the shoe.

To use the clothes tray raise it and push in. To lower the tray pull it out and drop it.

Oiling
Some machines are shipped without oil. A red tag tied to the "PRESS IRON" control lever will tell what to do in this case.

There are three oil holes requiring two or three drops of oil once a month. One is a cup at the back of the mechanism case; the other two are at either end of the motor.

General Suggestions
Start first on simple, flat pieces and, as you become more proficient, do the more difficult pieces such as men's shirts, etc.

Avoid, as far as possible, allowing buttons and hooks to come into contact with the shoe. Turn them towards the roll or cover them with a piece of cloth.

If you have never used an ironer before, follow the methods illustrated in the preceding pages. As you become expert you may find another way that you prefer. Don't become discouraged with your first attempts. The more you use the ironer, the more proficient you will become.

How to Iron Bed Sheets, Pillow Cases, Pajamas, Aprons, Curtains, Bloomers

Sheets
1. Sheets that are wider than twice the width of the Beauty roll should be folded in two first, then passed through the ironer twice, and folded to put away.

Pillow Cases
2. Pillow Cases are ironed from the closed end to the open end. If embroidered, the pillow case should be turned right side up the first time through. There is no need to release the shoe when thin flat pieces like pillow cases are being ironed. These thin articles lie flat on the roll, and the open throat of the Beauty shoe permits them to feed into the shoe without wrinkling.

Table Cloths
3. Table Cloths should be folded once when operating at the operator's right and with as much of the article in the shoe as possible. The other part of the table cloth should extend over the open end of the roll. This extended part should be ironed before the second fold lengthwise is made.

Embroidered Doilies
4. Embroidered Circular Doilies, when put through the first time, are ironed from the center with the embroidery facing down and turn through; the embroidered side should be turned towards the roll. This presses the embroidery into the pad and makes the design on the doily stand out.

Serviettes
5. Feed these into the ironer with the napkin edge flat and with the inside facing the shoe. When the article comes off the roll, take the end that is ironed last and start it through again first giving it a quarter turn. Several serviettes may be folded and ironed together. This saves a great deal of time.

Pajama Pants
6. Iron each leg of pajama pants separately from the bottom up. Then fold the legs together and iron from bottom to top. Pajama coats are ironed the same way as men's shirts. See pages 4 and 5.

7. You can bid goodbye to that tiresome, tedious method of ironing with a hand iron once you have the Beauty to do all the hard work.

Towels
1. Bath Towels, Tea Towels and Hand Towels are ironed after being folded once. They can be put through two at a time as shown in Illustration No. 1.

Apron Strings
2. Apron Strings are the first part of the apron to iron on the Beauty, as shown in Illustration No. 2. Apron strings are ironed together up to the point where they are attached to the apron.

Aprons
3. After the apron strings are ironed, place the apron over the roll and iron from bottom to top, allowing a part of the apron to extend over the open end of the roll. Fold the bottom of the garment on the arm to keep apron off the floor. Then iron the extended part from the bottom up.

Curtain Ruffles
4. Iron the ruffles by drawing the ruffled edge around the open end of the roll. This shapes the ruffle without creasing.

Curtains
5. When ironing body of curtains, allow the ruffled edge to extend out over the end of the ironer roll as shown in Illustration No. 3. Iron the ruffle first, then the body.

Bloomers With Elastic Band Waist
6. Slip the garment over the roll and iron the top portion all the way around. Remove the bloomers and place each band separately on the roll and iron all the way around.

When making up my Estimates I provided for $40,000 for the Alert Bay Residential School, being made up as follows: $36,000 being the grant on the basis of $180 per capita for two hundred children and a balance of $4,000 to provide for the Department's grant towards the salary of the Manual Training instructor at $40.00 per month, making a total of $480.00, and allowing approximately $600 for the purchases of manual training equipment and supplies. This left a balance of $2920 for emergency expenditures which might be necessary throughout the year.

Rev. Sir,

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 5th ultimo together with copy of draft agreement pertaining to a proposal that the Indian Village of Alert Bay on the Nimpkish Indian Reserve No 1, be provided with a domestic water supply from wells at the Alert Bay Indian Residential School.

In reply I beg to advise that after giving the above mentioned proposal further consideration the Department considers that it would not be advisable that the present pumping machinery and equipment at the School, which was paid for from School Vote, be used in connection with a water supply system for the Indian Village. It is believed that the combination of both systems would offer too many risks as to the needs of the school, and too many complications and difficulties should any breakages or defects occur during the operation of the system.

It is therefore considered that a water supply system, if absolutely required for the village, would be more satisfactory to both parties if entirely separate from the school system.

A copy of this letter is being sent to our Assistant Indian Commissioner, Mr. C. B. Ferry, who has brought this question to the attention of the Department on the suggestion of Indian Agent Todd.

Thanking you for the interest you have taken in this proposal, I remain,

Yours respectfully,

St. Michael's Indian School and

We have recently invested between $15,000.00
and $20,000.00 in the Construction of a Power Plant and
Electric Distribution system at Alert Bay, and are now
writing you with the idea of obtaining a contract from your
Department to supply Electric Energy to the above mentioned
properties.

It is our understanding that although your
Department does not directly pay for the Lighting of the
residential School, it does make a considerable contribution
to the Missionary Society on a per capita basis, and the
capital expenditure for lighting plant and the maintenance,
repairs and renewal of same.

Figures which we have secured from a re-
liable source would lead us to believe that the cost of the
operation of your plant at Alert Bay would be not less than
$130.00 a month, made up as follows:

Fuel & Lubricating Oils $ 300.00
Depreciation on $6,500.00 cost
of plant the life of which is
estimated at eight years 812.00
Interest on Investment 3% 195.00
Part time attendant at Plant, say 300.00

Total $1,607.00

Our understanding is that the Superintendent
of the School is opposed to the idea of purchasing energy from us for the reason that under the present arrangement the only expense to the School is the cost of the fuel and lubricating oils, the Department of Indian Affairs taking care of all other expenses mentioned above.

Memorandum:

With reference to the report hereunder from Inspector Pragnell regarding the moisture penetrating the outside walls of the Alert Bay Indian Residential School during heavy rains, I may say that the same condition existed at the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School in Nova Scotia.

You will remember that I made a careful investigation last year to find a remedy and I found that the Canadian National Railways had experienced the same difficulty with their buildings in similar locations.

The Shubenacadie Indian Residential School has been waterproofed by the Western Waterproofing Co., and the results appear so far to have been satisfactory. This is the same system that has been used by the Engineers of the Canadian National Railways.

If funds are available in the next fiscal year I would recommend that similar procedure be taken in the waterproofing of the walls of the Alert Bay School.

Schools: I also went over the Residential School with Mr. Anfield, the Principal, and Indian Agent Todd. There were 203 children in the school at the time of my visit. I am sorry to say, however, that the whole school had been down with mumps. Five children had had septic pneumonia, but the administration should receive full credit for the fact that they had pulled them all through safely. I found everything in very satisfactory order, clean and tidy, and all fire apparatus in good order, children looking well despite the mumps, and the food good and sufficient. Sir,

Under date of February 17th last, letter No.156-0-5, the Department wrote me enclosing copy of a letter received from the Pacific Power & Water Company Ltd., 675 West Hastings Street, Vancouver, together with their reply to the above company. As requested in the Department's letter, I have obtained the required information and respectfully submit same for the Department's information.

In regard to the Residential School, I enclose herewith copy of Mr. Anfield's report in connection with the electric plant now used at the Residential School, which will be self-explanatory.

The Department will please note in the comparison of costs, that at the present time in using the school plant the average cost per month does not exceed $54.25, whereas the local power company suggest that their cost of supplying electrical energy would be somewhat less than $130.00 which they estimate as the cost of operating the school under its own plant.

It is also noted in Mr. Anfield's figures he has made no allowance for depreciation and has provided for only actual operating costs. It is also noted he estimates the life of our present plant at ten years and that it has been in service at the present time for eight years. These are points which I feel should be taken into consideration in arriving at a decision in respect to the equipment and the possibility of making a change.

In regard to the Agency delco light plant, I enclose herewith an estimate of what it would cost to re-wire the Agency building in order to make it safe for using power other than the delco plant. I am inclined to feel the estimated cost as submitted by the Pacific Power & Water Company is too high, and that if I were given authority to arrange to have the work done myself and also be able to buy the materials wholesale, this cost could be reduced considerably, and would be pleased to undertake the work if the Department approved of dealing with it in that way.

I enclose also a letter received from the Company as to the cost of lighting the Agency, submitting the rates which sets out the approximate average monthly consumption and cost. My own opinion in this respect would be that our light bill would not be much higher than it is at the present time when we take into consideration that the delco plant is at the point where considerable money must be spent on it if we are to continue using it. It will require a new set of batteries and a complete overhaul, which I would not recommend when we have city lights now available. I feel the Department should encourage local endeavour wherever possible, all things being equal.
I would therefore recommend, as far as the Agency is concerned, that the Department arrange to take the Pacific Power & Water Company lights, and authorize me to arrange for the rewiring of the Agency buildings, which I feel can be done cheaper than the price quoted in their estimate.

In connection with the Residential School, I would recommend that no change be made there at present, as it appears the equipment is in good shape and should require no replacements for a further period of two years, unless the Pacific Power & Water Company can compensate the school by supplying electrical energy at a cost not to exceed the school's cost of their own plant at the present time. I would also recommend that if this cannot be arranged, the matter be left as it is until it is found necessary for further capital expenditure in connection with the plant, at which time the matter can be gone into again.

Dear Sir,

Replying to your letter of March 5th in connection with the lighting plant in the School, I have to advise as follows:

**Plant Engine No. 1** - 6½ H.P. Lister. Condition fair. Piston is sloppy, but it should be remembered that this engine has its original cylinder, pistons and bearings.

**Plant Engine No. 2** - ¼ H.P. Lister. Condition good. New cylinders and valves were installed on this engine two years ago. Original bearings and pistons in both cylinders.

**Switchboard** - First class condition. All relays and cut-outs 100%, and both engines operate on automatic control through this board.

**Batteries** - Coyle type, installed five years ago this coming Christmas. Present condition only fair. In our opinion they are the wrong type for an automatic plant, which places a tremendous drain on the batteries on starting. These batteries are splendid storage batteries, but are not heavy enough for starting work. This is their sole use here, as we only carry 300 watts on them before the relays kick in and the engines start.

**Wiring** - All O. K., and would not require replacement for an A. C. circuit.
The Indian Agent.

General Efficiency of Plant - This plant is 100% efficient at the present time and has never once failed us in the eight years of its installation. Credit must undoubtedly go to efficient care by our very competent engineer, Mr. W. Ward. It should be said, however, that with the increased buildings attached to the School, that the plant is getting very close to maximum capacity and any further heavy drain would overload it.

Potential Life of Plant - With the steady use of this plant here, I would imagine that ten years would be its normal life, following which time the plant should be rebuilt if satisfactory service is to be ensured.

However, with the advent of the modern automatic Diesel plants, it would appear to be poor economy to continue with gasoline engines, with their costly fuel and obvious danger from fire and explosion. When the time comes for replacement, I would strongly recommend a 60 H.P. automatic Diesel direct coupled to a 25 K.W. flat compound wound generator, in conjunction with a 300 Amp. Hr. heavy duty battery for night work.

Cost - For the calendar year, 1936, the cost of operation of this plant amounted to $419.49 or an average monthly cost of $35.00 which is very reasonable. It has remained at this figure for some years, rising from an average of $30.00 in 1932 when extra buildings were added to the plant. Cost of all parts and replacements in the eight years of installation would not exceed $270, or $30.00 a year at the outside. The engineer would not spend more than an hour a day average on the plant throughout the year, giving a maintenance cost of less than $200.00 a year in wages, or $16.76 a month. Fuel, repairs and time thus do not exceed an average of $54.25 a month, whereas the local power plant figure our light bill would average $100.00 a month, according to the local manager.

Trusting that this will convey the desired information,

Yours very truly,

FEA/L. Principal.

Dear Sir:

In line with our conversation of this morning, this letter is an attempt to answer your second question: "what assurance have you that this plant will be operating two or three years from now?"

While it is impossible for us to guarantee that the plant will be operating at that time, I can definitely state that it is the present intention and belief of the shareholders and directors that it will be, not only two years from now, but for the duration of time.

The cost of the plant to date in capital equipment has been around $18,000.00. If it became necessary to shut down because it had been shown that the operation was no longer commercially practicable, the value of the installed equipment would immediately become little more than the value of scrap metal - say $8,000.00. By shutting down the shareholders would lose over 50% of their original investment - a strong motive to keep operating.

How soon the plant becomes firmly established depends upon the feeling of the community for it, and upon little else. It is felt that this public feeling is becoming more and more favorable; that people are realizing that the plant is an asset to the community, and an enterprise worthy of their support.

It is our hope that you feel the same way about it, and that by your support you will help us to become an integral part of this community.

Yours truly,

(Sgd) "J. Potts"

So far as I have been able to determine from inspection and reports of the school staff, the work done approximately 400 square feet, has been successful in overcoming the leak in the area covered, that is, above the sunroom in the centre of the school. Other parts of the school, residence and laundry still leak very badly. Part of one of the interior walls at the southeast corner of the school was still damp at the time of my visit, from rain that had leaked through about one week previously. No additional leaks since my last visit in 1935 are apparent in the walls.

FURTHER WATERPROOFING

I would suggest that a larger area of the school wall be treated, as was done last year, as a further test of the effectiveness of this waterproofing material. It would, however, be desirable to have the caulking compound tinted to approximately the color of the brick so that a liberal use of the caulking material will not disfigure the building completely. The section most in need of additional treatment is the east wall of the school, residence and laundry. Most particularly that part immediately above the residence on the school wall, about 800

APPLICATION

The application of the waterproofing material should not be done when the walls are wet or damp or the temperature is below about 70° F. at the point where work is being carried out. I noticed that some of the waterproofing done by Mr. MacLean appeared to have been carried on when the temperature was low as the material in places congealed on the surface and in consequence will probably scale off. This occurred on parts of the building previously waterproofed.

The amount of the waterproofing liquid to be applied to secure a satisfactory job would appear to be more than was recommended by the supplying company. Comparing the work done previously with what Mr. MacLean did, I would say that the material first applied had either leached out or had been absorbed further into the brick, as the brick in the portion done by Mr. MacLean has a glazed appearance, similar to that when the building was first waterproofed, whereas the brick in the portion first waterproofed has much the appearance of the brick in the untreated walls.

DRAINS

Regarding Mr. MacLean's statement that the seepage is through the concrete walls and that drains would overcome this, I would like to point out that there are large tile drains all around the building placed as he suggests. I would also like
to point out that there are now several cracks in the basement walls through which leakage does not appear to enter but water still leaks through along the first brick course above the basement wall nearby.

I would recommend that additional work on the walls similar to that done by Mr. MacLean be carried out this coming summer, if the weather is suitable.

SCHOOL ROOF

I examined the school roof and find that repairs are urgently needed. Quite a lot of soil has accumulated on portions of the roof and growth has commenced. In such places the roof sheeting seems to be in process of decay. The bituminous coating on the roof surface generally is very thin and in places none remains. It would be desirable to renew the roofing sheet in many places around the roof edge next the parapet wall and particularly under the flashing. In some places the edge of the roofing sheet butts the parapet wall but does not lap it under the flashing, also in places examined, where a lap does occur, the paper is very fragile.

The flashing (copper) is not of the type shown on coping detail on sheet 5 of school plans (Lytton) but as shown on attached sketch. The intended protection is not provided by the existing flashing as is evident by the condition of the roof where examination was possible. A complete examination was not possible at the time without being prepared to effect immediate repairs owing to the probability of causing damage to the waterproof membrane.
I would like to point out, however, that I only found one leak which I could definitely attribute to the condition of the roof along the parapet wall. However, I would suggest that when repairs are to be made to the roof that sufficient funds should be provided to effectively seal the roof at its junction with the parapet wall completely around the building, although it may not be found necessary to carry out the work to that extent when a thorough examination is possible. There is 1350 lineal feet of parapet or other wall protected or intended to be protected by flashing.

I would suggest further that the roof be scraped, brushed and washed, and a new coat of asphalt applied over the whole roof area and gravel re-distributed.

SPECIFICATIONS FOR REPAIRS AND RENEWALS TO FLASHING (ABOUT 1350 LINEAL FEET)

Flashing is to be repaired before renewal of asphalt roof coating.

Scrape, brush and wash all along that part of roof adjacent to parapet or other wall where flashing is to be repaired. Raise counter-flashing and remove slip flashing. Apply four sheets 15-lb. asphalt saturated roofing felt to roof surface. Sheets to be one-half roll width. The first sheet to be applied to the roof surface with roofing cement and turned up the vertical face of the wall as high as the counter-flashing will permit, and fastened in place with nails driven through flat tin caps placed not closer than six inches to the edge of the roof deck. Each additional sheet to be applied to the one below with coating of roofing cement and to be turned up the vertical face to within one inch of the top of the preceding sheet and fastened with nails driven through flat tin caps placed not closer than six inches to the edge of the roof. In no case shall the top of the last sheet be below the lower edge of the counter-flashing, end lap to be not less than six inches, and to be fastened with roofing cement.

When completed the whole to be given a mopping of roofing asphalt applied hot and the gravel replaced.

The counterflashing to be turned down in a vertical position and the slip-flashing replaced. All cracks and broken joints in metal flashing to be soldered and where necessary flashing replaced. The counter-flashing raglet to be re-calked with Minwax calking compound where necessary.
Where the counter-flashing raglet is more than 12 inches from the roof deck full width felt sheets are to be used.

After the roof deck has been cleaned and the counter-flashing raised and before further work is carried out, an inspection will be made to determine the extent of felt flashing to be installed, after which necessary materials will be ordered.
SPECIFICATIONS FOR RENEWAL OF ASPHALT ROOF SURFACE AND ADDITION OF GRAVEL (11,900 SQUARE FEET)

Scrape, brush and wash all that part of roof not already done under foregoing specifications. The surface to be entirely free from dust, sand and moss before application of asphalt. Mop surface with 30 lbs. per square (100 square feet) roofing asphalt applied hot. Spread gravel over entire surface of roof, 450 lbs. gravel per square, only about half this quantity on roof at present.

Asphalt shall be a high grade roofing product having a melting point of approximately 170°. Gravel is to be such as will pass a 3/4" square mesh screen, free from sand, and to be washed before spreading on roof. Where the surface of the roofing felt is broken repairs are to be made in an approved manner before mopping on asphalt coat, not less than two sheets and nor more than four sheets of 15-lb. asphalt saturated felt to be used and to be applied with roofing cement and fastened with nails driven through flat tin caps.

Dear Sir:

In complying with your instructions to waterproof 400 square feet of wall at the Indian School at Alert Bay, immediately above the sun room, also behind the parapet wall on the south side of school building, I may say I rubbed the bad joints with Minwax Compound No. 1 and gave the bricks two very heavy coats of clear waterproofing which I soaked in, using over 4 gallons.

Behind Parapet Wall

I wire-brushed the brick thoroughly and put one coat of damp-proofing and followed this with one coat of trowelling compound about 1/8-inch thick. On my inspection I found a stub of a flag pole which had a crack one-half inch wide. This I sawed off level with the copper flashing and covered it with a heavy coat of trowelling compound and sealed it.

Roof

The roof is in poor shape, especially behind the south and east walls for about three feet. There is quite a lot of moss growing there and the paper, not being well covered with asphalt, is in bad condition.

The joints of the copping of the south wall I covered with the saturated cotton as far as it would go and finished the rest with sacking strips and trowel coated over them well. Behind the copping stone I covered with one coat of damp-proofing.

I also found what I should say is a bad leak on the copping of the sunroom roof, the flashing being pulled away from the main building fully 3/4 of an inch, which I caulked.

So you will see I have carried out your instructions and more, to have a good test.

South and East Walls

The brick, I must say, is very porous and unevenly laid, and worst of all, the mortar was mixed with very coarse sand and little cement which makes the joints of the brick very porous and undoubtedly allows the moisture to penetrate. The work done on these walls has been of some benefit, although I consider the clear waterproofing used has not a heavy enough base and would therefore recommend waterproof paint of not less than three coats, on these two walls in particular, coupled with careful inspection of all
pitholes and open joints in brick, which should be pointed before painting, and that this be done as early as possible next year weather permitting. In so doing I consider you will save the metal laths and plaster on the interior of these two walls.

The brick throughout the whole building is very unevenly laid and forms small ledges that hold the water and when the wind is blowing will eventually seep through the walls.

Drains

I fully believe the seepage in the basement is entirely caused for the want of a tile drain placed one foot away from the foundation wall and not less than 4" below floor level. When laying same there should be at least one foot of beach pebbles or crushed rock placed above to allow perfect drainage.

I also would suggest while digging is being done, to have a damp-proofing coat put on the outside of the cement wall to grade height. This will be further protection against any seepage through concrete wall.

Your instructions regarding my accommodation - although Mr. Todd no doubt did his best, there was no room at the school which necessitated my going to the hotel.

Material at Alert Bay

4 gals. Clear waterproofing
2½ " Damp-proofing
9 gals. of trowel coating
1 gal. of caulking compound

Yours very truly,

J.C. McLean

P.S. In carrying out these suggestions, I would recommend that a competent man be employed, one who thoroughly understands construction and preferably one who is conscientious and understands the treatment of leaky buildings, so that you will get results for the expense entailed.

Memorandum:

Mr. Wardle.

Re - Alert Bay Indian Residential School.

According to advice received from Mr. Webb, District Chief Engineer, Dominion Water and Power Bureau, British Columbia, it appears that there has been trouble experienced during wet weather at the above school caused by seepage through the walls of the building. Following an inspection an attempt was made last year to correct the seepage with the application of water-proofing material on the apparently affected sections of the building. The result of such treatment did not prove satisfactory and after much correspondence with the manufacturer of the product (Minwax Company Incorporated, 11 West 42nd St., New York) it was decided to re-treat a small section of the more seriously affected wall with the Minwax Company's preparations in an effort to determine if their product was capable of giving a satisfactory water-proofing job. This work was done last September by an experienced man obtained in Vancouver and a copy of his report is attached.

Last spring Mr. Webb had Mr. Warren of his office make an inspection to ascertain the results of the experiment of last September and report on further work that he would recommend to improve the remainder of the walls. A copy of Mr. Warren's report is attached. From this report it appears that the 400 square feet which were treated last summer have successfully kept out the water during the last winter and Mr. Warren further indicates that no additional leaks have developed since his visit in 1935. It would appear however that the whole building is in a poor state of repair due partly to wall leakage. Although a question which does not need to be considered at the present time, it is not apparent just how the quality of brick and mortar as indicated in Mr. Warren's report was used in the original construction of the building.

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director, Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.
As there still seems to be some doubt as to the results that might be obtained from using Minwax products on an extensive scale, Mr. Warren recommends that as a further experiment an additional 800 square feet of wall be treated at an estimated cost of $250.00.

On Mr. Warren's investigation of this building, it was found that the roof was urgently in need of repairs and he recommends that such work be undertaken. The cost of same is estimated at $995.00. Attached to Mr. Warren's report are specifications for repairs and renewals to the flashing as well as specifications for renewal of asphalt roof surface and addition of gravel.

In view of the condition of this building as described in Mr. Warren's report, it is apparent that something should be done to preserve this building insofar as the quality of its original construction will permit. Mr. Warren's suggestions are therefore concurred in and it is recommended that repair work be undertaken in accordance with his report provided that the money is available and the Indian Affairs Branch is agreeable to have such work undertaken. It will be noted that it is desirable to have the repair work in question done during warm weather and subject to your approval it is suggested that if this work is to be undertaken Mr. Webb might be instructed that the work is approved, but that it is only to be undertaken when weather conditions are suitable.

Respectfully submitted,

(sgd.) T.S.MILLS,

On October 2, 1937, the following letter was received from J. C. Kelley, Acting Salvage Officer:

Dear Mr. Todd,

I have to notify you officially of my intended marriage this coming summer, and to request the earnest consideration of the Department towards putting the Principal's residence at this school into better condition than it is now.

As you are aware, the residence has by its position on the south-east corner of the building, received the brunt of the severe leakage which has taken place on the whole weather face of the building, as a result of which the residence walls and ceilings are in such condition that the house will need a complete renovation from top to bottom.

A prima facie condition of any such renovation must be the waterproofing of the outside walls and I understand it is the Department's intention to carry this work through to a satisfactory conclusion as soon as the weather is suitable.

When the School was built, the Department furnished one room in the residence and supplied a cook range for the kitchen. The balance of the furniture required was supplied by the Indian Residential School Commission or by myself. For some years I lived in the residence, my meals and wants supplied by a housekeeper, but the place was so cold and damp that eventually I gave up the place and moved into the main building. Within the past two years, an increased staff made it necessary to move four workers back into the residence for sleeping purposes only, and though it has been far from comfortable for them, the first waterproofing job helped a little and we have been able, by pushing the heat in the evening and shutting off all the downstairs radiators, to get the upstairs rooms fairly warm for sleeping purposes. However, if the house is to be used as a home for permanent use, something must be done to augment the present heating supply. Dear Major MacKay:

I have read with considerable care the file of correspondence with regard to suggested improvements in the Principal's residence at St. Michael's Indian Residential School, Alert Bay.

I use a room in the residence when carrying out inspections around Alert Bay and have been there from 7 to 10 days yearly. This has given me an opportunity of seeing just what repairs and additions are urgently required.

In general, I am in agreement with the views put forward by Mr. F. E. Anfield and the recommendations of Mr. Indian Agent Todd, though I do not know where a sum of almost $500.00 is to be found to carry out the requested work.

I could not possibly recommend the installation of a hot-air furnace, and I regret that I am unable to even recommend that an oil burner be installed for heating purposes in the Principal's residence at a cost of $115.50. There is no reason, as far as I can see, why the heating of the Principal's residence should prove any more difficult than the School in general. I have found that when the engineer attends to his work the heating of the School and residence is quite satisfactory. It is quite possible that some attention should be paid to the regulation of the radiators through the School to ensure that when the residence is properly heated other parts of the School are at about the same temperature and not overheated as at present. It is true that when the main part of the School is only heated to a moderate degree, the Principal's residence, being furtherest from the boilers, does not receive sufficient heat.
The French doors suggested for the dining room and the living room are in my opinion necessary; such doors have been provided in the Principal's residence at St. George's School, Lytton. The door leading from the Principal's study to the verandah does not fit properly and certainly requires weather stripping. I would, in fact, recommend that all outside windows and doors of the residence be provided with metal weather stripping. This, I think, would do more to maintain a steady temperature than the provision of a costly oil burner. When I occupy a room at this School I find that the wind blows right through closed windows and doors, and, of course, lowers the temperature of the rooms considerably.

The walls and ceilings certainly require some sort of washable kalsomine, as they are in a dreadful state owing to the penetration of rain from south-easterly gales. I am further in agreement with Mr. Anfield when he states that the waterproofing of the outside walls should be attended to before any kalsomining is carried out inside the building, but I understand that it is the Department's intention to carry out this waterproofing as soon as the weather is suitable.

The kitchen range originally supplied for use in the Principal's residence has been made use of in the domestic science class, and is now completely worn out. The installation of power plugs for use of electric appliances in connection with the recently installed Alert Bay mains, is also recommended.

In conclusion I may say that, if my own recommendations are accepted, the cost of the improvements at St. Michael's Indian Residential School would be reduced from the estimated total of $491.46 to $375.96, which would be increased a little by the cost of the metal weather stripping (which I consider the boys of the Manual Training Class could install at no extra cost). I would, therefore, request that no more than $400.00 be authorized for the improvements of this School, although I am not able to make any suggestion with regard to where this money is to be found, as it would not appear that such improvements have been allowed for in this year's estimates.

Yours very truly,

Gerald H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools for B.C.
Office of Indian Agent.

Alert Bay, B.C.,
March 29, 1938.

Dear Sir:

Replying to your letter No.23/2627 dated March 22nd last, I beg to advise I have given the matter of heating the residence at the Indian Residential School due consideration, and in view of the fact that the residence at the present time does get a small amount of heat from the present heating system located in the main building, it is felt if the Department installed an oil burner in the hall or the residence it would amply heat these rooms and at the same time save the Department a considerable outlay in the cost of a furnace.

This suggestion has been taken up with Principal Anfield of the School, and he is of the same opinion as myself and therefore I would recommend that in place of installing a hot air furnace, at a cost of $300.00, with an additional cost of $150.00 for condensate pumps making a total of $450.00, an oil burner be installed at a cost of $115.50 as per estimate and illustration enclosed.

You will also please find enclosed a letter and quotations received from Mr. Anfield for additional work and material required to put the residence in proper condition so that he may make his home there when married. I have perused very carefully Mr. Anfield's letter addressed to me under date of March 21st, and agree with him that the work requested is necessary. The walls and ceilings and floors should be done over as well as installing the two French doors for the living and dining room.

In respect to the range, you will please note Mr. Anfield is requesting a new "Kleen-Kook" oil burner range as well as a hot water tank. I might state in this connection when the school was built the Department did supply a cooking range for the residence, but as Mr. Anfield has used it all these years in the interests of the school for domestic science classes as well as in the isolation building, I feel it should be replaced at this time and would recommend that a new one be supplied.

In respect to Item 4, "Installation of Power Plugs" I would state the school is now connected with the city power lines and electrical energy used for the ironer and frigidaire. Our present plant will not permit any further load, and therefore Mr. Anfield is asking that power plugs be installed so that he can personally use the city power, and I would recommend that this work be done for him.

You will please note the total items requested amounts to $491.46. By using Item No.3, Auxiliary Heater in place of the hot air furnace, the Department will save considerable money and would cut down the total cost to some extent.
Mr. Anfield has given the Department many years of faithful service in the interests of the Indian people, and I feel in recognition of this service the Department should at this time show him every consideration by having the residence put into good shape when it is going to be permanently occupied as a residence, and I would therefore recommend that the requests as submitted be approved at an early date so that the work can be got under way and completed by July 1st at the latest in order that he can take up residence there early in August, at which time he expects to be married.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Re: Lighting System, Alert Bay School.

In view of the fact that the batteries of the lighting system at this School have been in use since 1932, and are now reported to be "in their last stage of usefulness" and must soon be replaced, and in view of the further fact that the present lighting plant is gasoline driven, with the consequent "ever present risk of back-firing and explosion from engines which as their age increases, become more and more prone to such attacks" and in view of the still further fact that this lighting system will be unable to provide the N.B. Preventorium which will be opened in connection with this School at the beginning of January next with the light required, Mr. Principal Anfield has recommended to our Commission that arrangements be made with the Pacific Power and Water Co., Ltd. of 806 Royal Trust Building, Vancouver, B.C. for this school to be supplied with light and power from the plant of this Company they have recently established in Alert Bay.

From correspondence before me, I learned that the batteries of the plant now in use will not last the winter, and that the cost of replacing these might be saved if satisfactory arrangements could be made with the Pacific Power and Water Co. to furnish the light and power required at the School and Preventorium. I also learned that by the same arrangement the cost of replacing the gasoline engines with those of the Diesel type might likewise be saved.

It appears that Mr. Principal Anfield has talked the matter over very fully with Mr. Indian Agent Todd, and recommended that some of the "mechanical plant now in use be traded in for other electric equipment to be used should a
contract be made with the Pacific Power & Water Co., when
the proceeds from the parts disposed of would help to meet
the cost of the new equipment.

This suggestion was referred to your Commissioner
for B.C. and he advised that he was unable to agree to accept
the same.

In view of the circumstances set forth above I beg
to suggest that further consideration be given to this
important matter and that authority be given to Mr. Indian
Agent Todd and Mr. Principal Amfield to make the best arrange-
ment possible for providing the School and Preventorium with
light and power, and to dispose of some of the equipment now
in use should it be found possible to enter into a satisfactory
agreement with the Pacific Power & Water Co.

In keeping with the promise I made to you during
our interview on the 21st ultimo, I am recording for your
information a copy of the telegram I read to you at that time
and which I received while in Ottawa from Mr. Principal Amfield.
It reads as follows:

"Suggest reaching agreement with Department re
operating cost Preventorium (stop) Recommend
fixed additional per capita grant thirty cents
a day for basic number fifteen patients plus
cost light and power (stop) School lighting
plant unable handle Preventorium."

As a new set of batteries would cost approximately
$600, or nearly half that amount if the cells are retained and
new positive and negative plates installed, and as the cost of
replacing the gasoline engines now in use for those of the
Diesel type would amount to a very considerable sum, it seems
to me that from the standpoint of economy the change recommended
by the Principal deserves careful and sympathetic consideration,
and I trust that you may view the matter in the same light.
As the Preventorium is expected to be ready for occupation by
January first next, a prompt decision in the matter will be
appreciated.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

I enclose copy of a letter received from Mr. Indian Agent Todd, Kwawkewlth Agency, in the matter of heating of the classroom block of the Alert Bay Indian Residential School. I also enclose a letter from Mr. Anfield, Principal of the said school, on the matter, and tenders from Summerfield's Limited, Vancouver Iron Works and Patterson Boiler Works in connection with replacement of boilers in that building; finally, there is a copy of a letter signed by T.J. Arnall, Engineer of the Public Works Department, in which the present boiler in that building is condemned, with his remarks upon the matter. This latter letter, of course, is the one that started the correspondence.

You will see that the Indian Agent and the Principal are now using three oil burners as a temporary measure to heat this building. These burners were, and are, intended for the Preventorium which is to be erected. Both the Indian Agent and the Principal are so satisfied with the good results given by these burners that they suggest that instead of a new boiler being installed at much greater cost, that oil burners be used instead.

I wish to draw your attention to the fact that it would necessitate five burners in all, i.e., an additional two to the three now being used.

On the last page of Mr. Anfield's letter, you will see particulars as to prices of these burners and attention drawn to the fact that a saving of $800 to $900 would be made by using oil burners instead of a new boiler, and further that these oil burners seem to give even greater satisfaction than a boiler and steam plant would or has. Mr. Anfield makes the recommendation on the same page, and I concur in this, which amounts to the fact of the three burners now being used be accepted for the heating

Dear Sir,

The enclosed copy of correspondence received from Principal Anfield of the Alert Bay Residential School will be self-explanatory in respect to the new heating system for the classroom block which is found necessary owing to the boiler which is now some twenty-six years old being condemned by Mr. T.J. Arnall, Boiler Inspector.

To date I have not been officially advised by the Department that they have received from Mr. Arnall official notice that the present boiler is condemned, I only have Principal Anfield's word in which he informed me the Commissioner's office had received an official report. Mr. Arnall did, however, at the time of his inspection, inform me that the boiler would have to be replaced.

Upon receipt of the three oil burners which were purchased recently in Vancouver for the Preventorium to be loaned to the school temporarily until some arrangement could be made, I went to the school and carefully examined the efficiency of these burners in the matter of heating this building.

After taking everything into consideration, it was felt if two small 8" pot burners could be added to the three now operating, the building could be heated more cheaply and with greater efficiency and less outlay than could be done by replacing the old steam heating plant. To start with, it will cost at least $1200.00 to replace the present boiler and as all the fittings and heating system is twenty-six years old, I am of the opinion this would not stand up any length of time and the Department would be faced with replacement, which would in all probability run into $2000.00 or $2500.00 altogether.

Figuring this outlay against possibly $325.00 or $350.00 for installing five oil burners, which will no doubt give the school a better heating system, I would recommend to the Department that two more oil burners be purchased immediately and have the building heated in this manner rather than go to the great expense of the installation of a steam heating system.

Would you please advise me at your earliest convenience if you approve of the oil burners for heating rather than replacing the present system, and if so, that authority be given for the purchase of two additional 8" burners.

Your obedient servant,

Major D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Vancouver, B.C.

Dear Sir,

Attached please find bids on the installation of a new steam furnace for the classroom block at this school.

These are submitted at the request of Mr. Commissioner Mackay in Vancouver with whom I consulted on receipt of a wire to the effect that the present steam plant in this building had been condemned for further use by Mr. J. T. Arnall, Dominion Public Works Boiler Inspector.

As the school was then full to capacity with all class rooms running in this building, the Commissioner approved the suggestion that three oil burning heaters be purchased for the projected T. E. Preventorium, and used in the school block during the time that consideration of a new boiler was in hand.

These burners were purchased from the Dominion Oil Burner Distributors, Vancouver, on competitive bids secured by the writer, and were installed and operating at the school on Friday of this week.

It is understood by the Commissioner that these burners are lent for the purpose of heating the school block for the time being, and they will be stored on completion of their use, and later put into the Preventorium to be used as the heating units of that building.

In the one day's use made of these heaters it was found that they have proved splendid heating units, and in consultation with the school engineer it was decided to place before you the possibility of making them, with the addition of two other burners, the permanent heating unit of this school block. From the visit made by you to the school this morning, it was possible for you
The Indian Agent,
Alert Bay, B. C.

to form your own conclusions, and make your own recommendations to the Department.

From the school point of view, we would like to place the following before you:

(a) Value of a new steam plant in this block.

It should be borne in mind that the steam pipe and radiation system of the boiler now condemned were installed in 1912. The engineer informs me that not only has the boiler given out completely but that the steam pipe has split in several places, and that the radiation is in poor shape. It is his opinion, and in it the writer concurs, that the installation of a modern steam boiler with consequent increased pressure of an efficient installation might further weaken the present pipe and radiation. It is highly probable that following any installation of a new steam furnace, it may be necessary without warning to face the Department with the necessity of new plumbing and radiation.

The projected cost of this new boiler installed would be at least $1200.00, and we hesitate to recommend any such expenditure, having in mind the possibility of further requirements for pipe and radiation.

(b) Consideration should be given to the physical condition of the building proper before the steam installation is undertaken. The building, as mentioned before is 26 years old. No great improvements or repairs have been undertaken in the past fifteen years, and the wisdom of expensive heating installation must perforce be questionable.

(c) Value of Oil-burning heaters.

These burners are perfectly safe, passed by the underwriters and will handle adequately the heating of the classrooms. Vents have in all cases been found in existing chimneys, thus making the fire risk negligible. Manual control of these heaters by individual teachers makes it possible for each room to be kept at proper temperatures regardless of existing wind and weather conditions.
The Indian Agent,
Alert Bay, B. C.

It is my opinion that if the large 13" burner were moved from the large class room to the downstairs hallway, and a 10" burner placed in that room, with the purchase of two additional 5" burners, (one for the Home Economics room and the other for the downstairs classroom) it would adequately take care of the heating of this building until such time as it was necessary to dismantle the plant.

The present three burners have cost in the neighbourhood of $220.00, and the two additional 5" burners will cost approximately $100 f.o.b Alert Bay, and a saving of $800.00 to $900.00 is immediately obvious.

It is therefore recommended:

1. That the Department approve the use of oil burning heaters as the heating units to be employed in the school block, and that no purchase of steam equipment be made.

2. That the Department arrange for the immediate purchase of two only 5" Quaker Burnoil Heaters to be forwarded to the school immediately by the Dominion Oil Burner Distributors, Vancouver.

3. That the Department accept the vouchers for the three burners already purchased by refunding to Mr. Indian Agent Todd the amount expended thereon, these monies to be returned to the Preventorium account held in trust by him.

Will you please give your consideration to this report and advise Commissioner Mackay at the earliest possible opportunity of your recommendations thereon, so that this classroom block may have a satisfactory heating system before the winter weather sets in.

Thanking you,

Yours sincerely,

Dear Sir: Re: Boiler No.44557 B.C., Gurney Square
Sectional No. 945, Serial 106-425,
Indian Residential School, Alert Bay.

As near as I can find out this boiler was installed in
1912 and has been in continuous service since. It is used
to provide heat for the old school building.

In my 1936 report I pointed out that the metal had crystallized
and was unreliable and that the life of the boiler could not
exceed two years. In my 1937 report I stated that it should
not be used more than that first season. Upon examining it
this year I found that one section had cracked and during test
it was leaking quite freely. I must compliment the operating
engineer for carrying out my instructions to him, which have
prolonged the life of this boiler. But it has now reached
a state where something must be done before heat is supplied
to the building. Either a new boiler must be supplied or
more extensive repairs to the present one carried out.

If a new boiler is considered I would suggest a two pass
Steel Tubular one similar to those in the main boiler room,
but of the capacity of the one taken out. A square Cast
Iron Sectional boiler will cost approximately $1070.00
F.O.B. Vancouver, and a Steel Two Pass will cost approximately
$1600.00 F.O.B. Vancouver.

The building is distant about 450 feet from the main boiler
room and is of wooden construction and more or less of a fire
hazard. If it is decided to purchase a new boiler, I would
suggest that a boiler of the same size and design be purchased
as those now installed, and install it in the main boiler
room and connect to the main steam header of the school heating
system and a branch line led in the most direct manner to the
steam mains of the old school. This will mean that the steam
branch and returns will have to be led underground, but, as
the ground is easily dug, it will not add much to the cost,
which, including boiler, should not exceed $2700.00. If this
is considered, it will remove the fire hazard and also provide
an additional supply of steam for the main school.

Another method is to take out the broken section and replace
it with a new one and build a firebrick foundation for the
boiler in place of the present cast iron base. This could be
done for approximately $600.00 and would give a satisfactory
temporary job, but in any case, consideration must be given
to the weakness of the other sections of the boiler, which may
last for some time or may crack at any time, as before reported,
the metal has crystallized.

Dear Sir:

The situation with respect to heating this block was set out in a letter from this office to the Secretary dated September 28th, in which the installation of five oil burners was recommended instead of replacing the old boiler, which was condemned by the Boiler Inspector, and the replacement of which was estimated to cost at least $1200. Dear Sir:

I have received your letter of December 8th, together with copy of Dr. Westgate's letter regarding the lighting system at St. Michael's Indian Residential School, at Alert Bay.

On October 29th Mr. Indian Agent Todd wrote to this office in connection with the matter and forwarded at that time a letter he had received from Mr. Anfield, Principal of the school, in which certain suggestions for a change in the lighting system were set out but no definite recommendation made. This matter was dealt with during my absence from the office by Lieut. Colonel Pragnell, a copy of whose reply to Mr. Todd is attached hereto along with the letters referred to from Mr. Anfield and Mr. Todd, for your information. This subject was further discussed with the Agent a few days ago, and he stated he had no objection to the change being made, providing all costs involved in the switch over were met out of school funds and also that sufficient of the present equipment be retained to provide light and power, should the company fail to meet its obligations.

The Pacific Power & Water Company Ltd. are prepared to install the necessary equipment required to supply light and power to the main school and adjacent buildings and accept in payment therefor the 7 H.P. Petters engine, installed a little over a year ago by the Department at a cost of over $500.00 and now valued under the proposed change at $216.00, and also the 6 H.P. Lister gas engine and generator, which is the smaller of the two lighting plants in use at present, at a valuation of $150.00. The school would retain the larger of the two lighting plants for use as an auxiliary unit in an emergency, should occasion arise. To be of use in this connection I should imagine that new batteries would still be required and if we are called upon to supply these I cannot see where the argument that the switch over should be made in order to avoid this expense to the Department, can be maintained.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Under the proposals, there would be a sacrifice of our machinery at the prices quoted, particularly on the Petters engine, but I doubt if this constitutes a sufficient reason to object to the change being made. There would be no equipment surplus to requirements.

No information with respect to the rates the company proposes to charge for the electricity has been supplied to this office, and it is presumed that whatever these costs may be, the school is prepared to meet them from their own funds. Dear Sir,

The enclosed correspondence has been received from Principal Anfield of St. Michael's Indian Residential School Alert Bay, and will be self-explanatory.

It is noted the Principal is considering recommending to the Commission they use electric light and power from the Pacific Power & Water Company Ltd., Alert Bay, and discontinue the use of their own electric light plant in the school provided by the Department. Mr. Anfield sets forth a list of equipment required to make the switchover, and at the same time suggests the Department turn in the 7 H.P. Petters engine now used for pumping at the school well, and also the 6 H.P. Lister gas engine and generator which is a smaller unit of the present electric light plant, to the above Company, which would mean the switchover could be done without any cost to the school.

In looking up the engineer's recent report, I find he reports the electric light plant in good order with the exception that the batteries are poor. In looking back further I find last year the engineer stated the batteries should be overhauled by the resident engineer in charge, and this was reported to the Principal of the school at that time. I do not believe any effort was made by the school to have these batteries overhauled as recommended by Mr. Arnall, and this no doubt is the reason why the batteries have deteriorated so quickly.

I cannot recommend to the Department that we assume any obligation or cost in the matter of a switchover from the present lighting system in order that the school may use electrical energy from the Pacific Power & Water Company for the following reasons.

The 7 H.P. Petters engine which Mr. Anfield values at $216.00, was purchased new last year and cost over $500.00. This engine is in excellent shape and should be worth more than the value quoted by Mr. Anfield. I also feel that it should be kept intact as an auxiliary plant in case of emergency.

I am also opposed to our present electric light system being dismantled even though this small unit is getting old, as I am not satisfied that the present Company can guarantee to supply the school with continuous electrical energy. It is only a new Company starting up, and should anything happen to them it might mean the Department would be called upon to install a new electric light system at the school were we to permit the present plant to be dismantled.
I feel if the School wishes to switch over and take "city power" they should do this at their own expense and that the present equipment should be kept intact at least for the present, until such times as we are satisfied the Company can give continuous service.

Your obedient servant,

(M. S. Todd)
Indian Agent

Sir,

Your letter No.156-0-5 dated January 17th last in respect to the old tubular boiler now in storage at the Alert Bay Residential School has been received, and in reply I beg to advise you this boiler was some two years ago replaced by a larger one and has been in storage at the School ever since.

At that time the Salvage Officer requested me to try and obtain a sale for the boiler, but I was unable to do so. Later I wrote to the Department on May 17th last suggesting it be transferred to the Kwakwewlth Agency and left in my care to be used for any useful purpose I might decide; I had in mind at that time possibly I could utilize it in some Indian village for a bath house. However it was later found impossible to use it for that purpose.

On December 20th last Mr. Sharpe of Alert Bay, who owns a boat building establishment, told me he might be able to use it in his plant and offered me Twenty Dollars for it. After giving his offer due consideration I felt it was best to do something with it rather than leave it at the school to possibly rust out, and wired the Salvage Officer at Ottawa stating we had received this offer of Twenty Dollars and asked for authority to authorize the sale.

On the same date I received a telegram stating he would accept Twenty Dollars for it, and to advise the name of the purchaser.

I notified Mr. Sharpe that the Salvage Officer would accept his offer but to date he has not taken delivery of the boiler nor has he made any payment for it. Shortly after receipt of my letter Mr. Sharpe was injured and has been in the hospital ever since, and I presume that is why he has not been able to take delivery up to now.

Possibly I should have reported the matter to our Department in view of their letter of June 20th advising the old boiler could be used at some Indian village, but I was under the impression when I referred the matter back to the Salvage Officer he would immediately notify our Department at Ottawa and if they had any objection I would be so advised. When I received his telegram authorizing the sale and to accept the Twenty Dollars, I felt that everything was clear in Ottawa so far as past correspondence was concerned.

In view of your letter I shall not make delivery of the boiler until such time as I receive definite word from you. Would you kindly advise me your wishes by return mail so that I will know what to do when Mr. Sharpe comes to see me.

Your obedient servant,

M. S. Todd

Dear Sir:

I have to refer to Mr. Hoey's letter of April 13th in reply to correspondence dealing with the fire fighting intake at the Alert Bay Indian Residential School. The suggestion that an examination of the intake might be made by a local man was referred to Mr. Todd, who has reported that there is no one at Alert Bay qualified to undertake the work.

In discussing this matter with Mr. Warren of the local division of the Water and Power Bureau, he suggested that it would be best to have the work carried out in June when there would be a minus tide. At this time there would not be more than two feet of water over the intake and consequently it would be much easier, and probably less costly, to raise and examine the pipes.

In the current year's estimates provision has been made to improve the present water supply system at the Indian village of Alert Bay, and it seems to me that when our engineers are engaged on this work that it would be a good time to examine the intake of the fire fighting system of the school, provided of course the improvements to the village supply system are undertaken before the commencement of the school term in September.

In addition to the work at Alert Bay our engineers will in all probability be going up the coast in connection with work at Port Simpson, Kitkatla and Greenville, and could stop off at Alert Bay and examine the water intake at the school at that time. The question of probable costs was discussed with Mr. Warren.

Report on Fire Pump Intake.

Intake at low tide in six feet of water; time taken to prime pump, 12 minutes at half tide.

There seem to be stones in the intake valve and they prevent the flapper from closing. To clear it, it will have to be taken up by bending at the swivel joint, or by breaking one of the joints in the line and floating it out.

If it is raised the stones will roll down to the joint, and then back to the valve when it is lowered, also the swivel join, if badly corroded might leak if disturbed.

I have taken the pump apart three times to remove stones which have been carried up the pipe and had wedged in the impeller.

The new fitting installed for service to the Preventorium cannot be used until the pump is running which means running about 700 feet of hose from the nearest hydrant.

Dear Sir,

With reference to Departmental circular 502-606, file 150-65 of February 10th, 1938, issued by the Director of Indian Affairs in connection with fire prevention facilities at Residential Schools, it is necessary that the condition of the fire fighting pump intake at this school be reported to the Department forthwith, and a request made for remedial action.

If, for any reason, our domestic tank should be less than half full, it is very doubtful if this pump could be primed in time to supply water to the hydrants before the domestic tank ran dry.

Attached please find copy of report on this matter submitted to me by the school engineer. There is undoubtedly something holding the intake valve open, and it would seem that the advice of the Department's engineers should be taken before any attempt is made to check this by lifting the intake at the swivel joint. The pump has never failed to supply water to the hydrants, but the time involved in getting it through is dangerously long, and it will be appreciated if you will look this over at your convenience and advise the Department that in our opinion a situation exists which should be looked into by them without delay.

Dear Sir:

To modernize your existing gasoline driven Light Plants we have the following alternatives to offer you:

(1) FIT DIESEL ENGINES TO THE PRESENT GENERATORS

(2) ONE GENERATOR TO BE DRIVEN BY TWO ENGINES

(3) TWO DIESEL DRIVEN UNITS

By installing Diesel driven equipment it will be more economical than purchasing batteries. The average life of batteries is 4 to 5 years, and as a standard set of 110 Volt batteries cost approximately $600 to $700.00, this means a yearly charge of over $100. per year. Diesel Engines on the other hand, operating on less than one-half pint of diesel fuel per hour, it is more economical to have a small unit running to supply required current. We are pleased to quote you as follows:

(1) We could supply you with suitable diesel engines, direct connected to your present generators. The writer measured up your bases on his recent visit to Alert Bay so know that the physical dimensions of the recommended Diesels will fit on your present bases. We would propose supplying for the small unit, one 6 H.P. Single Cylinder, Lister, full Diesel, 4 Cycle solid injection engine. Price FOB, Warehouse, Vancouver..........................$390.00

For the large unit, one 12 H.P. 2 Cylinder, Lister full Diesel, 4 Cycle, solid injection engine. Price FOB, Warehouse, Vancouver..........................$590.00
Alert Bay Indian Residential School #2.

These engines would give you the same capacity as your present gasoline driven plants. Dear Sir,

Further to my covering letter of August 23rd last in respect to Estimates 1939-40, I beg to enclose you herewith letter and correspondence attached in respect to requirements for the Alert Bay Residential School, submitted by Mr. F.E. Anfield, Principal, and included in our Estimates on Sheet 9a. It was felt best to forward this correspondence so that the Department will be more familiar with Principal Anfield's requests.

Since the Estimates have been made up, Mr. T.J. Arnall of the Public Works Department has inspected the boilers and equipment at the Residential School, and informs me he is condemning certain heating equipment and that it will have to be replaced before the present winter, as it cannot be used further. Last year Mr. Arnall informed me some of this was in bad shape, and knowing this I went to the school and spent the entire time he was making his inspection with him in order to familiarize myself with his findings.

I have not to date received his report, but I believe when it does come it will be necessary for the Department to take some action in providing heat for what is known as the "Girls' Home" now used as a classroom block. This building as the Department knows, is very old, and I am of the opinion it is no longer safe to have open fires burning in the building. I am of the opinion if it is to be used further it should be heated by steam and that no fires should be permitted in the building unless it is made safe from the possible fire hazard. I do not feel I can take the responsibility if this building is continued to be used in its present state.

If the Department or the Commission do not wish to provide proper heating for this building, I would strongly recommend that the structure be closed for school purposes till such time as the present fire hazard is removed, and would also recommend that the Public Works Department be requested to make a special report as to its condition providing this building comes within their jurisdiction.

Your obedient servant,

(M.S. Todd)

When all are out inspect every bed, look under the beds, and in the night toilets for possible stragglers. Then proceed down the escape and assist with lining up and counting in the playground. Then take charge of fire fighting squad at main entrance.

In the event of an alarm, put on all light switches in your room, and proceed at once with your keys to the dormitories. The Laundress will go to Dormitory No. 6, and the Kitchen Matron to Dormitory No. 5. Put on the landing lights as you go.

See that the children cannot escape downstairs. Rouse up the children. Have them put on bloomers, shoes, sweaters or blanket, and stand at the foot of their beds.

Individual Instructions to Staff

(Cont.)

In the event of an alarm take your keys and proceed to the landing on the Boys' Side between the two junior dormitories on the second floor. See that the light is on on the landing.

Individual Instructions.

Farmer (Cont.)

When ready unlock the fire escape and have boys proceed to playground for counting or for fire squad station in front of building. The first three down are to stay at the foot of the fire escape and help juniors over the garden fence.

General instructions at foot of all the above individual instructions.

Keep the children calm - it is always a fire drill.

In all fire drills walk quietly - without fear - and our children will be safe.

These regulations are issued at the express instigation of the Superintendent General of the Department of Indian Affairs, and it is expected that all staff members will make themselves so conversant therewith that compliance in time of need will be almost automatic.

October 24th, 1938. To the men on the Staff.

Effective October 26th, the present duties of the Manual Training Instructor on fire drills, day and night, are cancelled, and are replaced by the following:

Should you hear the whistle blow a series of blasts, operate pump at full pressure, closing relief valve.
