April 27th, 1939 - General Notice to the Staff.

The copy of letter from Winnipeg herewith makes sad reading. Let us, however, take to heart the request made by Dr. Westgate and shoulder our individual responsibility towards fire danger and risk.

Please do not delude yourselves into believing that this is a fire proof building, it is far from it, and as much care and watchfulness is required here as would be needed in a building of similar size and frame construction.

Will you please make it your personal and individual responsibility to notify me without fail of anything which you consider contributory to fire risk in or about the school.

May 9th, 1939. - General Notice to the Staff.

The attention of the staff is called to the necessity of keeping rags, papers etc., away from the radiators. This creates a definite fire risk which must be avoided at all costs.

Teachers in class rooms are asked to check their stoves and see that the indicator does not go above 4 at any time. Boys playing with these stoves may leave them set in a dangerous position, and teachers should always check the indicator before starting school each session, and before leaving the classroom at the close of the day.

May I repeat the necessity of reporting anything untoward along the lines of fire hazard or risk. If at any time you notice anything wrong, any smell of burning, make it your business to report it at once to the man on duty, the night-watchman, or the undersigned.
May 30th, 1939. General Notice to the Staff.

The Night Watchman will be laid off as from Thursday morning, May 31st. This means that careful rounds must be made by the staff member on each side on duty at 10.30 p.m. each night.

Please see that all unneeded lights are out, windows closed in basements and that all taps are shut off. Keep your eyes open for possible fire risks and see that they are corrected.

The farmers will be responsible for late rounds at the barn. Will all staff members please pay special attention to lights after 10.30 p.m. Put them out wherever you see them unrequired.

Principal.
Alert Bay, B.C.,
June 14, 1939.

Sir,

On June 13th, 1939, at approximately 3:30 A.M. I was awakened by a resident of Alert Bay stating that Mr. Anfield had sent out a telephone call that the Residential School was on fire. I immediately proceeded to the School, arriving there at approximately 4 o'clock.

I found all the children and supervisors were out of the building, wrapped in blankets, and the rest of the staff were fighting the fire which at that time was under control but still burning in the walls and floors of one dormitory and the boys' sitting room. I remained at the school till approximately 7 A.M., when the fire was extinguished, doing what I could to assist in clearing up the debris in order that the school could resume its normal activities. I then arranged with Mr. Anfield Principal, to hold an investigation into the cause of the fire at 10 o'clock, and returned to the Indian Office and sent the following wires to the Department at Ottawa and the Indian Commissioner's office respectively:

Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

Reporting fire boys' dormitory and cloakrooms Residential School here early this morning. No personal injury. No interference classrooms. Maximum estimated cost labour and material One Thousand Dollars. Local labour and material available. Request authority for urgent repairs. Holding investigation cause of fire. Report following.

M.S. Todd.

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner, Vancouver.

Alert Bay, June 13th.

Fire early this morning Residential School. No personal injury. Have advised Ottawa requesting immediate repairs. Maximum estimate One Thousand Dollars.

M.S. Todd.

At 10 A.M. I returned to the School with Miss Thompson, clerk-stenographer, and questioned different members of the staff privately, and I enclose you herewith copy of their respective statements. I also enclose correspondence from Principal Anfield re Notices and Regulations of the School in regard to fire, which will be self-explanatory.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.
In my opinion the fire was caused by spontaneous combustion of oily rags left in the rubbish box in the sitting room of the junior boys. The statements made by Miss Bailey and Miss Sainsbury will be self-explanatory in this respect.

As a large portion of the floors in the dormitory and sitting room were burned entirely, it was considered urgent that immediate repairs should be made in order for the school to carry on, and I so advised the Department in my wire. At the time the wire was sent I had not had an opportunity to make a careful estimate of the cost of repairs nor could I tell at that time exactly what would be necessary owing to the condition of the building, and therefore stated in my wire One Thousand Dollars would be the maximum amount required for repairs. Since then, however, I have carefully examined all the damage and find the cost is going to be much less than originally estimated. Although we have not had time to get prices on material, it is felt from Three to Four Hundred Dollars will purchase all the material required, and Mr. Anfield has just now told me if the Department would provide this material at once, the Manual Training class will undertake to make the repairs before school closes.

The Residential School closes next week, and if the Department would approve of letting us purchase the material locally at once, we will be able to have most of the repairs done by the Manual Training Instructor and his class and this would save the Department considerable money, but if this cannot be arranged then I would recommend that the work be done by contract or day labour and completed as quickly as possible.

This report and recommendation is being forwarded the Department by "air mail" in order that we may have an early reply in case the Department can see their way clear to have the work done by the Manual Training class, in which case I would ask the Department to advise me by wire.

Your obedient servant,

(M. S. Todd)
Indian Agent
ENQUIRY BY M.S. TODD, INDIAN AGENT, INTO FIRE
at
ST. MICHAEL'S RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL
Alert Bay, B.C.
on
June 13th, 1939

Statement by Mr. F.E. Anfield, Principal:

I was awakened at 3:30 A.M. today by the ringing of the fire alarm in my residence. I proceeded to the main school with a flashlight, and went to the office and picked up a megaphone, then proceeded to both sides of the school and observed that children were already filing down the fire escapes. I then went over to the boys' side to ascertain the cause of the alarm, and on opening the door of the Lower School boys' sitting room, discovered one corner of the room in flames, with a great deal of smoke evident. I then unhooked the hydrant hose on the main floor, turned on the water, and directed the nozzle to the base of the fire, left the hose there running, and went out and made sure that the correct count of children had been reported.

I then went back to the source of the fire with the fire-fighting squad of boys and the Assistant Farm Instructor, whom I ordered to hook up the outside hydrants. I went back into the building and directed a stream of water from the inside hydrant on the fire, which was quickly put under control as far as danger to the loss of the building was concerned. By this time the main fire fighting pump was in operation and we put two main lines into the building and fought the fire from the basement toilet on the boys' side. I had also instructed the Head Matron to remove four patients from the Infirmary; had also observed the school Engineer was on the job with the domestic school pump whilst the Manual Training Instructor was in charge of the fire pump which took approximately thirty-five minutes before delivery of water was affected. This was reported to me by both the Engineer and the Manual Training Instructor.

At approximately 3:50 A.M. I called the local telephone system fire alarm and was answered by Mrs. Studly whom I requested to pass the call along. By 4 A.M. the fire was under control. I then instructed the men to cut open certain parts of the floors and ceilings of the sitting room; the interiors were flooded with water.

The action of children and staff in vacating the building was carried out most admirably; there was no panic or excitement of any kind in spite of the large volume of smoke in the dormitories on the boys' side. As soon as the fire was completely under control the children were returned to the dormitories, and a strict watch kept on the location of the fire. Hot cocoa was provided for the children working on the fire. All children whilst outside were covered with blankets; the weather was fine, and warm. By 6:30 everything was back to normal and the water all cleaned up, and the school is now functioning as usual.

From my observation I conclude that the fire started in a rubbish box in the corner of this sitting room. This room is immediately above the basement of the school and below the junior boys' dormitory.
No damage to equipment resulted from this fire, but I would estimate that damage amounting to One Thousand Dollars was done to the structure. The ceiling of the boys' downstairs toilet end of the lower school boys' sitting room will have to be replaced, and quite a lot of new joists, studding and flooring have to be put in, as well as painting. The boys' clothing room and upstairs dormitories will have to be redecorated due to smoke damage and paint blisters.

A night watchman was not on duty, he having been laid off on the 30th of May. It is customary at this school to engage a night watchman from October to the end of April, but in view of the worry caused by the loss of our Carcross School, I requested the Commission to put this man back on duty for the month of May, particularly in view of the special ceremonies in connection with the King's visit to British Columbia, which brought extra people passing through. So far as a Night Watchman is concerned I may say so far as I am aware the Department pays a grant for a night watchman for schools which are considered fire risks. I however took the stand that this school was not a fire-proof building, and years ago requested a night watchman for at least the six months of winter when the furnaces were kept going all night. It is my belief, however, that a night watchman should be on duty in this school for the entire term and I have arranged for him to return to duty tonight.

I would like to file herewith copy of Instructions to all staff members regarding fire drills, etc., and Notices issued recently in connection with danger of fire. That this training has been well done was evident to all this morning. Every child was safely out of the building inside of four and one-half minutes.

Indian Agent Todd:

What is your idea of how the fire could start in the rubbish box? Do you think there is a possibility of any of the boys smoking and throwing a cigarette butt in there?

Mr. Anfield:

No, I am certain it was not that, because the big boys have no access to that room. They are not allowed in there, it belongs to the little boys. In any case, this fire which we discovered at 3.30 could hardly have been burning from the time any boy had access to that room as they were all in bed by nine o'clock. If they had thrown a cigarette butt at that time surely it would have been discovered as rounds are made by the man on duty at ten o'clock. My opinion is that oily rags must have been in the box as I believe they oiled the floors yesterday.

Indian Agent Todd:

Are the boys permitted to smoke at all?

Mr. Anfield:

No, and the men on the staff are asked never to smoke on duty and only in their own rooms or in the staff sitting room. All dormitories are locked, and the boys have no access to the lower school boys' sitting room after they go to bed.

I might add too that the electric lighting plant ran well throughout the alarm and at approximately 4.15 I instructed the Engineer to pull the main switch in case the fire should have burned through any connections.
Statement by Mr. B.G. Chambers, Vice-Principal:

I sleep on the top floor of the building. About 3:30 I was wakened by the boys hammering on No.1 dormitory door. I got up and went down to it, and opened it and found it full of smoke. I then hurried down to the room below it, the lower school boys' sitting room, and on opening the door I could see flames from the floor going to the top of the ceiling. I shut that door, it had been closed, but not locked. When I got up the stairs Miss Turner was on the landing; she had heard the hammering too. I went and opened both dormitory doors No.3 and 4 and put all the lights on in all the dormitories and toilets and then put the fire gang on over on the far wall of No.4 dormitory. Then I unlocked the fire escape doors on No.3 and 4 dormitories and we got the boys out. They went out very quietly from both dormitories, taking a small boy each with them from the lower dormitories. The fire escape door in the lower dormitory was right above the fire.

After the boys had left the two top dormitories I made sure that there was no boy in either dormitory or in the toilets. I went round and looked under the beds and all around, then I went down and the ladies asked me to make a second check in No.1 dormitory which I did. Then I followed the boys around to the front of the building and put the fire ladder up to the Infirmary windows and carried three children down the ladder. One boy was able to come down himself. Then I went back to help Mr. Anfield.

Mr. Anfield
Do you think the fire could have started in the toilet below the sitting room?

Mr. Chambers
I do not think so; I think it started right in the corner of the lower school boys' sitting room, close to the fire escape. That is where the flames were going up. The rubbish box is gone entirely, and it is usually in the corner.

Indian Agent Todd
What was the construction of the box?

Mr. Chambers
It was a tea box, of three-ply.

Indian Agent Todd
Is there anything else in that room?

Mr. Chambers
The boys' slicker coat, but they are all there. There is a bench along the wall, the end of it is charred.

Mr. Anfield
Do you think that the fire could have been prevented in any way by having that door locked?

Mr. Chambers
I do not think so, not if it started from what we think it did. Mr. Hill said he was in there about 10:30 so it could not have been from a match or cigarette stub or he would have noticed it.
Mr. Anfield

Have you any suggestions to make in regard to the fire protection system in regard to the removal of children?

Mr. Chambers

The children were perfectly safe getting out and were very quiet and orderly, but I did think if we had a man at the foot of the fire escape it might be a help in a really serious case. One thing I would suggest would be to have some kind of mask a person could put on in case of emergency to check the children. I thought that this morning when I went into that room; if there had been children in it you would have to get them, and if the smoke had been a little bit thicker you could not do anything.

Mr. Anfield

Have you fire instructions posted in your room?

Yes.

Did you follow them?

Yes.

How long have you been in the School?

Nine years and two months.

Statement of Mr. F. Hutchinson, Manual Training Instructor

My duty in case of fire is to go down and start the sea-water fire pump. At approximately 3:30 this morning I heard the fire bell ringing, and got a few clothes on and ran down and started to prime the fire pump and while I was waiting to prime it I gave the engine a turn over to warm it up, then waited till Mr. Ward came down. About 2 minutes after 4 exactly we had it going. We have to wait until the fresh water gets into it and primes it. If it was efficient it would be primed right off the bat. The tide was very low but I could not see the intake of the pump line. If the pump had been working properly we would not have had any difficulty. I stayed there for three minutes then Mr. Ward told me to come up here and help you out and he looked after it from then.

Mr. Anfield

We are trying to ascertain the cause of the fire. As Manual Training Instructor, did you give out any oil, linseed, or turps yesterday?

Mr. Hutchinson

I gave some oil to Miss Bailey to do the floors. A little boy came in and he took the wrong tin; instead of the floor oil he took the linseed oil. Miss Bailey remarked to me after how much further it went, and I explained to her that it was linseed oil instead of the regular floor oil they generally use.

Mr. Anfield

I am going to ask you a personal question - what time did you come in last night? Did you notice any smoke or light of any kind as you came in?

Mr. Hutchinson

I came in about 12:30, by the back dormitory door. The windows were all closed so I would not have noticed smoke, but I would have seen a glow if there had been one, as it was pitch black. The last time I was in that sitting room was about 6 o'clock last night, I looked in when I came off duty.
Mr. Anfield
Did you ever see anybody smoke in there?

Mr. Hutchinson
No.

Mr. Anfield
What is the rule?

Mr. Hutchinson
Staff are not permitted to smoke while on duty.

Mr. Anfield
Have you fire instructions in your bedroom?

Mr. Hutchinson
I have; all I did this morning was what I was supposed to do.

Mr. Anfield
Those instructions are in writing?

Yes.

Mr. Anfield
Have you any suggestions to make that would improve the system of fire protection?

Mr. Hutchinson
The only thing is to have a buzzer in the dormitory so that the children could signal the supervisors in a case like this. Also to have one man free to go to the seat of the trouble, to have no other duty.

Mr. Anfield
I consider that my first duty and the first duty of every staff member is to see that the school is clear of children; that they are all safe first, then we can concentrate on the fire, but the children come first.

Indian Agent Todd
Did you see that box that was in the room yesterday?

Mr. Hutchinson
I just noticed it, I did not see it closely or what was in it.

Mr. Anfield
What are those boxes used for generally?

Mr. Hutchinson
Just to keep the room tidy, to thrown dirt and orange papers into. The floors are swept and the dirt and garbage are thrown into it and it is taken away in the morning. They are usually emptied at 6 o'clock at night of the day's rubbish, and it is only the night sweepings that are left over night.

Mr. Anfield
From your observation where did the fire originate?

Mr. Hutchinson
In the corner where that box was kept in the boys' sitting room, immediately under the boys' dormitory, right next to the fire escape door.

Mr. Anfield
How long did it take you from the time you woke up till you got to the engine?

Mr. Hutchinson
About two minutes; I had everything ready, but it took about half an hour to get that pump primed and going. If we hadn't had the fresh water tank full we would not have had a chance. Mr. Ward started the domestic pump first; I can't start my engine until it is fully primed.
Statement of Miss L. Bailey, Boys' Supervisor

I imagine it was about 3:30, I didn't look at my watch, we heard the boys knock and Miss Finley and I both got up. We heard the door of No.2 dormitory open and Mr. Chambers went in. When we went out of our room Miss Finley went to No.1 and I went to No.2 and found the boys ready to go out with blankets over their shoulders. Miss Finley had opened the fire escape door in No.1 dormitory and Mr. Chambers had opened the one in No.3 and 4; I waited till his boys came down and one big boy took one little boy and we proceeded; we had started when Mr. Chambers had the fire bell ringing. There was no disturbance or any excitement. I counted each boy as they passed and the number was right. They were counted four or five times altogether then we reported to Mr. Anfield.

Yesterday morning I oiled the boys' sitting room floor and the two hallways. We did not put much on, we only had about three inches in the nail, just enough to stop the dust. I helped the boys do it. We got the oil from Mr. Hutchinson. I asked for floor oil but I didn't know till the afternoon that the boys had made a mistake and got the wrong kind. I think it was linseed oil they got. We didn't have very much but it went a long way. After we finished our floors I asked Miss Sainsbury if she would like the boys to help her do her classroom floor and at 4 o'clock we went to her room, she was there too, and we took the cloths we had used and wiped them over her floor. We used every bit of oil up, in fact the cloths were almost dry when we finished, but they were very dusty. When we got through Miss Sainsbury remarked to me about being careful of the rags, so I said to the boys "Put them in the garbage can" and I said "Be sure and put them outside", and Miss Sainsbury said "Yes, put them outside". We stressed the point. The boys went and put the rags away, and they came back and said "We have finished, Miss Bailey". I said "Did you do what I said", and they said "Yes". By this time prayer bell had gone.

After supper we tidied up our sitting room, swept the floor and picked up anything around. We had emptied the garbage can in the afternoon so we put the dirt in the garbage can. The boys did the sweeping up. I didn't look into the can, I didn't know they had put the rags in there. We usually empty the garbage can at night, but there wasn't any dirt. I got my boys this morning and asked them if they put the rags in the inside garbage box or in the outside can, and they told me in the box.

Mr. Anfield

Thank you Miss Bailey for your very frank statement. What we wanted to know was how the fire started and if there was any possibility of incendiary action. It would appear it was spontaneous combustion with all the dust on the rags down in the bottom of the box.
Mr. W. Hill, Assistant Farm Instructor.

Mr. Anfield You were on duty last evening?

Mr. Hill Yes.

Q. Did you make rounds?
A. Yes, at 10.30.

Q. Did you visit the lower boys' sitting room?
A. Yes, it was the first place I went to. I closed the windows.

Q. Did you notice this garbage box?
A. No, not particularly; I went in with my flashlight.

Q. Was there any sign of fire?
A. No. I noticed the smell of the newly oiled floor.

Q. You have read these Notices put up recently about fire?
A. Yes, I have.

Q. Did you lock the door of the room?
A. No, I closed it but did not lock it.

Indian Agent When you make your rounds do you ever look into any of these waste paper boxes inside the building?

A. No. Last night was my first night that I made the rounds. I am new at the school and Mr. Coulard has been making the rounds but our duties have been changed.

Q. You did not see any boys around the school last night after 9 o'clock?

A. No, they were all in bed. I was upstairs with the boys till 10 o'clock, then I came down and Mr. Chambers was there. He said he would be up there. I made rounds at 10.30. I went to the kitchen and the boys' basement downstairs, everything was alright.

Miss Sainsbury, Teacher

Mr. Anfield We would like you to answer a few questions, about the oil that was used yesterday.

Miss Sainsbury Miss Bailey came to me and said she was going to have the floors oiled, and asked if I would like to have my classroom done. I said it was very dusty and some oil might improve it. At 4 o'clock she came and said could we do it then because she didn't want to keep it she would send it back to the Manual Training Shop if there was any left and I didn't want it. So she came in with two boys, there was very little oil left in the bottom of the pail. We got the rags she had used and they did the floor. There was only enough to do the front part of my classroom. When we finished, I said to her "Be careful about the rags, where are they going to put them?" She said, "outside".
I said, "You know I am very frightened about rags; I never have them in my classroom because I am afraid they might explode or something". She said, "We will put them outside in the garbage can".

In the evening I went back to my classroom after I came off duty and I thought I smelled an odor; it did not seem like fumes, it was just a strong smell of oil. I went into the boys' sitting room and said to Miss Finley "I think I will open these windows but they have to be closed at ten o'clock and I do not think I will be in my classroom. There seems to be a strong odor around here". I asked her who was on duty and she said "Mr. Hill". I saw Mr. Hill and if he would see that the windows were closed and he said he would.

During the time I was in my classroom Mr. Anfield came to the door and I noticed when he opened the door there was a strong odor and I wondered if it was in my classroom or outside. I went to the register and smelled it and it wasn't there and then I spoke to Mr. Anfield. I was not really worried about fire but it was on my mind because of this odor, but I remembered about the floors. I went to bed about 10.30 and was up when the bell rang, I did not smell anything, I am on the girls' side and the control door was closed.

Mr. W. Hill, Assistant Farm Instructor

Indian Agent
When you went into the room last night to close the windows did you smell a strong odor in there?

Mr. Hill
Yes, I noticed it but I thought it to be the newly oiled floors. It was not very strong, I presume the windows being open had killed it. I went straight to the windows and closed them.

Indian Agent
Mr. Anfield, is it customary to oil the floors in the school?

Mr. Anfield
Yes, the floors on the boys' side and the auditorium where there is hard wear are oiled about four or five times a year.

Mr. W. Ward, Engineer

Mr. Anfield
You used the other water supply first, the domestic supply?

Mr. Ward
Yes, I went straight up to that pump and then down to the other pump house.

Indian Agent
Did you have any difficulty getting the water in the pump?

Mr. Ward
Yes, "Hutch" was down there from about 3.30; it was just after 4 when we got it pumping.

Q.
What is the cause of the delay?

A.
It is the priming; it is caused through the faulty intake.
Indian Agent
How long has this situation existed?

Mr. Ward For the last eighteen months it has gradually been getting worse.

Indian Agent
Was the domestic pump running all the time?

Mr. Ward Yes; as soon as I was notified I went up and it started in a couple of minutes. I make it a point that that tank is full every night; it was full last night at 10 o'clock. The capacity is 15,000 gallons.

Indian Agent
Did the equipment work alright when you got it working?

Mr. Ward Yes, except that it is hard to prime and towards the end it lost its prime and would not pump enough.

Indian Agent
If this intake is repaired, will it be alright?

Mr. Ward Yes. If it is repaired it can have full pressure in 45 seconds. The way it is now you just have to wait, and the way it is now there is no fire protection for the Preventorium except our own domestic pump.
Ottawa

Dear Sir,

Further to correspondence regarding the damage done in the recent fire at this school, attached please find copy of letter from the Indian Agent, Alert Bay, of even date. You will note that the School is expected to supply the labour and in this connection it is necessary to make the following statement:

On the date after the fire, i.e., on June 14th, I interviewed Mr. Indian Agent Todd and informed him that the School Manual Training Instructor, and a class of twelve boys, were prepared and willing to do this work provided that authority was issued to purchase materials immediately. I notified Mr. Todd officially that the school would be closing inside of ten days, and that if action was not taken at once, we would be unable to carry this out. I understand from Mr. Todd that on June 17th authority was wired from Ottawa to make the necessary purchases. The material is just starting to arrive now, almost one month from the date of the fire.

The Manual Training Instructor is away on his Summer School course, following which he will take two weeks vacation. We have no boys in school capable of undertaking this work without skilled supervision. The few boys we have in school are kept more than occupied on the farm and other essential work at the school. All the boys really capable of doing this work are on vacation and most of them are graduates in any case.
The Secretary,
I. R. S. C., M.S. C. C.

Under the circumstances, it would hardly seem reasonable to expect the school to supply labour for this task, and after consultation with the Indian Agent, I would ask that you lay this matter before Ottawa forthwith with the request that authority be telegraphed to engage two men to proceed with this work immediately.

My estimate for labour was two men, 15 days each at $5.00 a day, total $150.00. Every effort will be made to have the job completed within or less than the estimated time. It is imperative that the work be placed in hand at once as there are gaping holes in the floors and charred walls in the basement and sitting rooms affected, not to mentioned the water-spoiled walls.

I am sure that Ottawa does not realise that there has been such a delay somewhere and that the only material so far received is the sheet metal ceiling which arrived last week.

The Department authorized a grant of $145.00 to pay the fares of graduating pupils, and it may help to point out to them that following a strenuous effort, it was possible to get the parents to meet all of this amount but $30.00, leaving $115.00 unspent, which the Department might be able to apply on this work of repair.

There are two good carpenters available, Mr. Fred Sharpe and Mr. H. McCuaig, both of whom have worked before at this school for the Department. A good helper is also available, a Mr. R. Thompson, who also has worked here before, so any, or all, would be acceptable to the local member, I'm sure.

If, for any reason, the Department is unable to unwilling to sanction this labour cost, I am compelled to ask immediate authority to engage same and charge to the Commission.

Sincerely yours,

Extract from Inspector Barry's report on the Alert Bay Indian residential school dated June 27, 1939.

Following the late fire at Alert Bay school I have a number of recommendations to make. These will involve the expenditure of a substantial sum of money, and I would ask that such suggestions be taken into consideration in the drawing of the plans for the proposed new residential school in the West Coast Agency.

(a) Two new escapes are required on the ends of the main building. One iron escape of simple design is required from the infirmary in the front of the main building.

The present escapes follow the general line of the stairs on each side of the school, and it is up the stair well that flames and smoke may be most likely to cut off the escape of the children. Escapes of course should not follow the same general direction down the outside of the school as the stairs do inside. In the present case the whole stair well on the boys' side was full of smoke, and through the fact that the boys and girls from the front dormitories and the supervisors had to pass across the stairs well to gain other dormitories and fire escapes they encountered dangers to which they should not have been exposed.

Doors should be cut between the dormitories on the upper or second floor to allow the children in front dormitories access to the escapes through the rear dormitories on the same floors.

Cubicles for supervisors should be constructed in each dormitory. These should be located near the doors to fire escapes. The latter should be kept unlocked and the way to them should be through the supervisors cubicle itself as in many of our schools. No doors in the school should be locked but they should all be protected by electrical alarms as suggested in former reports on different schools.

(Sgd.) Gerald H. Barry.

Sir,

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of August 4th last, file 156-0-5 in connection with the old boiler at the Residencial School which was sold to Mr. James Sharpe of Alert Bay.

Since I wrote you last I have asked Mr. Sharpe on several occasions to make payment for the boiler as agreed, and he has always told me he would bring the money in to the office in a few days. At the present time he is moving his boat building establishment from one location to another and as he cannot use it until he gets settled in his new quarters, I am inclined to think this is the cause of the delay in not paying for it, as he has no place to which to move it at the present time.

I would suggest that you leave the matter in abeyance for a short time longer and if he does not pay for it as soon as he takes up his new location, I will write you giving a definite recommendation at that time.

Your obedient servant,

Memorandum:

PURCHASING AGENT

Re: Disposal of old tubular boiler at Alert Bay Indian Residential School

On August 22, Indian Agent Todd replied to official communication in this connection, as follows:

"Since I wrote you last, I have asked Mr. Sharpe on several occasions to make payment for the boiler, as agreed, and he has always told me he would bring the money in to the office in a few days. At the present time he is moving his boat building establishment from one location to another and as he cannot use it until he gets settled in his new quarters, I am inclined to think this is the cause of the delay in not paying for it, as he has no place to which to move it at the present time".

No further information has been received from Mr. Todd, with respect to this boiler. He is being written again today.

Yours truly,

Dear Sirs:

Re: Alert Bay Indian School

We thank you for the opportunity of quoting on two Diesel engines to replace existing gasoline engines at the above school, and we are offering the latest type of Petter cold starting, full Diesel engine, as described in bulletin herewith.

We note that while your enquiry calls for 6 HP and 12 HP, the specification states that engines will be of 6½ HP and 14 HP. We are therefore offering our standard 8 HP and 15 HP, and you will note that in both cases we will reduce the standard speed of our engines somewhat in order that they may be direct coupled to existing generators.

These engines are true cold starting engines, and they are very readily cranked without compression, and after the flywheels are in motion a decompressor valve is closed, when they start instantly without external heating devices.

We would say that we have supplied a large number of them for electrical work, for which they are well suited, as they are fitted with a very sensitive governor and all told we have made approximately 600 installations of Petter engines in B.C. We are glad to quote as follows -

1 - 8 HP Petter Atomic cold starting Diesel Engine,
arranged for direct coupling by means of semi-flexible Renolds coupling to existing generator.

Engine to be complete with radiator, fan and pump, fuel tank with piping and fittings, exhaust piping and exhaust pot, and steel sub-base on which will be mounted your present generators. We also provide for starting handle and standard set of spare parts and tools.
1 - 15 HP Petter Atomic cold starting Diesel Engine, to the same specification as above.

We provide in our tender for complete installation of the above engines at Alert Bay, together with the labour involved in the installation of all exhaust, fuel and water piping, etc., leaving all in running order.

We provide also for the changes in the wiring as mentioned in the specification.

Price of the two engines, installed at Alert Bay, including 8% sales tax. . . . . . . . . . . . . . $1,998.00

Delivery -

At time of writing we have these engines in Vancouver stock, and our prices are based on the assumption that this order will be placed promptly, as the costs of deliveries from the English factory at this time are likely to be increased in the near future.

Regarding the allowance for the old equipment, we regret we have not had an opportunity of inspecting same, but if awarded the contract we would be glad to make an offer on the existing engines.

Hoping this meets with your approval, we are,

Yours very truly,

INTRODUCTION

These small Diesel Engines which we introduced some years ago have become increasingly popular and the rapidly growing demand for them is sufficient indication of the satisfaction which they give to purchasers.

We place reliability in the forefront in all considerations of design and the selection of material for component parts.

The simple, compact, enclosed design of these Engines combined with the ability to start from cold without any form of pre-heating, has led to their adoption by manufacturers of all kinds of driven machinery, such as concrete mixers, road rollers, air compressors, dynamos, pumps, etc. For every purpose where power is required on the farm, plantation, mine, etc., they are eminently suitable.

Having a power impulse per cylinder at every revolution of the crankshaft, they run with a smoothness and regularity which makes them particularly suitable for generating electricity and for other purposes where cyclic regularity is important.

Among the design features which contribute to the reliability, economical running, and long life of these Engines are:

1. The absence of inlet and exhaust valves in the cylinder head, which is of strong symmetrical design, leads to freedom from breakdown due to loss of compression or cracked cylinder heads. The water spaces are readily accessible for cleaning.

2. Bearings are of ample size having considerable margin over load requirements. The material used is of the highest quality specially selected for the required duty.

3. Lubricating oil is supplied by a Calibrator lubricator, under pressure, to the cylinders as well as to the large and small end bearings. There is no fuel dilution of the lubricating oil.

The fuel consumption is, we believe, lower than that of any other engines of the same power and can be taken at working load not to exceed 0.40 to 0.45 pints per b.h.p. hour.

The Engines are rated well within their maximum power and conform to B.S.I. conditions in this respect.

We recommend them with assurance, based upon long experience, to all requiring power for any purpose.

INTRODUCTION

THESE small Diesel Engines which we introduced some years ago have become increasingly popular and the rapidly growing demand for them is sufficient indication of the satisfaction which they give to purchasers.

We place reliability in the forefront in all considerations of design and the selection of material for component parts.

The simple, compact, enclosed design of these Engines combined with the ability to start from cold without any form of pre-heating, has led to their adoption by manufacturers of all kinds of driven machinery, such as concrete mixers, road rollers, air compressors, dynamos, pumps, etc. For every purpose where power is required on the farm, plantation, mine, etc., they are eminently suitable.

Having a power impulse per cylinder at every revolution of the crankshaft, they run with a smoothness and regularity which makes them particularly suitable for generating electricity and for other purposes where cyclic regularity is important.

Among the design features which contribute to the reliability, economical running, and long life of these Engines are:

1. The absence of inlet and exhaust valves in the cylinder head, which is of strong symmetrical design, leads to freedom from breakdown due to loss of compression or cracked cylinder heads. The water spaces are readily accessible for cleaning.

2. Bearings are of ample size having considerable margin over load requirements. The material used is of the highest quality specially selected for the required duty.

3. Lubricating oil is supplied by a Calibrator lubricator, under pressure, to the cylinders as well as to the large and small end bearings. There is no fuel dilution of the lubricating oil.

The fuel consumption is, we believe, lower than that of any other engines of the same power and can be taken at working load not to exceed 0.40 to 0.45 pints per b.h.p. hour.

The Engines are rated well within their maximum power and conform to B.S.I. conditions in this respect.

We recommend them with assurance, based upon long experience, to all requiring power for any purpose.

VIVIAN POWER for CAPE MUDGE LIGHTING PLANT!

There'll be jewelled lights along the shore at Cape Mudge this winter, for the Indians of that settlement have put in a new electric light plant. The chief leader, thirty-five horsepower Vivian diesel will supply the power and the tribesmen are doubling the capacity of the previous plant.

This is a climax to a series of achievements going back three generations. They have transformed primitive Indian encampments into what has every appearance of a white settlement. Many years ago, Cape Mudge village on Quadra Island, home of the Cape Mudge natives, was just a selection of wooden, windowless shacks unmarked by any sign of civilization. Today, the village is a thriving community, particularly that of the present Chief Billy Assu, its amenities include electric light, a modern water system and a community hall.

Chief Billy Assu, now sixty-five years old, has seen most of his life's work done from behind a big modern house built of cedar with a high protective wall. Now he has a modern home with electric light, bath and radio. When he was ten years old, he went to school, but his father was working for one of the farmers. While he was watching a ship unload, a barrel fell over him. He picked up some of the white stuff that fell out and crammed it in his mouth. That was his first taste of sugar.

When he was twenty-five he became a chief and then he married my late famous missionary, Thomas Crosby, and became a Christian. Next year the first white missionary came to Cape Mudge. His name was Mr. Wilson and he was Mr. Crosby, and he remained in the district forty years. Under the guidance of Mr. Wilson and the influence of his wife, the Cape Mudge Indians rapidly progressed into the prosperous community they are today.

Billy is one of the picturesque characters of the old-time Indians. His wise and able leadership of his tribe was honoured in 1937 when he was presented with one of three Coronation medals given to British Columbia natives. The decoration was given to him by M. S. Todd, Indian agent at Alert Bay. The silver medal bears an inscription which reads: "By command of His Majesty King George VI, Chief Billy Assu is decorated with this Coronation medal in recognition of services rendered to the Indian people."

Chief Billy has three sons and one Dan, is a leader in the United Church at Cape Mudge.

When you drive along the Island Highway in the evening and the lights at Campbell River turn on, you see the lights twinkling from the houses on Quadra Island across the swift waters of Discovery Passage, a memorial to the progress of the last three generations and another example of what these natives hope to continue to do in the future.

"GIVE ME A VIVIAN"

—Says Capt. J. Shannon

"Give me a sturdy boat and a Vivian," says Captain Jack Shannon, owner of the Shannon J., and leave the rest to me." He is so well satisfied with the performance of his 3 cylinder, 60 horsepower Vivian diesel that next year he is building—the Shannon M—will be fitted with a 4 cylinder, 80 horsepower model.

Jack's father was the pioneer otter trawler on Quadra Island. He knew four sons and a grandson carry on the tradition he started in 1912. Traditionally, trawling for ground fish was done on big boats with a cumbersome pole which often proved dangerous in a pitching boat. Even now, as fishermen know, the "otter board" call for speed is vital in handling. The boat must maintain a steady pull of 1½ to 2 knots so that the net rests on the bottom; go too fast and the boards may come off the bottom; too slow and the boards may get stuck deep in the mud. So Jack turns to Vivians for an engine that gives him steadily, even power for long periods of towing.

One great feature of Jack's new engine is its Wide Drive. This is a special Vivian feature. The Wide Drive is built in at the back of the engine, making the engine more compact and allowing more space below. But Jack, like every other Vivian user, is enthusiastic about his engine as a whole. He has had his 60 horsepower engine for four years, and it is still running away from him. All the time he has never had a moment's delay. Previously, he had two Vivian gas engines, the first of which he bought in 1915. Jack particularly emphasizes the saving made by Vivian Diesels: whereas his operating costs with the gas engines averaged $50 weekly, the Diesel has reduced that figure to $11.

Jack has had his share of pioneering and adventure. He was one of the original pioneers who founded the grey cod fillet curing industry in 1938. Grey cod are caught periodically in large quantities and are fished for by the fish. Prior to 1938 there had been no market for them. Jack turned grey cod to profitable use when he began to cure them for curing.

Daring has claimed him too. Once his vessel was negotiate Seymour Narrows and the man on watch neglected to call Jack and anchor above the Narrows until the tide came. After bucking its way through the Narrows, the tide rip forced the boat over towards Ripple Rock Whirlpool. For several minutes it hung on the edge of the whirlpool, depending entirely on the strength of its engine to fight the current. If the Vivian Diesel had stopped, there could have been no Jack Shannon here today. But the Vivian never faltered and, after the tide eased, took the boat and its occupants safely to port.

Gray & Jack's Fast Stepping "Sumas"

One of the fastest tow-boats in Port of Vancouver service is the 40-foot Sumas, owned by George Jack, a 40-foot ship powered by a 6 cylinder, 120 horsepower Vivian Diesel.

The Sumas is used extensively to tow and conduct a general towing business. We had heard, some time before, several reports about these boys being able to pull a big string of logs or scows on time, but we had to pin Hugh against the wheel-house of the Sumas before we could get him down his modesty and get him to tell the truth.

Towing 175,000 feet of lumber to Victoria (from Port Ceres) through heavy seas, winds and choppy water didn't seem much of a feat to Gray & Jack, but we got our report from Hugh that they did it. They made an average speed of 3½ miles per hour. Now that isn't much for a big towboat, but the Sumas is not a big boat, only 40 feet long, and when you get 175,000 feet of lumber on the end of the line building up a wind you've got to be careful to make that time.

To see the Sumas licking it up False Creek you'd think she was going twice as fast. Hugh claims that this illusion is gained by the way she sits in the water, that her draft has been lowered and when she hits it up she pushes the sea away from all sides.

Gray & Jack have been doing some experimenting with their Vivian Diesel and they think they've got it just about right for good towing.

Great boosters for the Vivian engine, Gray & Jack think there's nothing like them. The Sumas was formerly powered by a 60 horsepower Vivian gas engine. It was the remarkable performance put up by this motor that resulted in their buying the big Vivian Diesel.

Introduction

The modern cold starting oil engine stands for reliability and economy. It has long passed its experimental stage, and is now used as a power unit in every industry, on all kinds of land and sea transport and in every country in the world.

The present day mechanical injection oil engine (now known as a Diesel engine) has evolved from the original British patents of Herbert Akroyd Stuart, of 1892, under which the world's first commercially successful oil engine was manufactured at our Grantham Works in 1892. Thousands of engines of this early type were produced at Grantham, and many are still in service.

The excellent service which these early engines have given has set a high standard, and the proof that this standard has been maintained is provided by the fact that Ruston & Hornsby Ltd. are today the largest manufacturers of oil engines in the British Commonwealth.
The Works in which Ruston Oil Engines are produced are up-to-date in every respect. They include a modern foundry, forge, machine, erection and test shop, a well-equipped model works, a laboratory where all materials are tested and a special shop for the manufacture of fuel pumps and atomisers.

A new self-contained section of the works has been erected for the production of the small vertical oil engines described in this publication. This new section includes machine shop, erection, test, painting and despatch all under one roof.

Entirely new equipment has been installed, and the most up-to-date production methods have been instituted in order to provide the greatest possible accuracy of workmanship without the high prices which the high quality of the product would otherwise necessitate.

The Ruston Foundry has recently been equipped with a mechanised section in which all small castings are produced. The addition of this new section makes the foundry one of the most up-to-date in the country; there is indeed, no foundry in existence that is better able to produce castings of the type needed for small oil engines.

Some Features

The ease with which Ruston engines can be started is due to the design of the combustion chamber and injection system. The engine is turned by hand with the compression released, and after about three turns the fuel pump is brought into action and full compression applied. The engine fires instantly. This applies equally to engines working in tropical climates and to those in cold damp atmospheres.

The simple, straightforward design of the combustion chamber is responsible for a highly efficient combustion which is reflected in economical working. For the same reason the engine is very clean internally and will run for long periods without decarbonising. A wide range of distillate fuels may be used. In general the specific gravity should not be greater than 0.88 and the viscosity not greater than 50 seconds at 100° F. (Redwood No. 1).
It is only the work of a few seconds to remove the easily detachable covers to gain access to all working parts, which are protected from dirt and drainage while the engine is running, but which are readily accessible for inspection, cleaning or adjustment.

This feature together with the adequate filtering of inlet air and fuel, renders these engines suitable for working in dusty or other impure atmospheres.

Note also the robust simplicity of the design.

The general design of the bedplate and housing, which are formed by a single casting, can be seen in the illustration on this page. The cylinder heads are separate castings carrying the valves, rocking levers and overhead valves.

The valves are made of special heat resisting steel, and the stems are fitted with hardened renewable steel caps. A useful feature of the cylinder head design is that the atomisers can be removed without draining the water jackets.

Renewable cylinder liners of the wet type are used. They are of centrifugally cast iron and are nitrogen hardened.

So thoroughly is the hardening done that if one of these liners is broken up, the hardened edges of the fragments are of sufficient hardness to cut glass.

Note the expansion joint formed by two rubber rings round the liner near the bottom.

Cast iron pistons are fitted and are provided with three pressure rings and one scraper ring.

The gudgeon pin is of the floating type which is able to carry with safety greater pressures than a fixed pin could take. Lubrication, moreover, is more certain with a floating pin, which therefore has longer wearing qualities.

The design and performance of these engines gives free working piston rings and prevents the sticking of rings common in many high speed engines.

The fuel is injected by a fuel pump of the plunger-release type. On multi-cylinder engines a separate pump is provided for each cylinder and is mounted alongside the cylinder which it serves. The fuel pump plungers are actuated direct from the camshaft.

The atomisers are of simple design and need no attention beyond an occasional cleaning.

The crankshaft is a solid steel forging, forged in our own works and machined to fine limits. The material is tested in our own laboratory.

The crankshaft is accurately balanced and is drilled to take the lubricating oil under pressure to the large end bearings.

The camshaft is of steel and is machined from the solid. The valve cams are hardened and ground. The overhead valves are actuated by rigid push rods and rocker arms mounted on the cylinder head. Valve adjustments are easily made after the removal of the valve cover.

The fuel oil is filtered twice before it is injected into the cylinder. A filter mounted on the side of the engine strains the oil before it reaches the fuel pump, and a further small filter is placed in the fuel line between the pump and the atomisers.
The lubrication is by forced feed from a gear type pump placed below the level of the oil in the sump, and delivering oil through oilways cut in the crankshaft to the main and big end bearings. The cylinder liners are lubricated by splash, whilst the valve gear is lubricated by cups screwed in the valve cover. This method of valve lubrication is extremely simple and avoids the complications of a complete pressure system. The cups can be screwed down whilst the engine is running.

USTON small vertical oil engines are the outcome of long experience and research. They are 4-stroke compression ignition engines running on the lighter grades of Diesel oils such as those commonly used in "Diesel-engined" road vehicles.

The fuel is today easily obtainable almost everywhere, and since it is non-volatile it is free from spontaneous fire risk, and is not subject to considerable loss through evaporation when stored in comparatively large quantities.

Steady vibrationless running is a feature of these small engines. The exhaust can be effectively silenced, and when the engine is enclosed in a well-built outhouse very little sound can be heard outside. These engines are simple to run and maintain. They start by hand from cold and can be looked after by a chauffeur, gardener, tractor driver, or any intelligent man or youth. Simplicity has been obtained by skilful design and not in any case at the expense of performance. The sectional drawing on the centre page of this leaflet reveals the whole design of the engine and illustrates the robust construction of all parts. Uses for which they are ideal include; the lighting of country houses; providing power for small workshops, dairies, farm buildings, etc.; driving concrete mixers, elevators and conveyors, and other equipment requiring a built-in power unit, and a multitude of other purposes for which a limited supply of power is needed.
The ease with which engines in this series can be started is one of their outstanding features. The engine is turned by hand with the compression fully released. When sufficient speed has been attained (usually after 3 turns) full compression is put on and the fuel pump is brought into action. The engine fires instantly.

Factors which contribute to the lasting qualities of these engines are—

1. Smooth running due to sound design.
2. Freedom from delicate parts.
3. First-class materials and workmanship.
4. Rigid inspection during manufacture, including our own laboratory test on materials used.

The illustration shown above illustrates the simple nature of the engine and its robust construction. Note for example, the straightforward design of the cylinder head also the simplicity of the governor and speeder gear by which the speed of the engine can be varied while running.

The design of the combustion chamber ensures economical combustion of the fuel. This in turn means low fuel consumption, a clean engine and a clean exhaust. Thus fuel costs and maintenance costs will both be low. The cost for fuel and lubricating oil works out at approximately £1 to £4 per B.H.P. hour.

LOW FUEL CONSUMPTION

(Redwood No. 1).

CLEAN RUNNING

Because of the efficient combustion the engine is very clean internally, and will run for long periods without de-carbonizing or cleaning.

PISTON RINGS

The design and running performance of these engines ensures clean running, gives free working piston rings and prevents the sticking of rings so common in many high speed engines.

LONG LIFE

The factors which contribute to the lasting qualities of these engines are:

DESCRIPTION OF ENGINE

THE ENGINE is provided with a specially designed Combustion Head incorporating the "Lister Patent Combustion Chamber," which ensures a positive start from cold by hand without need of Cartridge, Heating Lamp or Electric Ignition. A variable compression ratio initially ensures easy starting and subsequent running at low maximum pressures.

THE CYLINDER BORE is treated with the LISTARD process of chrome hardening (Van der Horst Patents) which has been proved to give the greatest wear resisting surface yet known, whether the wear may be due to heat, chemical action or abrasion from the piston rings; thus giving a greatly lengthened life throughout which the engine retains its ease of starting, fuel and lubricating oil consumption, and develops rated power.

THE PISTON AND RINGS are of high grade material, and finished to an accuracy equal to that employed in the finest motor car engine. Long life and full compression are thus assured.

THE CRANKCASE is totally enclosed and dust proof, making the engine especially suitable for work in dusty and gritty surroundings.

THE CRANKSHAFT is made from high grade steel, accurately machined and finished by grinding to an accuracy of half of one thousandth of an inch. It is extended beyond the Flywheel on both sides allowing the pulley or coupling to be fitted on either side or if necessary a pulley on each side.

THE CAM, CAMSHAFT AND ROCKERS are of high grade steel, accurately machined. The working surfaces are hardened and finished by grinding.

THE CONNECTING ROD is a Steel forging with renewable bearing at both ends. The small end Bush is of Phosphor Bronze and the large end bearing is of Steel Shells lined with white metal.

THE BEARINGS for Crankshaft are of ample size to provide maximum durability.

THE ENGINE is provided with a specially designed Combustion Head incorporating the "Lister Patent Combustion Chamber," which ensures a positive start from cold by hand without need of Cartridge, Heating Lamp or Electric Ignition. THE CYLINDER BORE is treated with the LISTERAL process of chrome hardening (Van der Horst Patents) which has been proved to give the greatest wear resisting surface yet known, whether the wear may be due to heat, chemical action or abrasion from the piston rings; thus giving a greatly lengthened life throughout which the engine retains its ease of starting, fuel and lubricating oil consumption, and develops rated power.

THE PISTON AND RINGS are of high grade material, and finished to an accuracy equal to that employed in the finest motor car engine. Long life and full compression are thus assured.

THE CRANKCASE is totally enclosed and dust proof, making the engine especially suitable for work in dusty and gritty surroundings.

THE CRANKSHAFT is made from high grade steel, accurately machined and finished by grinding to an accuracy of half of one thousandth of an inch. It is extended beyond the Flywheel on both sides allowing the pulley or coupling to be fitted on either side or if necessary a pulley on each side.

THE CAM, CAMSHAFT AND ROCKERS are of high grade steel, accurately machined. The working surfaces are hardened and finished by grinding.

THE CONNECTING ROD is a Steel forging with renewable bearing at both ends. The small end Bush is of Phosphor Bronze and the large end bearing is of Steel Shells lined with white metal.

Dear Sir:

I have to refer to your letter of July 31 in the matter of the supply of two Diesel engines to replace the 6½ H.P. and 14 H.P. gasoline engines now at the Alert Bay Indian Residential School. Mr. Indian Agent Todd in a letter to this office dated August 11th stated that Mr. Anfield recommended that the existing gasoline units be replaced by 6 and 12 H.P. Lister full Diesel engines. The information I have would lead me to conclude that it would be a mistake to replace the existing gasoline engines with the Diesels of the H.P. suggested by Mr. Anfield.

In the present set-up there is an automatic feature built in the engines and connected to the batteries which starts the engines in operation when the batteries need recharging which lessens the constant attention of an attendant that would otherwise be necessary. The present proposal is, of course, to do away with the use of batteries and install two Diesels directly connected to the present generators. As the engines proposed are of less H.P. than the existing gasoline engines it is extremely doubtful if they could do the work required of them without heavier maintenance costs than we have been called upon to meet with the existing set-up. Unless we are prepared to put in more powerful units than proposed by Mr. Anfield, my opinion is that we would be well advised to retain the engines now in use and supply the batteries required.

Dear Sir:

I have to refer to Mr. Hoey's letter of the 12th instant, and regret that my letter of October 6th dealing with the application of St. Michael's Residential School for two Diesel engines to replace the present gasoline engines of the lighting plant was not sufficiently definite.

The information I intended to convey was that of the engines quoted in the low price field those offered by A.R. Williams Ltd. would be more likely to do the work required of them than the lower powered engines quoted on by Hoffars Ltd. Frankly, I am not satisfied that the Department would be well advised to replace the existing gasoline engines, which are in good condition, by the low powered Diesels suggested. Information obtained subsequent to my letter of the 6th convinces me that unless the Department is prepared to put in more powerful Diesels than those referred to herein, the best and most economical course to take would be to replace the old batteries by a new set of greater capacity and continue to operate the existing gasoline engines.

The capacity of the existing set of batteries when installed was 90 ampere hours but it is considered that it would be much better to provide 160 ampere hour set in replacement. My information is that such a set should last at least six years, and with proper care eight years or more. The estimated cost of a 160 ampere set of batteries suitable for our requirements is approximately $475.00, f.o.b. Vancouver.

I would recommend the replacement of the old batteries and the continued use of the existing gasoline engines.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Sir,

With further reference to Departmental circular of February 10th, 1938, and to the circular letter regarding this matter under date of October 4th, 1939, 502-920, 150-65, signed by Dr. H. W. McGill and Mr. R. A. Hoey, it is necessary to inform the Department that for the safety of the building the 2" fire hose on each floor of the school should be increased in length.

During the fire in June last it was this inside hydrant which saved the school, but fortunately the fire was on the inner wall rather than the far one. These hose only reach as far as the doors of the large sitting rooms or class rooms on each side of the building. These hose are 50' in length and should be increased by at least 25' on all floors except the main floor, which should have an additional 50' as the present hose does not reach the residence at all.

It would also seem necessary to advise that in our opinion fire escapes should be installed at each end of this building, rather than, or in addition to, the present escapes at the back of the building. It is realized, of course, that this would entail a large capital expenditure, but I am convinced that sooner or later these should be installed.

Your consideration and report on this matter will be appreciated.

Yours very truly,

Principal.

Dear Sir,

It is necessary to lay before the Department the need of replacements to the lighting plant engines at this school.

These engines were installed in 1929 and have given continuous and very satisfactory service ever since. Last year an application was before the Department for the replacement of these engines and batteries with a dieselized plant, and in view of this application no extensive repairs were carried out on the plant as it then stood. The Department, however, decided to replace the storage batteries and to continue the use of the present gasoline driven lighting plant engines.

Memorandum:

Dr. McGill

As requested in your memorandum of the 18th ultimo, I am forwarding herewith a copy of a report prepared by our Chief Architect, Mr. C.H. Buck, on his inspection of the Indian Residential School at Alert Bay and dealing particularly with the waterproofing of the walls.

The main points in Mr. Buck's report seem to be that the brick used originally in the School was of very poor quality but that where the wall has been waterproofed, satisfactory results were obtained. Also, that waterproofing would have to be undertaken at intervals not exceeding five years.

I hope this information will be of use to your Branch.

Director.
Memorandum:

Mr. Mills

Re: Indian Residential School,
Alert Bay, British Columbia.

In connection with work carried out at the above to render the building waterproof, our records show that in a report dated July 21st, 1937, Engineer Warren of Mr. Webb's staff stated that to determine the protective qualities of a product prepared by the Minex Co., Inc., of New York for the purpose, an area of 400 sq. ft. of the exterior brickwork was treated, with satisfactory results. The material for the work was supplied gratis.

In consequence, in addition to other roof repairs found necessary, and included in the report referred to above, Mr. Warren recommended that further waterproofing be carried out on the east walls of the school principal's residence, and laundry, covering an additional 800 sq. ft., where leakages were evident. The roof repairs, and waterproofing of walls were estimated to cost approximately $1,145.00. This expenditure was approved by our Director in his memorandum to this Service under date of September 16th, 1937, and in a letter dated September 18th, 1937, Mr. Webb was instructed to proceed with the work.

In a letter dated October 8th, 1937, Mr. Webb acknowledged our instructions, but advised that owing to the lateness of the season, work could not be started that year.

During the 1938-39 fiscal year, funds to the amount of $1,345.00 were provided, with which amount the repairs to the roof were carried out and waterproofing applied.

The above is all the information that is available on our files regarding the matter in question.

I may say, however, that while en route to Bella Bella in March, I was able to spend an hour with Mr. Anfield the Principal of the Alert Bay School, who hurriedly conducted me through the school, and indicated to me what work had been carried out by Mr. Warren.

The walls treated were:

1. The whole east wall, above the roof of the Principal's residence.
2. Part of the east wall of the Principal's residence.

T. S. Mills, Esq.,
Chief Engineer,
Engineering and Construction Service,
Ottawa.
I observed that the brick used in the school originally was a poor type of lightly burned stock brick, commonly used for backup work. It is highly absorbent, and poorly laid. I also observed that the wall area waterproofed was considerably in excess of what I now discover to have been recommended in Mr. Warren's report of July 21st, 1937. However, during a conversation with Mr. Warren in this office recently, he explained that more work than recommended had actually been carried out; but at a cost within the estimate.

I observed while at the school, that where the waterproofing compound had been applied to the exterior, the interior of such walls were dry. In other untreated areas, the plaster was wet and cracked, giving evidence of long-standing trouble.

While unfamiliar with the compound used, it would appear to be giving satisfaction, and in my opinion some similar treatment should be applied to all exterior brick surfaces.

It should be borne in mind, however, that applications of waterproofing compound, to exterior surfaces, subjected to such rainfall conditions as exist at Alert Bay, could not be considered permanent; but would require treatment at intervals not exceeding five years.

Dear Sir,

Attached hereto please find bids on the following equipment urgently required for this school:

(1) A new range for the main kitchen at the School.

We already have an oil burner, and if provided, the range should be stripped for same. The present range is in bad condition, the ovens are burned through, the flues are gone as are also the top plates. It has been in used since the new school was opened, and whilst it has given good service, it is not really of as heavy a type as is required for this work. Should the Department sanction this item, which was included in the estimates for the present fiscal year, we would like to suggest that the weight in the sectional cover (first) be increased, and the other three graduated. This is necessary through the use of an oil burner which gives off a very intense heat on the fire box section of the range. This heat is necessary in order to get the required temperatures in the ovens. Whilst we would like to have this range equipped with a canopy to take the heat out of the kitchen, we do not feel that we are justified in asking the Department for this additional expense in the light of present day conditions.

(2) A new Bakery oven.

From the bids submitted we would strongly recommend No. 3 of the Pendrith Machinery Co., Limited, that is a baking cabinet, three deck type, for wood firing, at a price of $316.00. This is the cheapest of all the bids submitted and would answer our needs adequately.

This bake oven would be used extensively for the baking of meats, fish, cakes, etc., and would prove a real saving to the big range which is not, with all its size, adequate for the needs of this school. We need an additional bake oven, if at all possible but realizing the urgency of economy, we would say that should the Department find itself unable to supply both these needs, the hot range must come first as the continued life of the present equipment for another year is extremely doubtful. Thanking you for your consideration of this matter,

Yours sincerely,

Principal

AIR MAIL

Dear Sir:

In reviewing the estimates submitted for the fiscal year 1941-42 from the Kwawkewlth Agency it is noted that an amount of $2,310.00 is requested for the completion of the waterproofing of the outside face of the Alert Bay Indian Residential School.

A similar request was made when forwarding the estimates from this Agency for the current fiscal year and we provided in our appropriation an amount of $2,100.00 for the purpose. As we have no record or having received any correspondence during the past summer in connection with this matter it was presumed, until receipt of your estimates for 1941-42, that the condition had been corrected.

Would it be possible to have this work done this fall? Similar work was done in 1938-39 under the direction of Mr. Warren who is an official at Mr. Webb's office. Please interview him and, if it is possible, you may proceed with the work at once on the understanding that the total cost of material and labour must not exceed $2,100.00. If not could you purchase the material required from the current year's appropriation? Mr. Warren will be aware of the material needed. It is understood that the work done under Mr. Warren's direction in the fiscal year 1938-39 has proved satisfactory and, therefore, it seems advisable to use the same material.

Yours truly,

Major D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B. C.
